QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TELECOM AUSTRALIA: ILLEGAL USE OF TELEPHONES

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Communications confirm or deny claims made on today's A.M. program that there are links between Telecom Australia officials and organised crime? Is it true, as claimed, that as quickly as police raid starting price betting premises, some with up to 50 telephones, the telephones are re-installed in new premises and that numbers are changed within 24 hours? Does this contrast sharply with the long delays often experienced by potential telephone subscribers? Has the practice reached such dimensions that any system of police raids is successfully negated by the next race day? What is the Minister's response to the call on the A.M. program this morning for a full scale investigation into these allegations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —At no stage and in no way is the Government prepared to condone any behaviour by officers within Telcom or any other officers that in any way breaches the law. It is for that reason that Telecom lays down very tight procedures which inhibit the provision of telephone connections to any known illegal activity. Allegations were made last year in the Press, which I referred to Telecom and asked it to take up, regarding the treatment of starting price bookmakers. I understand that this matter has been discussed at the recurring meetings of Police Ministers, the last one being held last November. My colleague the Minister for Administrative Services has advised me that he is awaiting a report from police officers, who are now intent on trying to ensure that there has been no failure to pursue inquiries, that any illegality in the connections pursued by Telecom has been corrected.

ANSWER.PARA: Telecom has advised me that there have been at least 40 disconnections as a result of illegal use of the telephone system this financial year. There has also been a number of post-conviction disconnections where, as a result of action taken within the courts by police authorities, the telephone has been seen to be used for illegal purposes. I would hope that if the honourable gentleman or the person who made the assertion on the A.M. program this morning have any information that could be of help in identifying persons concerned he would pass that information on to the New South Wales Police Force, to the joint task force that is presently inquiring generally into drug activities and so on, or to the Federal Police.

From the point of view of Telecom itself, this activity is in no way affecting its capacity to connect subscribers as and when they apply. Every effort is being made by Telecom to connect new applicants for telephones as soon as possible, subject to the availability of suitable local facilities. If the honourable gentleman has any information about this matter, I would be very happy if he passed it on to the sources I have mentioned. However, I certainly see insufficient substance in any of the assertions made to date to justify any wider-based inquiry. If the honourable gentleman has any such information which might assist in broadening the necessity for an inquiry, I would be very happy to receive it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer will be aware of the opposition to the Government's proposal to amend the sales tax regulations to allow retailers, if they wish, to require local government and related organisations, parents and citizens organisations and other organisations to pay sales tax and then claim the refund . Is it still the intention of the Government to proceed with these amendments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the opposition, particularly from a large number of local government bodies in Victoria. I would say to the honourable gentleman that that opposition has arisen as a result of a misunderstanding of the announcement I made on 18 December and also a misunderstanding of subsequent announcements I made in an endeavour to remove the original misunderstanding. At no stage has it ever been contemplated by the Government that people would be obliged to take advantage of the procedure that I outlined on 18 December. The purpose of that procedure was to enable bodies which would be exempt from the payment of sales tax included in the class of sales tax extension, which has been rejected in another place, to pay, in effect, the sales tax, and then to claim an exemption. But it was to be quite optional, and those purchasers were still to retain the right to deal on an exemption basis in respect of individual items with individual retailers.

ANSWER.PARA: However, be that as it may, the fact is that, now, through the combined opposition of the Labor Party and the Democrats, the legislation has been stalled in the Senate. In those circumstances, it is highly questionable whether there is any point in proceeding with giving effect to the announcement that I made on 18 December. I had to obtain advice on certain procedural matters from the Taxation Office, but my own disposition-and, I believe, that of the Government-is that as the 2 1/2 per cent is not going ahead, the exemption procedure that I outlined is, therefore, academic, and that ought not to go ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question without notice to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the Minister to a report in Monday's edition of the Australian Financial Review that there has been opposition by the Department of Trade and Resources and the Department of the Treasury to the Australian Government's ratification of the Law of the Sea Treaty. Is the Minister in a position to explain why these departmental differences have been allowed to become public, so that they can now be used by United States interests as an argument against ratification of the treaty in order to protect such narrow interests as those of the deep sea mining companies? Will the Minister indicate to the heads of the relevant government departments the necessity of having an Australian bipartisan attitude, which is in the interests of the developing countries, particularly the countries in the Pacific region? Will he also indicate to the departmental heads the words of the Prime Minister of Fiji-that unless the United States ratifies this treaty, it will not have a friend in the Pacific?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Contrary to the comments just made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, I am informed that there was agreement between the departments about Australia's attitude. Be that as it may, government policy is made by the Government, and the Australian delegation was instructed to vote in favour of the Convention on the Law of the Sea at the 11th session, which ended in New York on 30 April. I think that it would be of interest to the House if I outlined precisely what happened at the end of the conference. The convention was adopted by a vote of 130 in favour, four against, and 17 abstentions. As I mentioned a moment ago, Australia voted in favour, and we expect that the text will be open for signature later this year.

ANSWER.PARA: This has brought one step closer the objectives of this Government and, indeed, of the Australian Parliament, of getting a comprehensive and widely accepted international convention. The text adopted contains many new principles and provisions which have been accepted by consensus after a great many years' work. I extend thanks to the members of successive Australian delegations who have worked so hard over this period. There is considerable satisfaction at the widespread support for the convention. It is, nevertheless, disappointing that the text was not adopted by consensus, and it was particularly disappointing to us that the United States voted against the convention.

We understand the concerns of the United States, most of which were directed particularly at section XI, relating to the exploitation of the deep sea bed resources and, indeed, we sympathise with some of those concerns. But I hope that, as the heat of debate cools in the aftermath of the conference, the United States and the other countries which did not support adoption of the convention will carefully reconsider their positions as the convention is open for signature. I hope that they will look again at the advantages of working within a secure and agreed international framework, even though it might be at some cost to their own national goals. I hope that they will agree to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Industrial Relations report to the House the results of the maritime-waterfront conference held in Sydney last Friday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can report to the House the results of that conference. It was indeed a very successful one because an undertaking was given by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Confederation of Australian Industry that they would investigate, with their own affiliates, the existing consultative arrangements and dispute-settling procedures on the waterfront and in the maritime industries. That was an important undertaking because it means that the parties themselves recognise that there is room for improvement. The ACTU and the CAI have agreed to provide me with an interim report so that I may in turn report to the Premiers at their June conference.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the features of the conference last Friday was the number of people who were there. About 50 delegates attended. They represented 18 of the 22 unions which had been invited and 8 employer bodies, including the Australian National Line and Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. The very fact that so many people and so many different unions and organisations had to be invited does identify an immediate problem on the waterfront and in the maritime industries. There are moves already afoot for the development of common negotiations and a common award on the waterfront and of course to reduce the number of unions with which employers have to deal. I understand that on the maritime side similar moves are being made in the background within the union movement.

It is against that background, of course, amongst others, that the Government put forward its proposals to open the door within our industrial legislation for the formation of industry unions. The observation was made to me that when one looked around the conference and saw the number of different organisations and unions involved one could immediately put one's finger on one of the fundamental problems facing the waterfront and the maritime industries of Australia. I look forward to receiving the reports from the ACTU and the CAI because I think they will provide us, from a basis of self-examination, with a foundation upon which we can do further work to improve the industrial climate in the ports of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs inform the House as to whether the levels of participation in the Government's major manpower schemes, in particular the Special Youth Employment Training Program, are as great as anticipated in the 1981-82 Budget? If not, can he provide some indication as to the likely shortfall in actual compared to budgeted participation in the major programs? Can he indicate what he perceives to be the major reasons for this inability to achieve the expected levels of participation ?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: EMPLOYMENT AND YOUTH AFFAIRS; CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a large measure of success in the operation of the Government's manpower and training programs including the Special Youth Employment Training Program to which the honourable member has referred. However , the success has not been confined to that program. On the evidence that I have seen, a number of the other programs have been very successful. The evidence for that proposition is evidence which comes to me from employers. Indeed, I was at a function on Friday where a number of employers spoke very highly of the success so far as they were concerned of the Special Youth Employment Training Program. It is not simply a question of the fact that a subsidy is paid because there is evidence-and I can certainly go this far-that well over half of the young people who undertake work experience under that program either stay on with the same employer after the subsidy has come to an end or virtually immediately obtain employment without a subsidy with another employer. That is the first part of the evidence.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of the evidence relates to an investigation of the operation of the program undertaken recently by the Bureau of Labour Market Research. This is being conducted with the assistance of a detailed survey. I have seen some preliminary results of that survey and an analysis is being undertaken to provide me with the details of the results. However, the early and preliminary results indicate quite clearly that that scheme is successful. It may not be the case that other schemes are as successful. We have never maintained that there is a 100 per cent success rate with respect to young people and others undertaking training under our programs. Nevertheless, a great deal of evidence is available to suggest that the programs have been successful.

There may be some shortfall in the number undertaking work experience and training under the programs. It is very difficult to predict accurately at any time of the year the complete use that will be made of the scheme for the succeeding 12 months or, indeed, for any long period. As a result the Government announced recently a concerted drive through the Commonwealth Employment Service to encourage more employers to take on more young unemployed people under the Special Youth Employment Training Program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer: Has the Government considered what I believe to be a worthwhile proposal for a tripartite economic council made up of representatives of government, unions and employers? Would such a council be an ideal forum to discuss, amongst other issues, the link between real increases in wages, inflation and unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the pre-Budget consultations between the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Government the possibility of more detailed discussions taking place, possibly on a tripartite level between employers, representatives of employees and the Government, was discussed. The Government, for its part, reacted positively to the idea of such talks taking place. It was agreed between the Government and the executive of the ACTU that for talks of that kind to have any prospect of success in making a contribution towards an improvement in national economic understanding, it would be necessary in the first instance to agree to a sensible basis on which the talks should take place. To that end we invited the ACTU to put to us concrete proposals as to how the talks might be structured.

ANSWER.PARA: We have, through my colleague the Minister for Industrial Relations, discussed the matter in general terms with a number of employers' representatives. The Government sees great value in fostering such talks taking place. I think all of us in this House would be aware that nothing but good can come of a greater understanding between employers, employees and the Government of the economic consequences of certain action by different sections of the community, not just the actions of employees, but also the actions of government and employers. Equally, we all recognise that overnight we cannot bring about a change in climate and in attitude. If we are to have any prospect of something useful coming out of discussions of this kind, on the one hand there must be a willingness on the part of all parties to respond positively-for our part we have that willingness and we have already responded positively-and on the other hand, equally, we must have realistic and not unrealistic aspirations as to what might be achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware of a recent Public Service Board report which indicates that since the enactment of the controversial Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act on 6 February last year, 719 public servants between the ages of 55 and 59 have voluntarily retired? Most of these retirements are in the senior levels of the Third Division of the Public Service , as exampled by the Taxation Office, where 90 per cent of the 114 voluntary retirements were from that Third Division-in other words, those with the high pensions who can afford to retire and go on part time consultative work, et cetera. Does he also realise that much needed expertise is being lost to the Public Service, particularly in sections such as the Taxation Office? Does the Prime Minister realise that his whole concept of the Act has backfired and what does he intend--
—Order! The honourable gentleman will ask for information and stop giving it.
—I am finishing now, Mr Speaker. What does he intend to do to reverse this process so as to protect the efficiency of the Public Service?

—Some assumptions inherent in the honourable gentleman's question are not necessarily correct. Obviously, especially in the first year of the scheme which allowed voluntary retirement from the age of 55 years, it would be expected that a number of people might take advantage of that provision. The matter was discussed and debated for many months-indeed, I think for a year or two-before it finally became law and therefore a backlog of people would have wanted to take advantage of the provisions. I find it odd that the honourable gentleman believes that people within the Public Service but who wish to get out should virtually be conscripted to stay within the Public Service. I would not have thought that that would work well and to the advantage of the Public Service, for the benefit of the morale of the Public Service or for service to the Commonwealth. I think that all honourable members in this House ought to know-I hope most agree-that by and large Australia has been very well served by its Public Service, especially by those in the First and Second Divisions and the senior levels of the Third Division--
—What about the Chairman of the Public Service Board?
—Order! The honourable member for Chifley will remain silent.
—They have worked very hard and very long in the interests of the Service. I am not quite sure what point the honourable gentleman sought to make, except that he does not like the legislation.
—You have ruined the Public Service. That is what prompted it.

—This legislation was very much designed to improve conditions in the Public Service and to open up further options to its members. The fact that a number of people have taken advantage of the early retirement provisions is in no way remarkable. It will increase the managerial flexibility of the higher levels of the Service and is not to be regretted at all.
—Ask the Chairman of the Public Service Board.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Chifley to remain silent.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to reports of massive demonstrations in Poland during 1 and 2 May. Is the Minister able to explain the implications of these most recent demonstrations?

—I have seen accounts, as I am sure all honourable members of the House have, of the two large pro-Solidarity demonstrations held in Warsaw in recent days. The demonstrations emphasise the continuing gulf between the Polish people and the martial law regime there, despite some relaxation of the martial law restrictions. While the Government welcomes any betterment of the present lot of the Polish people, we cannot lose sight of the fact that martial law, itself, still remains in force, that thousands of people are still interned and that many factories still remain subject to military discipline. I note that in recent days the Polish Ministry of the Interior has issued a warning relating to the present relaxation, saying that internment, reinternment and summary penal provisions are still in operation under martial law regulations. As I stated in my Press release of earlier this year, the Government calls for the lifting of martial law in Poland, the release of detainees and an early return to the circumstances in which the people of Poland can be left free to decide their own future. These conditions have not been met and until they are the Government cannot consider conducting business as usual with the military regime in Poland.

—I ask the Treasurer whether it is a fact that the pension increases which are now due will take hundreds of thousands of pensioners within about $6.50 a week of having their pensions taxed and that by May of next year all pensioners will be having their pensions taxed. Is it also a fact that today pensioners who earn more than the allowable income are already the highest marginally taxed people in Australia because for every additional $2 they earn the Department of Social Security takes $1 and the Australian Taxation Office takes another 32c-a total of 66c in the dollar compared with the highest marginal tax of 60c in the dollar? Will the Treasurer ensure that any measures necessary to remove these unconscionable imposts upon pensioners will be taken?

—It is true that shortly, when the pension next goes up, it will be closer to the ceiling of the zero rate step in the tax scale. But as the Minister for Social Security and I have said time and again-I repeat it in the interests of allaying unnecessary fears on the part of pensioners-there is no substance to any suggestion that as a result of the next increase any person who relies on the pension alone will be subject to tax. To raise the matter in the manner it was raised by the honourable member for Hunter is calculated only to disturb and not to allay the fears of Australian pensioners. It does the welfare of Australian pensioners no good at all for the honourable member to try, by a cheap trick, to make misleading representations about the effects of the Government's policies. The honourable member has again talked about the marginal rate of tax payable by pensioners. He is talking about the combination of the withdrawal rate of 50c in the dollar and the application, for the first time, of tax. If he knows anything about the history of taxation and pensions in Australia, and I am sure that he does because he follows these matters very closely, he knows that that kind of charge has been capable of being made ever since the taxation of pensions was first introduced-not by a Liberal Government but by a former Labor Government of this country. That sort of charge has always been capable of being made, but to suggest that the combined effect of the withdrawal of the pension at a rate of 50c in the dollar and the application of the standard rate of taxation of 32c represents in reality a marginal tax rate is completely to misread the situation.
—Can the Minister for Trade and Resources advise the House on the prospect of a commercial uranium enrichment industry being established in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it was in 1979 that the Government made a decision to seek a commercial feasibility study of the possibilities of having a uranium enrichment industry in Australia. As a result, the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia was formed. It consisted of four major Australian companies: Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, CSR Ltd, Peko-Wallsend Ltd and Western Mining Corporation Ltd. This group set about looking at the various forms of technology. In April of last year it presented a pre-feasibility study of the work that it had done. The Government then gave it further authority to go ahead with a full commercial feasibility study and it has been working on that. Of course, the success of a uranium enrichment industry in Australia will depend wholly on whether it can be competitive. I think there is every chance of such an industry developing in Australia and being competitive because this group is not in a hurry. It is looking at the progress that is being made in technology. Changes are taking place all the time. It is hoped that in the course of the group's study, which will probably take a couple of years, it will be able to pick up the most advanced and latest technology which, if we do move into an enrichment industry, will make it competitive with the rest of the world.

—I ask the Minister for Education whether it is a fact, as declared in the final report of the Vice-Chancellor of the Australian National University, that there has been an overall decline in the number of students entering tertiary education and that a major reason lies in the 'striking reduction in recent years in the public financial assistance for tertiary students'. Is this claim supported by the fact that the maximum Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowance is now worth nearly $12 a week less in real terms than in 1974 and the further fact that the proportion of tertiary students receiving public assistance has fallen from 79 per cent in 1974 to 59 per cent currently, that is , a drop of 20 per cent in the period of the Fraser Government? In view of the convincing evidence establishing that the TEAS allowance is inadequate to provide a reasonable level of support for students from lower socio-economic homes dependent on this allowance, and the extraordinary reduction in general public assistance available for tertiary students since this Government came to office, will the Minister guarantee in the forthcoming Budget to increase appropriately the TEAS allowance and ease the severe means test that so savagely discriminates against students and their families with greatest need?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report referred to by the Leader of the Opposition in relation to student allowances and the question of enrolments in universities. There has been a change in the balance of enrolments in universities and colleges of advanced education. I am sure that this is also known to the Leader of the Opposition. In recent times there has been an increase in the number of students to whom we would generally refer as mature age students. There has also been a decline in the number of students going straight from school into universities and colleges of advanced education.

ANSWER.PARA: A number of reasons have been advanced for this change in the balance, including desire on the part of some potential students of universities and colleges of advanced education to take some time off after leaving school before returning to full time education. It has also been advanced-as suggested by the Leader of the Opposition-that the level of student assistance allowance, or the Tertiary Education Allowance Scheme as we call it, is also a contributing factor . In responding to that part of the honourable member's question, I draw attention to the fact that it has been stated by many people in the higher education field that when, I think in 1974, the previous Government did away with tuition fees and TEAS was introduced, there was not a big change-indeed there was not a noticeable change-in the entry into higher education of people from the lower socio-economic group. I know that the Leader of the Opposition did not seek to suggest this, but it is not true, as suggested by some people, that the assistance provided by way of TEAS is the factor that determines whether more young people from the lower socio-economic group enter universities and colleges of advanced education.

The Government is concerned about this whole area of student assistance. It is being reviewed at the present time in the context of the forthcoming Budget. The Government has also announced its intention to introduce a students loan scheme. I emphasise that this proposed loan scheme, which the Government hopes will be operating at the beginning of 1983, will be in addition to TEAS and not a substitute for TEAS. It is a new scheme that is being devised by the Government to provide another means of support for students undertaking higher education. I give the Leader of the Opposition and the House an assurance that the level of TEAS and the means test applying to TEAS will be reviewed in the Budget context. In addition, details regarding the proposed loans scheme, that is, eligibility and the conditions under which loans will be provided, will be considered in the Budget context and an announcement will be made soon after that.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL HIGHWAYS IN NEW SOUTH WALES

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Transport to his Press statement of 27 November 1981 in which he expressed concern about the proposal of the New South Wales Government to commit a disproportionate share of Commonwealth funds to construction of new national highway work between Sydney and Newcastle and also that this proposed transfer would result in an unacceptable slowing down of urgently needed construction work on the Hume Highway. I ask the Minister: First , what are the Commonwealth's priorities for construction of national highways in New South Wales? Secondly, what action is being taken to implement these priorities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since 1971 priorities for the national highway program in New South Wales have indeed been shared between the Sydney-Newcastle section of the northern highway and the Hume Highway between Sydney and Melbourne. The Commonwealth's first priority has been the Hume Highway which, of course, links two very important population centres. In May last year I wrote to the New South Wales Minister for Roads informing him that I would expect the New South Wales program for national highways to be consistent with the ratio of funds between the two roads, that is, the Newcastle-Sydney road and the Sydney-Melbourne road. I was surprised to receive the program from the Minister in New South Wales three months after the commencement of the financial year, asking the Commonwealth to increase the effort on the Sydney to Queensland border road by 7 per cent and to reduce the effort on the Hume Highway by 6 per cent. I sought from him a revised program to conform with the Commonwealth program. Five months have now elapsed and I have had no further response from him. So far this has not resulted in a hold up of any work in New South Wales because projects were approved on the Hume Highway and, of course, some projects were ongoing and were approved on the Sydney-Newcastle end. But it seems extraordinary that the New South Wales Minister would not have a sense of urgency regarding full approval for the New South Wales highways program.

ANSWER.PARA: I can assure the honourable gentleman that we will maintain our priorities. There are some very important unfinished works on the Hume Highway and, so far as the Commonwealth is concerned, the New South Wales Government will adhere to the priorities we have established. Of course, the State governments receive each month one-twelfth of the total sum for all categories of roads. If New South Wales continues in this vein we may have to cease payment on a monthly basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs and preface it by referring to an article in the Melbourne Age of Saturday, 24 April, which outlined a number of serious administrative and legal difficulties being experienced by the Community Youth Support Scheme. I ask the Minister: Is it a fact that employers involved in offering work experience opportunities to CYSS participants could be prosecuted under the State labour laws if participants are employed at less than award rates? If so, what does he intend to do about this situation? Will all CYSS participants who engage in work experience or voluntary activities be automatically covered by existing workers compensation provisions in each State? If not, does his Department intend taking necessary action to rectify this situation? Is it a fact that Commonwealth Employment Service managers appointed to local CES committees are not being paid overtime for attendance at evening meetings of these committees? If so, what is the explanation for this?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: EMPLOYMENT AND YOUTH AFFAIRS; CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I did have brought to my attention the article to which the honourable member refers, including the part in which I was recorded accurately as having said that the Government has received a great deal of praise from a large number of Community Youth Support Scheme projects and their committees for the reforms that have been made to the scheme which is now working very well.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to the three matters to which the honourable member referred, firstly, it was never intended that young people who are participants in CYSS would work on a full time basis. They work for work experience. That is intended to give them the experience which will better fit them when they apply for jobs. They will then be able to say accurately that they have had practical working experience and that will put them in a much better and stronger position when they apply for jobs.

With respect to the workers compensation aspect, the policy in the past has been that the committee which has been given funds to cover all or most of the running costs of the scheme was given the responsibility of taking out its own insurance. Many of the committees have done that. Those committees which have understandably drawn our attention to that matter perhaps may not be aware of the fact that other committees have taken out their own workers compensation insurance from time to time. If, however, there is a particular and widespread problem with respect to that matter I will, of course, investigate it.

With respect to Commonwealth Employment Service officers attending committee meetings, it will be recalled that it was felt, we believe on very good grounds, that there should be more of a liaison between the Commonwealth Employment Service and the CYSS projects to make the local committees more aware of employment opportunities in the neighbourhood and to make CYSS more employment oriented. We believe that that was a good decision. It was never intended or suggested that the CES managers should attend every single meeting of the local committees and I would be surprised if in fact anyone expected them to do so. They will be there and they will be available when their assistance is needed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable gentleman claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The honourable gentleman may proceed.

—Under a prominent headline 'Bilingual Australia Planned' the Australian newspaper yesterday asserted that the Federal Government had taken a radical step towards identifying and adopting a second language to be spoken in Australia and said that I foreshadowed the policy in an address at an award ceremony in Melbourne at the weekend. The Australian has this morning editorialised on the basis of this report, saying that it is difficult to see much advantage in this proposal and that no doubt Mr Macphee will be able to make clear precisely what he has in mind. I am informed that Mr Sam Lipski on radio station 3AW in Melbourne this morning has expressed similar reservations and has called upon me to make a clear statement.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make it quite clear to the House and to the Australian people that the Australian report yesterday is utterly wrong. It is a complete misrepresentation of what I said. I did not say that Australia should adopt a second language. I am in fact completely opposed to any such proposition. It is a nonsense and it is something which I would never have thought of advocating. Specifically, I reject the suggestion that Australia should ever have a policy leading to a reduction in the predominance of English in areas such as the law, the administration, education and even in day to day conversation. That was what was imputed to me. Any genuine examination of my speech which was released to the Press will show that I was not advocating what has been attributed to me. My speech in fact concerned multiculturalism, not national language policy. In it I stressed the importance of what one might term our core culture, which includes the English language, our Parliament, our judicial system and the freedoms which are integral to those. I stress that successive waves of migrants have embraced those values and that they are the essential core of our society. What I said on language was that I hoped that an understanding of other languages would enrich our own society while maintaining Australia's social cohesion and would extend our effective dealings with other countries.

Last evening I authorised a letter in these terms to go to the editor of the Australian. Because the Australian telex was registering as being out of order at approximately 6 p.m. this was not dispatched until 9 a.m. this morning. Had it been received I trust that the Australian would not have proceeded with its editorial this morning. In any event, I would have hoped that the editorial writer would have actually checked the story against my speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's expecting a bit much, isn't it?
—It would spoil a good story.

—It is expecting a bit much, as the honourable member for Port Adelaide says. It would spoil a good story and it is expecting a bit much. But in any event, had that been done the editorial should not have eventuated. Even though the editorial referred to reports of what I said, the only person who interpreted my speech as calling for a second language was the Australian's own reporter. So the editorial fed upon its own misrepresentations. That reporter set up straw arguments which the editorial demolished. I agree with the demolition but I resent my name being associated with that newspaper's creation.

SPEECH.PARA: In order that this astonishing misrepresentation of my speech might be fairly dispelled I draw the attention of those interested in this subject to the fact that my speech will be in the next issue of the Commonwealth Record so that all reasonable persons might judge for themselves what I really said. Because of the number of people who have phoned my office protesting about what has been attributed to me I ask for your indulgence, Mr Speaker, to read three quotations from what I actually said. First of all, I said:

In truth the core culture of Australia is based on the historical accident of British rule and owes virtually everything to the English essence of that British rule: The language, the parliamentary tradition and the judicial institutions.
I also said:

Each successive wave of migrants has embraced the English core culture; not only by adopting its language and institutions but by the freedoms which are essential to those institutions. The adoption of the core was said to be assimilation but in fact it was integration because the culture which surrounded the core was an identifiably new mix of cultures. It is a continually evolving multiculture. For that cultural diversity to retain social cohesion, however, it must guarantee equality of opportunity to all. Thus the new Migrant Selection Scheme places an emphasis upon literacy in the language of origin-not on a prior knowledge of English; but persons arriving in Australia as migrants are expected to learn English as soon as possible and, through that language, to gain other skills.
Finally, Mr Speaker, with your indulgence, I also said:

Language is the deepest manifestation of culture and enables the expression of features unique to a particular culture. Major domestic and international advantages to Australia are already evident from the linguistic abilities of its population. There will shortly be an enquiry by a Senate Committee on matters relevant to the formation of a National Language Policy and perhaps Phillip Institute of Technology will make a submission to the enquiry.

The idea of a National Language Policy which will enable future Australians to acquire a fluency in languages other than our national language is most important. It is sad to reflect that many people here today do not speak the language which was the native tongue of their parents. This was because the philosophy in Australia when those parents migrated was that people should abandon their former culture (including language) and become Australian even though no clear effort had been made to define what that meant.

There is no dispute that English is the national language and the the institutions and freedoms associated with it are central to the Australian culture. There ought also be no dispute that services should be delivered to people by Federal, State and local government and by the private sector regardless of their ethnic origin though having regard to any special disability they might have. Thus English language disability must be rectified as soon as possible by the availability of language courses--
Obviously, English language courses-

But ethnic specific services-positive discrimination-ought to be carefully circumscribed, so that what are often called 'mainstream services' are delivered to everyone but with a greater degree of cultural sensitivity than used to characterise the Australian way of doing things.

I believe that those extracts expose the nonsense of the Australian's report and its editorial. My words are contrary to those attributed to me. My sentiments could not be more opposed to those which have been falsely attributed to me. My sentiments were very clear to any reasonable observer and they were very well received by the 2,000 people who were in the audience.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This statement relates to Australia's demographic trends and the 1982-83 immigration program. Population size, composition and distribution have far-reaching implications for many policy areas. This was recognised by the Government when it decided to present annual reports to Parliament on Australia's demographic trends. The first such report, which I tabled last year, provoked a great deal of discussion. I believe it has added a good deal to the growing awareness of population issues in government, in private enterprise and in the community in general. I now have pleasure in tabling the second such report, 'Review of Australia's Demographic Trends 1982'. This report has provided valuable background to the Government's decisions on future migrant intakes, to which I will return shortly. I would first like to draw the attention of honourable members to some of the main points of the review.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's population growth rate fell from above two per cent at the beginning of the 1970s to a little above one per cent in 1975-76. Since then it has increased, to 1.64 per cent in 1980-81. This is higher than in all but a few developed countries. For example, recent estimates of annual population growth are: Canada 1.1 per cent, Japan 0.9 per cent, the United States 0.7 per cent, New Zealand 0.3 per cent and the United Kingdom 0.1 per cent. In Australia in 1980 the net reproduction rate, a common measure of population replacement, was 0.91. This was nine per cent below the long term replacement level of 1.0. It was also below the previously lowest recorded levels of the depression years of the early 1930s. Nevertheless, there has been some increase in the numbers of births during the last two years after the steady decline throughout most of the 1970s. In 1980-81 there were 231,000 births, compared with 224,000 in 1979-80. This rise is the result of an increase in the number of women in the peak childbearing ages of 20 years to 29 years rather than an increase in fertility, as measured by the average number of babies born to each woman. The rate of decline in fertility has, however, lessened over the same period. This may foreshadow an upswing in the near future, following similar trends in some other developed countries.

There has been an increase in immigration since the mid-1970s. Settler arrivals in 1980-81 were 111,000 and are expected to be about 123,000 in 1981-82. In deciding upon future migration levels, programs have traditionally been expressed in terms of numbers of arrivals. However, once a migrant has been issued with a visa, he or she may choose to travel to Australia at any time in the following 12 months. This has made management of the program somewhat unwieldy. It has led to the delay in the departure of intending migrants on occasions in order to meet arrival targets. To improve the management of the migration program it will be expressed from now on in terms of numbers of applicants issued with visas. It is estimated that about 5 per cent of applicants issued with visas do not in fact migrate. New Zealand citizens are not subject to immigration selection and visa requirements and are no longer included in migration program numbers.

Against this background I can announce to the House today the Government's decision on the migration program for 1982-83. The number of migrant visas to be issued in 1982-83 will be in the range of 115,000 to 120,000, and I would expect that there would be a modest increase in the program over the following two years. These figures will, of course, be kept under review and adjusted as might seem appropriate.

This immigration program reflects the Government's new migration policy, effective from 19 April 1982. It is a response to the community demand for more family migration, Australia's continuing humanitarian commitments, and shortages of workers in some professional and skilled occupation groups. However, it also takes account of the need not to import unemployment, and to that end independent applicants with occupations not in shortage here or without close family resident in Australia will not be eligible to apply under the new policy.

The population effects of migration also depend on permanent departures and on long term movements into and out of Australia. Net annual migration gains can be expected to continue to fluctuate from year to year, but broad population trends can be illustrated by using a long term average annual net migration gain of 100 ,000. On this assumption, Australia's population in the year 2001 would reach 19 .9 million, or 14 per cent higher than the 17.4 million which would result from a zero net gain from migration. Together with expected levels of natural increase, this level of net migration gain would give us an average annual growth rate of about one and one half per cent over the next 2 years.

I would now like to mention some changes in the age structure of the population . Since the beginning of the 1970s our population has been aging. Preliminary figures from the 1981 census show that the population aged under 15 years declined by 43,000 between 1976 and 1981, while the population over 60 years grew by 250,000. Immigration has tended to slow the aging process because most migrants are younger than the average age of the population. Nevertheless, even with the average net migration gain of 100,000 a year I mentioned earlier, the number of people aged 65 and over will grow much more rapidly than numbers in other age groups: More than 60 per cent by 2001 compared with a 34 per cent growth in the population as a whole, and a 24 per cent growth in numbers of children under 15. By the year 2001, the proportion of the population aged 65 and over is expected to be nearly 12 per cent, compared with 9.7 per cent in 1981. However, in many developed countries this aging process has already proceeded much further. For example, in 1980 the proportion of the population aged 65 and over in the Federal Republic of Germany, the German Democratic Republic, Sweden and the United Kingdom was between 14 per cent and 16 per cent.

Changes in the age structure will have implications for many areas of policy. For example, in education considerable flexibility will be required in teaching and ancillary staff and buildings and equipment because of expected substantial fluctuations in the numbers reaching primary, secondary and tertiary education age groups. As the population ages, so will the labour force. By 2001 there are expected to be relatively fewer working-age people under 35 years and appreciably more between 35 and 55 years. The labour force may thus become more experienced, but perhaps less mobile. An aging population will also lead to changes in demand for goods and services. Market growth can be expected to move from teenagers and young adults to the more mature.

Because many demographic changes are gradual, there has in the past been a tendency to disregard them. The few examples that I have given demonstrate that the consequences of demographic trends will play a very important part in determining Australia's future. It is therefore critical that we monitor those trends regularly and forecast their implications. We will then be better prepared to face the challenges of tomorrow. The matters covered in the 'Review of Australia's Demographic Trends 1982' are very important long term issues. I commend the Review to the House. I present the following papers:
Australia's Demographic Trends Review-Ministerial Statement, 4 May 1982.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the tabling of the report and the comments of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee). Before referring to either the report or the comments I raise with the Minister a question that is directly concerned with our immigration policy; that is, the implications of the changes in the law that took place as from 19 April. A very long investigation throughout 1981 brought about those changes. A great deal of information was passed out as to how both sides of the Parliament saw this as an opportunity for reinforcing family reunion as the basis of our migration program in Australia. Many thousands of people are now flocking to the migration offices seeking information, forms and guidance on how they may be able to use the new migration program in order to facilitate entry into Australia of members of their families. Unfortunately the bureaucratic processes have not been oiled up to meet the expected demand. The Public Service Board has had before it for some time applications for increased staff for the Department. As yet we have no reply as to when that is likely to take place. There is no doubt that the major offices, particularly Sydney and Melbourne, have not been able to deal with the number of people who have come before them. I am told that in some sections of the Department in Canberra-I would like the Department to check on this-even incorrect forms have been handed out to people who have sought information, in the hope that perhaps they can be put off for some time.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a great pity that having had such fanfare and such mutual support in the introduction of this new scheme, there has been a breakdown in the mechanisms to deal with the people making inquiries. Obviously a lot of the people making inquiries will be disappointed because they have not looked at exactly how they will be affected by the changes. They expect that the family reunion program has quite a wide interpretation and, in fact, is in accordance with their own interpretation of 'family reunion'. Nevertheless, a number of people seeking assistance will be within the new guidelines. If the Government is serious about making these changes it should have been serious about seeing that the Department had the required number of staff to deal with the people now coming before it. Since 19 April our office has been inundated with complaints from people making inquiries and from staff who have been expected to cope with this rush of new inquiries without being able to deal with them. I ask the Minister to move speedily on those matters because a lot of people have been extremely disappointed with the way the Department has dealt with them to date.

When this report was tabled last year I said, and I repeat, that it is an impossible exercise for the Parliament to deal in isolation with a report on demographic changes. Demographic changes are of enormous importance to Australia but to have the report in isolation of what will happen to the aging of people, what will happen to the Government's decision about the migrant intake and what will happen to the percentage of people who will retire, means absolutely nothing at all to us. If this Parliament were not so lazy and if this Government were not so lazy in terms of utilising all the abilities that preside in this Parliament, parliamentarians would be used to look at all the policy areas that should be a part of this report. All we are doing here is saying that next year we will have a migrant intake of between 115,000 and 120,000 people. Without really knowing why, the majority of people in Australia support a general increase in Australia's population. The number announced by the Government will service not only the domestic demand of the ethnic communities here in Australia who want to bring out their own people but also it will service in a humanitarian way the refugees and the special humanitarian program which has been announced by this Government.

But what does it mean for Australia to say, for instance, that we have 15 million people now but in 18 years' time we will have 20 million people? The Government should not just ask the Parliament and the people outside it to accept that the additional five milllion people will be a good thing and we hope it all works out okay. This Government, especially now-or any government in power in any country-when it is embarking on a program that will see a 33 1/3 per cent increase in its population in 18 years ought to have some idea of the ramifications of that increase. What will it mean, for instance, for people who live in Sydney, a city which by that time will probably have 4 1/2 million people? What will it mean for those who live in Melbourne, which will have four million people? This is the likely outcome of the actions on which we are embarking. We do not really know the impact on local or State governments, on the planning authorities or on all the social welfare authorities.

We do not really know what will occur industrially in 18 years' time that might change the sort of pronouncements made by the Government in this demographic report presented today. For instance, at this very moment Sweden is going through an election campaign. The Socialist Party of Sweden is predicted to be winning that campaign and is likely to be re-elected on 19 September. One of its platforms is the introduction of a 30-hour working week. This is the position in 1982 in Sweden. We are just getting into 36 and 38 hour working weeks in Australia. What will be the ramifications for Australian industry over the next 20 years? What will be the make-up of the work force? Now we refer to people who are over 65 years of age and retired as the aging community. Who will we refer to in the year 2001 as the aging community and how will we cater for those people? Every one of us knows, if we face reality, that today we are not looking after the people who have retired. The 60 per cent of people who do not have access to superannuation are being looked after very poorly by the governments of Australia. But what will occur when we see the massive increase in their numbers, as predicted by the Minister today, working on today's standards? No one expects the standards of today to apply in 18 years' time, so the 12 per cent or 14 per cent increase in the number of people over 65 years is likely to result in a 20 per cent increase in the number of people who have retired from work in the year 2000. Are we seriously considering going from year to year embarking on this process of trying to maintain all these retired people on the same sloppy sort of pension system that is applicable in Australia today?

That is one area of the spectrum. What will happen in the field of education? What will it mean if we have fewer kids aged between five and 15 years in 10 years' time or if we have troughs and peaks in the field of education? How is Australia factually facing up to the number of people who will go through its educational institutions over the next 18 years? That is another area. We have the whole question of urban development. There will be a lack of mobility because of the numbers of people who will be unemployed. Half a million unemployed will not have the right to move around Australia. How many people do we expect to be unemployed because of what will happen to our industries in the next 18 years?

All of those things should be ancillary to this report tabled today. These are not matters that are so abstract and so far removed that we can leave them to the next generation of politicians. In the year 2000 people will be living virtually by the standards that we set in the Parliament today and we cannot run away from that. But we should face the fact that there are vast gaps in the way in which we are dealing with these problems.

The report says, very briefly, that in Australia fertility rates and mortality rates are highest amongst the Aboriginal people. As a nation we can never hold our heads high until the mortality rate of the Aboriginal people is exactly the same as that of the white communities of Australia. For 200 years we have lived with a disgraceful record of treatment of Aboriginal people. We cannot pass that off by saying: 'Well, they are having bigger families and they die younger than the rest of us do'. We should be able to say that we have a program in that regard. No one expects any government to be able to overcome the problems with which Australia will be faced in the next year or two, but how far ahead are we planning?

We do not seem to be doing anything which recognises that governments, to be successful, must be able to work according to plans which have been laid down by far-sighted predecessors. For instance, we cannot say, as does the report, that, if we continue to take 120,000 migrants a year, in the year 2000 we will have 20 million people. None of us can give carte blanche for an intake of 120,000 migrants annually. We do not know what will happen in our region. The approximately 60,000 Indo-Chinese refugees that have been accepted by Australia in the last five or six years came to us as a result of the great political turmoil in that region. We cannot say that the same turmoil will not be experienced in other parts of our region and that we will not be expected to take the same number from different areas; or that other areas of the world will not be affected and Australia will be called upon to assist; or that there will not be political turmoil in the areas from which our traditional migrants come and that pressure will be brought to bear on us to take greater numbers of members of their families.

From time to time we will be confronted with all of these problems. But the infastructure of our method of accepting migrants and of how we are to deal with them when they arrive should not be planned from year to year. It should be laid down as a basis for looking after these people because Australia will remain a country of high migrant intake for a long time. It seems to be the general consensus that that is a good thing for Australia. Therefore, we should be able to plan a lot further ahead than we are at the moment.

Also to be considered is the whole question of the effect on the environment of having a population of 20 million. An enormous pressure is built up by virtue of everyone living in the major capitals. The great majority of our population lives in six or seven centres. We should be looking ahead at what it all means in terms of energy, water resources and trade. Everything that will be required by a nation of 20 million people ought to be part and parcel of a report of this nature.

The Minister has said that this is an enormously important report and that a great deal of discussion ensued last year after it was tabled in the Parliament. That is probably true. Academics from the various universities got hold of it and argued about it. Some supported it, some argued against it. Some are pro- migration; others are anti-migration. The one place where discussion is not taking place-as it should before it takes place anywhere else-is in the national parliament. The House will be going into recess on Thursday and will not be resuming until 16 August. By anybody's standards outside that is not a bad break . One would have thought that it would be a golden opportunity for any government to send a batch of parliamentarians to study some of the questions that I have raised in relation to this report, because these will be the important issues of the future. If we all sit around between now and 16 August worrying about who will get a tax cut it might help the people who are in work this year but it will not help the unemployed very much. It will not help the migrants who come here in the next year or two. There are probably other things that could be done which should receive priority.

These matters should be the subject of inquiry by standing committees of the Parliament. As I have said to the Minister on many occasions, Australia's migrant intake and attitude to the refugee problems which exist around the world ought to be the subject of an examination by a standing committee of this Parliament. Such a committee ought to be looking at these questions all the time so that when they come before the Parliament experts who have been working on the committees and who have visited the places, if necessary, can advise us in the positive way that congressional committees of the United States of America do. This would enable us to become experts on the subject. We would not be completely dependent upon bureaucrats coming back and telling us their views on what is happening outside Australia.

The one great failure of a report of this nature is that it comes to us in isolation; we are told only the bare figures. No one can argue with them because if the material being fed into the computer proves accurate over the next 20 years the conclusions will prove accurate. We need to know of the ramifications of embarking on a program which will lead Australia to having 20 million people in another 18 years. Jimmy Carter asked Congress and the people associated with Congress to prepare a report on the situation in the United States in the year 2000. That was done. Unfortunately, Ronald Reagan pushed it into the rubbish bin . This sort of exercise ought to be carried out in Australia. We may argue about the conclusions or the criteria that are used to reach those conclusions, but it would be a very worthy exercise.

We do not criticise Australia's migrant intake. We have reservations on some occasions about the way in which refugees are brought here in terms of where they are coming from. Perhaps other countries have been ignored because of the dictatorships that may be present in those countries. It seems to be of the utmost importance that we take it one step further. We should not talk just about numbers and the migrant intake; we should also talk about long term planning of the services that will be available and the way we will overcome the problems that will exist in another 20 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Committee's 198th report is the result of its investigation of the administration and management of the Government Aircraft Factories at Fishermens Bend and Avalon in Victoria. I should stress at the outset that while our investigations relate largely to GAF, we realise that much of what we say has relevance to all government factories. Many of the problems we identified-in particular, the problems for a commercially oriented organisation operating within a government framework-may be applicable to other areas of government commercial activity.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the early 1970s GAF has received repeated criticism from the Auditor- General with regard to its accounting, financial control and management procedures. The Auditor-General's unfavourable comments in his reports for 1979- 80 and previous years led the Committee to the conclusion that the problems being experienced at GAF, whilst serious breaches of Commonwealth accounting practice and procedure, were a symptom of more complex issues, including the management of the factories and their relationships with the mainstream departmental administration in Canberra.

Our investigation of GAF concentrated on three main areas: Firstly, issues raised by the Auditor-General; secondly, efficiency of the factories' management , including level of support received from the Department of Industry and Commerce in Canberra; and, thirdly, the future of the maintenance of production capability appropriation and the current and future viability of the aircraft industry, which was referred to in great detail in the 1976 report of the Industries Assistance Commission.

In our examination of the comments of the Auditor-General in relation to specific matters of accounting procedure and practice, we found a low standard of government accounting, resulting from years of neglect. Consequently, we endorse the comments of the Auditor-General when he said:
. . . collectively the unsatisfactory accounting disclosed by audit represented a critical state of affairs.

The Committee cannot excuse the neglect of the GAF in many basic accounting procedures and practices. Nor can it excuse the lack of action by the management at GAF to rectify these irregularities, particularly since many have been the subject of repeated comment by the Auditor-General over the last decade. The Committee is in no doubt that there has been a lack of commitment by senior management at GAF and within the Department of Industry and Commerce to the observations of the Auditor-General, and a regrettable tardiness in the control of existing systems and implementation of new systems to take account of the changing requirements of modern business practice.

Management staff at GAF have consistently proven over the last decade their inability to react to constructive criticism directed at encouraging remedial action, or even to rectify problems of this nature that they have identified. An example of this was Project Phoenix, a management review which cost the taxpayer $1m between 1973 and 1976 in consultants and equipment costs alone. It appears to have had little effect on managerial efficiencies. The Committee found that management of GAF had only a rudimentary knowledge of this review. As Project Phoenix was originally designed to be a continuous system of managerial review designed to produce savings of around $1m per annum, the Committee regards the handling of this project as quite unacceptable. We examined in some detail management deficiencies at the factories and found that in the areas of staffing , working conditions, remuneration, industrial relations and the adoption of modern business practices, GAF lagged far behind its competitors in private industry.

The Committee feels that the multitude of problems facing GAF is due to the lack of a co-ordinated and integrated approach by factory management over the last decade to its responsibilities and a lack of prompt action on factory issues by the Department in Canberra. The Public Accounts Committee believes that the major reason why GAF has been unable to develop adequate management and financial control systems is the extraordinarily long decision making process involving the General Manager of GAF, the Department of Industry and Commerce in Canberra and the various other departments such as Defence, Finance, Administrative Services, the Public Service Board and so on, all of which have an input into many areas of factory management. This process severely limits the General Manager's ability to respond in a timely and effective fashion to day to day management problems, and to develop modern management practice. The Committee strongly endorses the general proposition of letting the managers manage. The inflexibility and inefficiency caused by the present management approach should be eliminated.

A further area of concern to the Committee is the fluctuating work load in the aircraft industry as a result of the time lag between major defence re-equipment programs. Because of this, the industry suffers from problems of morale and retention of technological, research and manufacturing capability. The Committee is of the view that, if GAF is to function efficiently in a quasi-competitive environment, many of the problems caused by its formal attachment to the mainstream of Government departmental administration must be removed.

Possible options canvassed by the Committee included, first, that GAF and other Government factories be formed into separate independent statutory corporations with policy advice and co-ordination being provided through a new department of defence production, which would also be responsible for defence purchasing. The second option was that a tripartite aerospace corporation including the Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation, Hawker De Havilland and GAF, with the Commonwealth retaining a proportionate share of the equity, be established. The third option was for a separate company to include GAF with a majority shareholding vested in the Commonwealth.

The Committee concluded that the most acceptable solution would be the first, namely, to re-form GAF into a Statutory Corporation. This solution could also be applied to all other Government defence factories. Our conclusions and recommendations are directed towards placing GAF on a more efficient commercial footing. However, irrespective of the future of GF, the Committee recommends that financial reporting arrangements for GAF be rationalised, taking account of the many new developments in government accounting practice currently under consideration by the Government and the Public Accounts Committee. In this regard, the Committee will shortly table a report on the form and standards of financial statements of Commonwealth undertakings. This must include one set of accounts prepared and submitted to the production board as statements examined by the Auditor-General which are then presented to the Parliament as a record of the financial achievements of GAF.

However, the major point to emerge from the inquiry was, as I have already mentioned already, the inappropriate nature of a Government departmental framework for the efficient operation of commercial undertakings. It is essential to remove GAF from this framework and to place such undertakings on a similar footing to private industry, particularly regarding the decision-making process. It is also considered important to centralise the policy and co- ordination function for the operation of government factories into one separate department reporting directly to an appropriate Minister. I commend the report to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fifth Fraser health scheme is now seven months old. Its creator has already been consigned to the scrap-heap of history and his scheme is likely quickly to follow him. It has already had a damaging impact on a new inflationary spiral in this country. It is increasing social costs right across the community, particulary among the less well off, and is enveloped in bureaucratic confusion and ineptitude. Let me take each of those charges in turn .

SPEECH.PARA: The health changes of last year have given a significiant impetus to the renewed inflationary spiral in this country. The Government predicted that the health changes would lead to a 0.75 per cent increase in the consumer price index for 1981-82. As usual, it got its figures wrong. It was out by 90 per cent . The increase in the CPI attributable to health was 1.3 per cent in the December quarter and 0.1 per cent in the March quarter, a major impact on the renewed upward movement of inflation in this country. I quote the comments made by the economics editor of the Sydney Morning Herald, not just on the impact of the health changes on the CPI but also on the general ineptitude of this Government in health matters as related to finance. He states:

The startling rise in the Consumer Price Index during the December quarter-much of it caused by the latest round of Medibank changes-adds another chapter to the long and sorry story of the Fraser Government's health-care foul-up.
He went on to say:

The latest Medibank funding changes, announced last May, top off the record of perverse decisions. The message of the Medibank muddle . . . is that there has got to be a better way to balance the Budget.

It is not just simply a matter of the impact on the December quarter or the marginal impact on the March quarter. The impact of the health changes on inflation is not yet exhausted. The Commonwealth Government has simply lost control of hospital charges yet the growing difficulties of the States will press hospital charges ever skywards well in advance of the rate of inflation. Hospital charges in New South Wales have been raised to $96 a day-90 per cent above what they were in August last year. That is well above the rate of inflation. Impending increases to at least $100 a day are in the wings in Victoria and South Australia. That is 100 per cent above the charges prevailing last August. These new charges must inevitably flow into increased insurance contribution rates-in New South Wales the increases have already occurred-and further fuel inflation in the course of this year. We warned the Government last year, as did the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals, that for the Commonwealth to abdicate responsibility for hospitals, to divorce responsibility for hospital charges from responsibility for health insurance, would open the inflationary floodgates . The inflationary implications of the present scheme will simply prove intolerable, making nonsense of the Government's anti-inflation rhetoric.

Equally intolerable will be the impact of these hospital charges on health contribution rates for the ordinary Australian family. Private health funds contributions are simply a regressive tax paid not to government but to private agencies. Irrespective of their incomes, all Australian families but the very poor have to pay the same flat money rate tax to the private health funds for basic health insurance. As a result of the changes in 1981 that tax stood at an average of $10 per week per family across Australia. As a result of the further increases in New South Wales, the Medibank basic rate in that State is now $11. 86 a week. The increased charges already in the pipeline in Victoria and South Australia will mean that most families will be facing rates of $12 a week for basic health insurance by the end of 1982.

There will be no co-operation from working families in this country in the battle against inflation if the Government persists in undermining the social wage in this way. An editorial in the Australian Financial Review had this to say:

. . . the Government has effectively, in the latest of its series of unbelievably incompetent manoeuvres in the area of health finance, made sure that demands for cost of living adjustments will be louder than ever.

This Government is full of the rhetoric of the need for tough options, full of the rhetoric of self-sacrifice. But the toughness is always applied to poor and middling income earners. The self-sacrifices demanded are always of the less well off in this society.

Labor's health plan, by reversing many of the disastrous health decisions of 1981, will reverse the impact of health changes on the consumer price index. The nation can be confident that the changes outlined in Labor's health plan will reduce the CPI by between 1.8 per cent and 2 per cent. Moreover, by designing our plan around an income related levy so that people contribute according to their means, we ensure that the broader shoulders bear the heavier burdens. Not only is this fairer and more equitable, but also it gives a Labor Government much greater opportunities to secure the co-operation of working people in the economic struggles that lie ahead.

Of course, there have been rather pathetic efforts by the Government to impugn the costing of the Labor health scheme. Such efforts coming from this Government are simply derisory. It has never been able to get any of its health sums correct. Each of the four Fraser health schemes in the past four years were abandoned because the Government's sums were wrong. Either the impact on the CPI was grossly underestimated, as with the latest scheme, or the impact on the Commonwealth Budget was wildly out. The Government got its sums wrong and each of the previous four plans was abandoned. The same will happen to the fifth one because its calculations are incorrect. Nearly every estimate concerning the fifth Fraser health scheme--
