The whole process of stigmatisation of the disadvantaged is costing the taxpayer $3.18m. The Labor scheme will provide exactly the same cover for these people without the need for stigmatisation and certainly without these absurd bureaucratic costs.

Again, it has been revealed in the last week that the Government is now encouraging a massive advertising campaign by the private health funds with, of course, the Australian contributors' money, to clear up all the confusion over the health tax rebate. The private health funds are being advised in circulars from the Department of Health that they should have newspaper and television advertisements to explain to their clients the rather complicated health rebate; that there should be co-operative hot lines run by the various insurance agencies all, of course, at contributor's expense; and that there should be staff briefings and chemist briefings to explain this complex aspect of the scheme.

Not that the private funds, the great beneficiaries of the latest scheme, have contributed that much to its successful operation; indeed, the behaviour of some funds was clearly under attack in some of the changes that were made in a Bill brought into this House last week. In New South Wales, the Medical Benefits Fund of Australia Ltd, and to a lesser extent the Hospitals Contribution Fund of Australia, have been slowing down their payment of hospital claims. The delay is now close to two months in the case of the MBF. Of course, this has increased greatly the cash flow problems of the public hospitals. Again, the MBF is refusing to pay outpatient claims over the counter. This is part of a wider dispute over entitlements under the latest scheme, but it further exacerbates the hospital cash flow problem. Furthermore, the Department of Health has found it necessary to send to all the funds information regarding the entitlement of disadvantaged people who lose the health care card. Some funds are informing people who lose their entitlement to health care cards that they must serve the normal waiting period before becoming eligible for basic fund benefits. Of course, the Government has found it necessary, rightly so, to correct that misinformation being passed across counters by insurance companies.

Finally, I wish to refer to the social costs of this type of scheme. The Achilles heel of any voluntary scheme is that many people will remain uninsured and not be covered by the disadvantaged scheme. For instance, of those 600,000 people who inquired after health care cards only 170,000 were given them. It is likely that many of the 430,000 who did not get cards will not have taken out health insurance for the very good reason in many cases that they simply believe that they cannot afford the weekly rates of health insurance. It is all very well for the previous Minister to suggest that they give up their television sets-black and white or colour-and listen to radios so that they can afford health insurance. Many of these people have already given up what many of us would consider to be the basic necessities of life. Of course, health insurance for them is becoming a new cheap form of gambling. But it is a gamble which, according to statistics, they are likely to lose. The evidence is that low income people are more likely to fall ill or be injured through their work and home environments, that the uninsured are simply bad debts waiting to be hit by a truck or injured by a poorly guarded machine. There are recurring problems, then, of bad debts, and people will be increasingly dunned for medical and hospital debts. One of the distinctive signs of the new scheme is that throughout the country most of the public hospitals have in recent months entered into contractural relationships with debt collectors to tackle what is becoming a growing problem. The Government has a simple choice. It will either remake this health scheme or be told by the Australian people, quite clearly and unequivocally, that this health scheme will not be tolerated.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Petrie spoke of an increase in the cost to the community because people will have to pay for the professional treatment of an increased number of people in public hospitals. The honourable member did not equate those figures at all.

The honourable member asserted that Labor's figures are wrong and that the Government's figures are correct. Did he mean the Budget figures or the figures the Government brought forward afterwards to try to justify its arguments in criticising what we have said? He cannot have it both ways. Either the Budget figures are correct or they are not.

TALK.START.PARA: —These are correct, up to date figures.

—If they are not correct, one wonders what the effect is on the rest of the Budget. The honourable member interjected that these figures are corrected figures. I have pointed out that his assessments are wrong because they are based on wrong assumptions. I want to deal with some of these assumptions. You alluded to the fact that there was a massive increase in the cost of health care in this country associated with the introduction of Medibank. You were careful to say 'under the Labor Government'. You have not come out with the full story--
—Order! The honourable member should address the House through the Chair.

—The honourable member does not come out with the full story, which is that the cost increase which did occur when Labor first came to power was a continuation of what had been occurring for the previous three or four years. Towards the end of the 1960s people noticed that the cost of health care was beginning to go up precipitously. In 1973, in 1974 and at the end of the financial year 1974-75, when Labor was in government, costs were continuing to go up. That is perfectly true.
—Accelerated dramatically.

—Accelerating at the same rate as they had been doing before we even got into power and under a health scheme introduced by the Liberal Government in 1954. The Labor Government changed nothing about the health scheme until July 1975. Let us be honest about this. The Labor Party did not change anything until it introduced Medibank in July 1975. The rapid acceleration of the cost of health care services in this country was taking place under the voluntary health insurance system. I will tell the House why Medibank did not make a very significant change to that catastrophe.

SPEECH.PARA: Both Medibank and the voluntary health insurance system before it are in essence insurance guarantees for the payment of private fee-for-service medical fees. It is the same the world over. Wherever costs for health care are guaranteed on a fee-for-service basis with insurance backing, costs go up. As doctors discover that whatever services they provide, they will be paid for, they take advantage of the system. The proof of my argument is the fact that last week the Liberal Government introduced a Bill to try to clamp down on fraud and over-utilisation. In his speech the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) representing the Minister for Health was at least honest enough to attribute it to the medical benefits system. He did not blame it on Medibank because he knew that would be wrong. Surprisingly, he chose to be honest about it and I am thankful for that. The real cost problem relates to this system of a fee-for- service reward to doctors for whatever services they provide.

Another assumption that the honourable member for Petrie makes is that under our proposal there will be a loss of freedom of choice in that patients will not be able to choose their own doctor and to use private hospitals if they wish. Nothing in what we are proposing in any way stops a patient from going to a private hospital other than, one might say, the increasing costs which are now taking place under the Government's scheme, irrespective of our plans. It has already been said that the costs of hospital care have skyrocketed. Already the private benefits funds are signalling that they will need to increase their contribution rates. The fact is that, under the present Liberal Government scheme, costs are continuing to run away from the community.

Let us look at a bit of history once again. Medibank was introduced not because the Australian Labor Party consisted of a mob of geniuses who could derive something out of the air, but simply because we observed what was going on in the community and particularly what was discovered by the Nimmo committee of inquiry, which was set up in the late 1960s by a Liberal government, not a Labor government, to look into the increasing problems associated with the private voluntary health insurance system. We now have basically that self-same system once again. The problems that the Nimmo committee discovered were: The gross inefficiencies of the private health care system, the bureaucratic bungling associated with the administration of the whole complex arrangement and the claim that, as a result of it all, a lot of disadvantaged people in the community received no cover at all; they just gambled on the fact that they would not get sick. Of course, the chances were they, coming from the disadvantaged sections of the community, would lose out. The way they live, the lack of nutrition and so on, meant that they were more likely to get ill-and they then suffered. Consequently, the hospitals had the problem of chasing around and trying to collect bad debts. The hospitals have now started to make arrangements with fee collectors to chase up the poor who cannot pay their hospital bills. We are back to 1969 or 1970, when Mr Justice Nimmo presented his report. For the very reasons that he set out, we took the hint and made changes. He said he could not argue against the private voluntary health insurance system and all the multitude of 100 funds or something like that. He saw they were inefficient, that their conditions varied and that people could not make their way through the maze. He proposed a government department to overlook the whole damn lot of them and to make sure that people could be properly informed about what they were getting if they contributed to any particular scheme. He proposed government supervision. We took the next logical step and established a national health insurance system to do it all for everybody. Immediately the burden dropped from many people's shoulders, in terms of the contribution rate. People were required to pay a levy. People have to pay whichever system is in use. There is nothing voluntary now and there was nothing voluntary before we introduced Medibank because, if no one belonged to a benefit fund, one could not claim any tax rebate in respect of the money that one had paid for medical and hospital benefits. People had to belong to funds. The fact is that, by the introduction of a national health insurance scheme, the inequity is removed and the size of the contribution one makes depends on one's ability to pay, not on a flat rate which hits the poor much more than the rich, as is the case now under the Liberal scheme. The contribution is related, under the Labor Party's proposal, to one's capacity to pay. So the poor pay less and the rich pay more, which is social equity. Automatically everybody is covered. The disadvantaged do not have to try to find out what they are entitled to, be discouraged, afraid to inquire and put off. They know that they do not have to worry about it. They will get what they are entitled to, namely, the medical treatment their condition indicates they should get without worrying whether they can afford to pay for it. The condition for medical treatment should not be the depth of one's pocket: It should be the medical need which indicates the need of the individual .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harris Mr G.McD.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yet again the matter of the Government's new health scheme, as it has been described by the Opposition, has been proposed for discussion. Whenever the Opposition cannot think of a new matter for discussion as a matter of public importance, it brings on this issue. As the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges) has already remarked, this will be the fourth or the fifth time in the last year that this issue has been brought forward. One can just hear the Opposition Executive speaking to the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) and saying: 'Have another go. It won't do any good but we have nothing else to put up.' Once again we have to face a regurgitation of the subject of today's matter of public importance which has been put in various forms. On each occasion, it seeks to suggest that what we have devised is not as good as the Australian Labor Party efforts of the past. This time, the Opposition claims:

SPEECH.PARA: The inflationary impact, the social cost and the bureaucratic ineptitude of the latest Government health scheme.

In case any listener is misled by the Opposition's reference to the latest health scheme, it ought to be pointed out that the Opposition is referring to the scheme announced a little over a year ago and which, by now, is well accepted and understood by the Australian community at large with, it would appear, the exception of the Opposition.

The reality is that members of the Opposition wish to return to the failed policies of the years 1972 to 1975. It is Whitlam revisited. We all know that that policy simply did not work. The honourable member for Petrie has given a detailed dissection of the alleged and proposed scheme of the Opposition. It is worth reminding ourselves of that previous disaster. When this Government came into office, it inherited arrangements which had been made by the former Whitlam Government-as the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Dr Cass) said a few moments ago-characterised by rapidly accelerating health costs. At that time, there was no doubt that the open-ended 50-50 funding arrangement between the Commonwealth and the States simply did not work. It was characterised by a steady increase in costs of delivery of health services without an improvement in the quality of those services. The unsatisfactory experience led to the Government instigating the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals. The report of that inquiry left no doubt that the existing arrangements were totally unsatisfactory.

I think that, when our arrangements are being criticised and when they have been contrasted with what are said to be new arrangements proposed by the Opposition, it is worth reminding ourselves of what the Jamison Committee found and held to be the position under the former arrangements. The report in part states:

Information provided to the Commission shows a general over-supply of hospital beds in Australia, significant differences in total provision between States, maldistribution of beds within the States and a close relationship between the supply and use of hospital beds . . .
The States have been encouraged by the hospital cost-sharing agreements in particular to devote a large share of their health budgets to hospitals.

. . . the attitudes and efficiency of some hospital administrations has not been impressive. The Commission has evidence of ridiculous and unsubstantiated demands for additional staff, inefficient allocation of staff and rostering of overtime, and reluctance to introduce measures with proven cost savings such as contract cleaning. Other examples of wasteful practices include rosters deliberately organised to ensure that certain employees had a guaranteed overtime component in their wages, whether the hours needed to be worked or not, and arrangements for payment of salaries and allowances in excess of award provisions, sometimes with authorisation from the hospital's board but commonly without approval of the appropriate health authority. The Commission regards these as manifestations of poor managerial control and of a total lack of appreciation of the managerial function in publicly funded institutions.

. . . health authorities and hospital managements in general have not taken enough trouble to promote cost constraint-they must take more action; financial efficiency has taken second place to spending in many hospitals-this situation must be altered; the present system of funding encourages and promotes expenditure with little consideration of need-need must always be the main con- sideration; . . .

They are remarkably devastating findings and are completely damning of the situation before this Government instituted a year ago the arrangements now existing. It is amazing that somebody from the Opposition should complain about inflationary tendencies when there is such a damning finding of a total lack of cost control and cost constraint, because in the long run the amount that we have to pay in health insurance, in taxes or in Government contributions to health is solely dependent on the real cost of the delivery of health services. It was because of that experience that the arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States were altered to a system which required the hospitals and the States to have more regard to their costings. The States and the hospitals now have a clearer knowledge of the limit of the amount available to them and have to ensure cost control. The new system means that Australians have a health system which will be no less effective but far more cost efficient. It is interesting to note that even States such as New South Wales in recent times have taken decisions regarding hospitals. That shows that the message about cost constraint seems to be getting through.

At the same time, the health insurance system also required significant changes . There had been a steady withdrawal from the health insurance system of people who could pay and should have paid for health services. The national figure of those with health insurance had dropped to around 60 per cent, and in one State down to 55 per cent. This was clearly unsatisfactory. It was contrary to the principle of the user pays and more particularly to the concept that those who can pay should contribute to the cost of their health care. It meant that those who had the greatest demand-they were typically the older people-were paying more because as fewer people contributed to the health insurance funds the community rating slipped and those who contributed had to put in more than their share. This new scheme has resulted in a much higher proportion of wage and salary earners contributing to health insurance.

The success of the new scheme can truly be seen by the fact that many people have now taken out private insurance. The proportion of those who have moved to health insurance cover is over 70 per cent and, combined with those covered by the Commonwealth and in some instances the States, it is clear that very few are not now covered. I am informed that approximately 97 per cent of all Australians are covered either by private health insurance or by some form of government cover. It is worth repeating that this scheme is not one which leaves people to their own devices when they are unable to contribute. The situation is quite the reverse. Pensioners, the unemployed, the newly arrived and those on low incomes have their health costs met by this Government. Those on low incomes are covered under a scheme which is clearly defined and which has a generous test. A man with a wife and two children can be earning almost 70 per cent--

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, put a bit of zip into it. Don't you believe in it?

—The honourable member should just listen carefully. A man with a wife and two children can be earning approximately 70 per cent of average weekly earnings and still be covered by this Government. I was amazed to hear the honourable member for Bonython, I think it was, say that poor and middling income earners were not covered. I would have thought anyone earning 65 to 70 per cent of average weekly earnings would not be considered poor. Nonetheless, if they have two children they are still covered by these measures. If a person has not yet got himself covered but is without means, he will still have the opportunity 13 weeks after treatment to apply for cover. This means that inadvertent failure to seek cover will not disqualify him. Under these new funding arrangements, once the tax rebate is taken into account those who have taken out health insurance are in fact paying no more-indeed, it is sightly less -than they were prior to 1 September last year. The reality is that the present scheme much more fairly delivers health services to the Australian community and it does so in a way which ensures that costs are controlled and that the health delivery service is far more efficiently managed.

2. Follow the expressed wishes of the Aboriginal community when making such a decision.
3. Ensure that control over the College remains in the hands of the Aboriginal community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate that this debate be resumed today, 4 May. It is fitting also that I say a few words about the Battle of the Coral Sea, which we commemorate each year, and rightly so. This is the fortieth anniversary of that great battle, which took place between 4 May and 8 May 1942. It was, as many people will recall, the first action decided at sea in which the ships involved did not fire a shot. In view of the debate which surrounds some of the equipment that we are talking about today, that is an appropriate point. It was the first serious check to the Japanese advance upon Australia and, in the long term, it ensured the security of Australia during World War II. In the last few weeks we have seen commemorated in Australia the Battle of Tobruk-last Sunday; Anzac Day the week before; and on 24 April the Kapyong battle of the Korean War. They all serve to emphasise the vital importance of defence to this country. Some of the battles that I have mentioned were far away but the Coral Sea battle was close to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The prime responsibility of any government, in any country, must be to secure the nation's boarders, because without security we have nothing. Without secure borders all of the grand infrastructure that we have in this country would be meaningless. The Battle of the Coral Sea stopped a Japanese force that was assigned to take Port Moresby. Some 62 Japanese ships, 26 American and Australian ships and land-based aircraft took part in the engagement. The result was to some extent a tactical victory for the Japanese, but strategically they were forced to withdraw. It would not be right, when mentioning the Battle of the Coral Sea, to forget the debt that we owe to our American allies. It is one that we should acknowledge each year because it was they who stood by us in those very difficult days. To those who say that we should not stand by them when they need our assistance, I say that we will and we do. I pay tribute to all those who took part in that great battle of the Coral Sea.

To come closer to home and to take up the points of this defence debate, I say firstly that of all the members of this Parliament, past and present, the least fitted to criticise Australian defence policy are the members of the Australian Labor Party. In the years-fortunately few-that Labor was in office in this country, I was a regular serviceman. In the years 1973-1974 I commanded an infantry battalion in Townsville. I know only too well-probably better than anyone here-the disastrous effect that Labor's defence policies had on the Services and servicemen of Australia. I recall taking over a battalion when the Australian Labor Party had just marched out half of its strength by saying to the national servicemen: 'Go home boys, go home'. The Labor Government decimated the Services of this country by an irresponsible action, taken for short term political gain. I refer to its marching out half the strength of the units of the Australian Army. Yet the Opposition now claims that it has a responsible view on defence matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were all conscripts and you know it.

—Whether they were conscripts or not has nothing to do with the fact that they were manning units of the Australian Army. Yet the Labor Government said: 'Go home tomorrow; don't wait until we can phase this out; don't worry about the units you are manning; just go home'. They marched out in droves. That action decimated units overnight. Of all the actions that I can think of during those years when Labor was in charge of the country, that would have been the most irresponsible.
—Liberty is something we shouldn't tolerate. That is what you are saying.

—I do not understand what liberty has to do with this. We are talking about the defence of liberty. We then engaged in a constant battle to re-form units. Having done that, we went through a constant battle to try to train them, to get them out of camp. In those days the defence policy of the ALP could be expressed in these terms: 'Keep everyone in camp. That will not cost much. Give them no training. They will cause no problem in camp. That is the best defence policy. We will just pull everyone back to Australia, put our heads in the sand and that will be the end of it.' I do not believe that the ALP was deliberately trying to disrupt or run down the Services, but its actions had that result because it did not understand how servicemen thought. It still does not. Labor believes that it is just a matter of having equipment and of keeping soldiers in uniform. It has no understanding of the mentality and make-up of servicemen.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1975, the former Labor Government having decimated the Services of this country, this Government has reversed the trend. It has increased the strength of the Services by about 4,500 and, in percentage terms, capital equipment expenditure has increased. I can well remember the ALP concept of continental defence, which involved sitting at home and doing nothing. No one really knew what that statement meant. In 1974 I thought I would test it. I decided that we would run an exercise in the Gulf country. I then set about planning it, but no support was provided. I was told: 'No, you cannot go and exercise. What do you think this is? What are you training for?'. We were virtually kept at home. However, I was determined to get there and was prepared to walk, if necessary. Eventually, common sense came to the rescue and we got some support equipment and a few trucks and aircraft with which to run that exercise. Do not talk to me about ALP defence preparedness and policies. Labor has nothing to be proud of and is certainly in no position to criticise.

I turn now to one of the major points of the defence debate-the purchase of the HMS Invincible. There can be no doubt that it is a controversial purchase. I freely admit to having some doubts about it. But I think it is well to remember, as I have mentioned, the role that the carriers played in the Battle of the Coral Sea. It is even more pertinent to remember what is happening in the Falkland Islands. I ask how such an operation could possibly be carried out without a carrier such as Invincible taking part as indeed it is. I have some criticisms of the purchase, as do many others. One is that there are no present plans to provide fixed wing aircraft for the carrier. The Government has said that it has no such plans at the moment. I sincerely urge it to consider, as soon as possible, acquiring those aircraft-even if only a few of the existing generation-so that expertise can continue to be sustained while we are waiting for next generation aircraft to be purchased.

One aspect that I believe has not been properly articulated is that the purchase of the Invincible probably does not make much sense in the context of continental defence, as members of the ALP understand it-to pull out from everywhere and sit at home. But if we look upon it as part of the equipment required by the defence policies of the 1980s, which Australia should be pursuing, the purchase of the Invincible makes a great deal of sense. I refer to the development of forces which can work in a regional context, which can work with our allies, which could be prepared-in the Pacific Islands, in New Guinea and in some of our own dependencies and off-shore installations-to take their place as part of our defence posture.

We are moving into an era of regional defence. This is not before time. It seems to me that the carrier is essential in this context. We have seen the folly in past years of not being properly prepared. We have seen the folly of holding and claiming ground when not only have we not been prepared to defend it but also we have not had the kit with which to defend it. I think it is fair to say that although the British Government has no alternative but to do what it is doing now in attempting to throw the Argentines out of the Falkland Islands, in hindsight it will be seen that these dependencies around the world cannot be held any longer by leaving 40 marines there and hoping for the best. Sooner or later someone will come along and threaten our dependencies or some of our allies. In that context it seems to me to be absolutely essential that HMS Invincible becomes part of the Australian defence scene. We should also move to acquire those extra helicopters and fixed wing aircraft as soon as possible.

Australian defence should not be a subject of fierce political debate. We hope to move towards some sort of political consensus. We cannot afford to be less than strong in this area. We need to be strong enough to deter any potential aggressors. What has happened in the Falklands and throughout history indicates that a threat can come very quickly from a direction which is completely unexpected. I recognise that some of the points that have been made previously in this debate-no doubt they will be made again by the Opposition-are valid, but I certainly do not regard them as being in any position to legitimately criticise this Government for the efforts which it has made in defence since it picked up that cross in 1975. I can well remember what it was like in the years between 1972 and 1975. I end this speech simply by urging that, when the Invincible comes to these shores, it be fully equipped so that we can take our place, as we should be doing, in the regional defence of this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday in this Parliament the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) bluntly declared that the Government's defence policy was tattered and in disarray. He confessed that, so far as the nation's defence capability was concerned, Australia stood naked and disabled. He outlined how flyers would not be allowed to fly, sailors would be kept on-shore and soldiers would be effectively reduced to polishing broomsticks . It was not a major statement on the national defence of the country but a national disgrace. We had from the Minister characteristic table thumping and hell raising rhetoric on the threat of the Soviet Union. We heard hard adjectives and hard nouns about military reach, strategic lodgments, footholds, world domination and awesome power. We were even warned of the seeping presence of the Soviet Union in our own region.

SPEECH.PARA: The obvious question, as one listened attentively to the Minister's speech, was : What sorts of policies does the Government have in hand to counter this awesome sinister Soviet threat? We discovered a few pages later that the defence capability of the nation was to be gutted. That is the official policy of the Government. It has terminated the purchase of not five but 10 Fremantle class patrol boats. Just after the invasion of Afghanistan by Russia a statement was made that 10 extra Fremantle class patrol boats would be acquired. That number was reduced to five. That latter five represents the five whose purchase is now being terminated. So when in the wake of the Afghanistan invasion it was established in the Government's mind that it was absolutely essential to have 10 extra patrol boats, we now find that none of them were necessary. But nothing has changed. The Russians are still in Afghanistan, Afghanistan is safely forgotten and the 1980 election is in the past.

We discover that the destroyer follow-on program is permanently stalled. The acquisition of anti-submarine warfare helicopters is to be deferred; others are to be cut. I find myself nonplussed by this because now we find that exclusively the justification for the extraordinary expensive purchase of HMS Invincible is its anti-submarine warfare role. It was a cruel mockery of the Minister in his concluding comments to declare:
I have spoken today of the prospects for the nation's continued security.

The facts are that the defence capability of this country has now been effectively paralysed by the policies of the Fraser Government. The Minister for Defence is only one of the members of that Government. The centrepiece of the Government's defence program is the acquisition of a half billion dollar-that is , $500m-aircraft carrier which will carry between four and five helicopters. That represents a $100m parking spot for each of the anti-submarine warfare helicopters on this aircraft carrier which has a capability of carrying 16. The cost of that is that there will be no helicopters for the four FFG frigates. We will lose eight helicopters. Therefore, we will be down at sea by between three and four helicopters. The FFGs will, in the same circumstances, be extraordinarily vulnerable. Their harpoons have a range of 60 miles. Their radar system has a range of 20 miles. As a matter of simple arithmetic, it is clear that without the over-the-horizon radar capacity provided by the helicopters, the FFGs will be operating with only one-third vision. They are, I repeat, highly vulnerable. These are the sort of cockeyed priorities which the Government has.

The whole cost of this is further extended. There will be no fixed wing naval air power cover for the Invincible. If anything has been established by the role of this type of aircraft carrier, it is the absolute necessity-if a decision is to be made to buy this sort of equipment-to have fixed wing air power cover to protect, as an umbrella, the aircraft carrier, to protect the helicopters that operate from it and to protect the flotilla that operates in conjunction with the carrier. Not only will there be no fixed wing naval air power for the carrier, but also there will be no fixed wing naval air power of any sort. Admiral Synnot has declared that without that fixed wing naval air power the effectiveness of the carrier is demolished.

The Minister went on, after all this rhetoric of the threat which surrounds us internationally and in our own region, and comfortably confessed a wind-down in our resources, our capability, as our defence response. He then went on, equally comfortably, to talk about our commitment to regional defence co-operation. On the next page of his statement he admitted that the armed forces would be embalmed-that is, flying, sailing and training time would be slashed. Equipment repairs will be cut back. That is not a reassuring defence statement at all. It is a pathetic 'tour de farce'. It is the performance of an easy going paladin. On his record he has first claim to become master of HMAS Spurious.

What does this mean? It means not just paralysis this year but worsening paralysis in the years ahead. The payments for the Invincible and the P3Cs for this coming year are relatively moderate. There will be far larger payments made in the succeeding years. The Minister argues that the wages bill suddenly exploded. Well, the Government deserves to get caught on that. In the Budget the Department of the Treasury declared that there would be a 13 per cent average increase in wages for the community. In fudging the figures the Department of Defence declared that the average increase would be only 6 per cent for the armed Services. There would be a pay increase of 6 per cent for the armed Services when the rest of the community would receive an increase of about 13 per cent. This was at a time when there were flow-on arrangements and when an inquiry was about to report, as the Government well knew, on wages and conditions of the defence forces.

I come to what I regard as the real heart of this matter. It is not so much the equipment aspect, which is serious enough; it is what the deferrals, the displacements and the terminations really reflect. The facts are that those things reflect that the defence of this country is confronted by an equipment cost crisis. It gets worse year by year throughout the current five-year defence plan. By the way in which it will develop, I expect the Minister will be glad if he can move out of his task. It is only two years since the declaration by himself and by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) of the necessity for increased steaming time, increased flying time, increased training and so on. It is only two years since the Russian incursion into Afghanistan. Nothing has changed in that respect. Nothing has changed in the Indian Ocean area, in the troubled Gulf, down through North Yemen, into Mozambique or in any of the other areas which the Government declared itself to be concerned about. The Government now finds, with an election safely behind it and with Afghanistan almost forgotten from its memory, that it can put the whole system in reverse.

The Government is facing a cash chaos situation. The Prime Minister rightly declared in his weekend broadcast that there are commitments for equipment in excess of $6,000m. How will that be paid for? On all of the estimates I have been able to make it will not be possible for the Government, on its present programming, to pay for that sort of obligation. Over the next seven years it will have to establish an average of 16 per cent of the defence budget for equipment purchases to be able to meet that amount. But that is based on the assumption that there will be no new equipment and that the Government can neglect some very large and expensive items of equipment that have to be paid for within two to three years. This will, therefore, generate dreadful difficulties. It is also based on ignoring the fact that inflation has not been accounted for. Much of the costing input of that total figure of $6,000m was derived in earlier years. If an inflationary factor were allowed for, at least $ 1,000m more would be added to that figure in current day terms.

The $6,000m covers only major programs. In Appropriation Bill (No. 1) there is another section of the budget for defence which is described as 'Other equipment '. That covers 40 per cent of the total equipment outlays and represents another $4,000m. With $6,000m and $4,000m, $10,000m is the total commitment for equipment that the Government has itself locked into through the curious and confusing way in which it makes decisions on defence expenditure. With some more simple arithmetic, if we allow for inflation the figure really comes to between $11,500m and $12,000m. How will the Government pay for that? Will it run raffles , introduce work sharing into the armed services or resort to its traditional fall-back policy of crossing its fingers and hoping that somehow it will come out okay in the end. I am talking about a real equipment expenditure commitment of $11,500m to $12,000m currently, without allowing for new items which inevitable will have to be committed.

There are a number of reasons for this situation but one matter I want to focus on is the implication of this for our balance of payments. Time and again I warned that inevitably the Government would get itself into serious trouble because it was not programming sensibly its defence expenditure programs. When it did make commitments, it did not stick consistently with them, apart from buying the wrong sort of equipment for this country. I have mentioned the total figure of about $12,000m for which the Government has committed itself for new equipment at this point. From experience, about 70 per cent of the equipment purchases come from overseas, so we are talking at this point about more than $8 ,000m being committed or inevitably to be committed for defence purchases from overseas. For the next seven years that will take on average each year an outflow of cash from this country in excess of $1,000m to pay for defence equipment. Currently service debts-that is, the payments on earlier foreign investment and the flow of capital out of this country for that purpose-are in excess of $2,800m. Does anyone genuinely believe that the economy of this country is now in a condition to be able to take that sort of strain or is likely to be able to do so in the foreseeable future? TALK.START.PARA: —In those circumstances we can understand why the country is getting into trouble and why the economy cannot take the strain of spending on defence equipment. Too many items are being deferred and they are banking up to the point where there is a very large accumulation of cost which, frankly, represents a critical situation and will be beyond the capacity of the economy to bear. I want to ask questions of this Government, particularly of the Prime Minister who, fundamentally, is responsible for this mess today. I ask whether we are prepared for the defence of this nation. Where are the Macchi replacements, the Caribou follow-on, the stand-off weapons for the F111Cs, the air-to-air refuelling, the FFG helicopters and a range of other items which were declared in the 1976 White Paper as essential-items which it was declared almost exclusively would have been acquired by this time? SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to have the opportunity to follow the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and deny totally the whole thrust of the nonsense that he has just spread in this chamber and to the Australian people. To allege, as he and his party have done, that the defence capability of this nation is to be gutted and that projects which are being deferred are being terminated, is to demonstrate a lack of responsibility to the servicemen of this country and a lack of responsibility in his task as Leader of the Opposition. It is incredible that this man, knowing full well that the amount of money to be spent on defence this year will rise by about 20 per cent in the current Budget, has nonetheless come into this House and presented this false appearance of concern about non-existent cuts. There are no defence cuts; there are deferrals. Decisions have been made to bring forward existing commitments and commitments that were not due for implementation for some years. In exchange other commitments are to be deferred.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party has never been able to understand defence. We can see from its own achievement its genuine concern about defence! We hear great protest from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison). We hear that it is a disgrace that equipment purchases should make up only 13.1 per cent-I think that was the alleged figure- of the total defence vote. TALK.START.PARA: —More shonky figures.

—Not necessarily.

—There is a genius on the opposite side who can increase the percentage going to one side without decreasing the percentage going to the other side. No doubt when he is Treasurer, the defence forces will feel the benefit of his wit just as they felt the benefit of Labor's great concern for the Services when it decimated the defence forces within the three Budgets in the financial years 1973-74, 1974-75 and 1975-76.

SPEECH.PARA: In the seven years that this Government has been in power, every decision taken by the Government on defence has been criticised by the Labor Party. It is incredible, is it not, what politics will prompt people to do without any real concern or any real recognition of the need for morale or the reality of defence within the Australian environment. We have, for example, all these allegations now being made about how the Invincible is inappropriate and how it should not have been purchased when, in fact, on 9 September 1980 a decision was announced to this House that the Government proposed to replace HMAS Melbourne with a purpose-designed ship to be equipped with helicopters for anti-submarine warfare but with a potential also for operating short take-off and vertical landing aircraft. That decision was taken then. This House and the nation knew then that there would be a commitment to purchase this ship some time in the mid-1980s. I stress this to the House and to the nation to dramatise the point that what has happened is that this purchase has been brought forward.

The result of bringing it forward-Australia will get the ship much more cheaply , by the way-has been that other defence purchases have been deferred. The purchase of the 10 Orions, which are absolutely vital if there is to be any anti -submarine capacity around Australia has been brought forward. That purchase is absolutely vital. The bringing forward of these purchases is an opportunity that we must take but that action is being attacked by the Opposition, no matter what the consequences are of not bringing them forward.

What are the consequences of not bringing forward these purchases? That is what we would like to hear the Opposition discussing. The consequences are that we would not be able to purchase the Orions in this production run and, if we got them at a later stage, they would be extremely expensive.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not matter.

—The expenditure of a mere $280m does not matter, according to the Opposition. It is only $280m.
