SPEECH.PARA: It is self-evident that the allegations of cuts, the allegations that the defence capability of the nation is to be gutted, are arrant and disgraceful nonsense and are allegations which are aimed at causing disaffection and concern among the armed forces of this nation, and are having an impact on morale. There is no doubt that these deceptive and nonsensical allegations are having an impact on morale. There is no doubt that any fair, honest, person, who examines what is actually happening within the context of this 20 per cent increase in spending, will understand that there is simply a changing of priorities.

The Opposition can say that it does not agree with the priorities. Honourable members and people in the nation have the right to disagree with the priorities. They can say that they would rather, for example, have the present purchase of any of the items that have been deferred than those which we are getting. If that is the line they will adopt, let them argue it coherently. Let them not come into this House and deceive the people by claiming that there has been a gutting of our defence capabilities. What is happening is that the purchase of vital major and key items of equipment for our defence capability has been brought forward, thus delaying the purchase of various other items of equipment. Let it be clear that it is nothing more than that.

In the disgraceful contributions that have been made to this debate so far, we have not heard from anyone opposite any acceptance of the fact that there has been provision for a 20 per cent increase in defence spending this year. That is an 8 per cent real rise after we take inflation into account. Has the Labor Party ever achieved such a rise in defence spending in its period in office? What it did was to bring about a decrease in the proportion of budget spending going to defence to the lowest level. That is the position based on the figures available to the Parliamentary Library. Labor reduced Australia's defence effort to the lowest proportion of budget spending on record. Yet the Opposition alleges in this House that it is the protector of the defence forces of this nation. It is absolutely incredible. We see this kind of deceptive nonsense from the honourable member for St George who is reported at page 2080 of Hansard as saying:
The Fleet Air Arm is gone and all we will have is a helicopter aircraft carrier without any helicopters.

A former Minister for Defence comes in and spreads that nonsense. I wonder whether he has heard of the six Sea Kings and the two more on order which will be available to go on the In- vincible when she arrives? I wonder why he would seek to deceive this House by saying this kind of nonsense? Those helicopters naturally are to be equipped-I am glad to see that the honourable member for St George has now entered the House-with sonar dunking devices which make them a very potent weapon against the threat of submarines.

Members of this House will note that rather than there being no sense of coherence about the Government's defence strategy, we have by bringing forward the purchase of the Orions and the purchase of this carrier, which was originally called a through-deck cruiser-that may in fact describe it more accurately-aimed clearly at providing an anti-submarine warfare capability and that surely is of primary importance to an island continent. The combination of those Orions and the anti-submarine warfare helicopters is, of course, obviously a vital part of a coherent defence policy which this Opposition is unable to understand. The Opposition wants to spend its money on more and more submarines. It obviously takes a much more aggressive approach to defence than does the present Government.

Let us examine the allegation made by the Leader of the Opposition-once again falsely, and I stress that-that the FFGs would not be equipped with helicopters. The allegations against this Government's defence policy are false. There is an increase in terms of equipment becoming available. Let us have a look at the fact that 18 light helicopters, the purchase of which was approved in 1980-81 and the contract for which is expected to be let in mid-1982, are planned to be used for training on the FFGs.

TALK.START.PARA: —When?

—By mid-1982. They will not be anti-submarine warfare helicopters, nor is it accurate to refer to the Royal Australian Navy's FFGs as ASW frigates. The fact is that there is a capacity for these light helicopters to be attached to and to provide a degree of training for the FFGs. To hear the Leader of the Opposition allege that there will be no helicopters with over-the-horizon radar is to suggest that the only helicopter that has that capacity is in fact an anti -submarine warfare helicopter. I suggest that the training that can be gained on the FFGs by having light helicopters-I concede the point that they are not as warlike in terms of reality as an ASW helicopter-is nonetheless particularly meaningful. It may well be that the Navy, after evaluation, could decide not to put ASW helicopters on the back of these FFGs. Having made the decision that ASW helicopters are to go on the Invincible, the need for putting ASW-style helicopters on the back of FFGs will be significantly diminished. As I understand it, the priority of that kind of helicopter is very low now that decision has been made to purchase the Invincible.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to this House and to the nation that any attempts by the Opposition to denigrate the Government's increased spending, its purchase of very important equipment and its bringing forward of these purchases and any attempts to suggest that this is a gutting of our defence capacity and to pretend that the 20 per cent rise in spending is a fall, are simply dishonest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) which I seconded. First I want to make just two points about the speeches made by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) and the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) and then ignore them entirely as they deserve to be. The first is that it was not until 1980 that the expenditure of this Government on the defence program exceeded as a percentage of gross domestic product what it was during the period of the Whitlam Government. The second point I want to make-and this concerns the question of bipartisanship-is that in terms of the aggregates of defence expenditure, including each point of time when the Government has said it wishes to increase defence expenditure, the Opposition has said that it will support the aggregate increase. We have said that in circumstances in which Australian economic conditions have been extraordinarily difficult and when it might have been expected that the Opposition would give priority to housing, education or social welfare. Instead, the Opposition has accepted the need for increased defence expenditure. But we have reserved the right, on precisely the problems that are being raised here today-the questions of the priority of that expenditure-to offer critical comment, and that has been done most effectively by the Leader of the Opposition and by the Opposition spokesman on defence, the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes).

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is deserving of condemnation because it has added incompetence on planning and confusion in strategic priorities to deceit in public presentation of defence policy. It has no conception of the relationship between strategy and doctrine and force structure and the relationship between force structure and a five-year rolling procurement program. As a result, it had permitted items to be brought forward, then deferred, brought forward again, and deferred again with consequent gluts and bottlenecks in equipment expenditure and expenditure on capital infrastructure. It has compounded the disastrous consequences of this process by dropping in an item such as the Invincible with no understanding of the impact that has down the line where Defence officials try to maintain some relationship between procurement and strategy for the defence of Australia. Thus, we have a situation in which the purchase of the Invincible requires deferral of the purchase of its escorts, of associated anti- submarine warfare helicopters, of fixed-wing naval air power, of installations required for its effective deployment and of aids to land-based air cover. Ironically, the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) himself recognised the inadvisability of his own current behaviour when in his Afghan crisis defence statement of 25 March 1980 he said:

We do not judge it necessary at this time to make sweeping changes to the whole force structure planned for later in the decade. On the whole, there is not yet a case for the large additional emphasis upon equipment numbers that would commend measures such as off-the-shelf purchases, or other short cuts with attendant cost and other penalties in terms of suitability for the Australian environment.
We could not have put forward a better criticism of the Invincible purchase ourselves.

Where is the change in our current strategic environment to justify this? As alarmist as the Minister was, he was nowhere near as alarmist as he was two years ago. Indeed, it must be said that those of us on this side of the House who are members of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence are grateful to the Minister for his kind references to the report of the Committee and for his statement that he accepted the Committee's assement that in looking at our strategic environment we should be 'cautionsly optimistic '. I feel sorry, however, for those in the Department of Defence associated with the preparation of the Minister's speech. I would bet good money that they carefully worked their way through the Committee's report, looked closely at the strategic and doctrinal aspects of defence self-reliance and drummed up some document which did not indulge in the sort of hyperbole the Minister has indulged in about threatening environments, recognising that the measures he was announcing were wholly inappropriate to such alarmism. His advisers have had some frustrating months trying to hold this Government on course-a course which we supported when it was announced in the 1976 defence White Paper. Defence self -reliance has gone out the window. We have a bowdlerised form of the old forward defence with no place to be forward in.

Now the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has complained about allegations that he has cut expenditure. This is despite that fact-as the honourable member for Corio clearly pointed out-that his Government has never spent its entire defence appropriation in the period in which it has been in office. This year it will be about 84 per cent. If he feels that he is unjustly dealt with, he has been hoist with his own petard. Repeatedly this Government has presented dramatic statements to this House announcing dramatic new programs, which are in fact years down the pipeline, as though they could be implemented the next day. Nowhere has this tactic been more deceitfully used than at election time in my home State of Western Australia.

Consider the case of HMAS Stirling. Shortly prior to the 1977 State election, the Minister announced in a Press release that from early 1979 the Royal Australian Navy would be permanently based in Stirling-that two destroyers and two submarines would be deployed joining the two survey ships and a patrol boat. Then in September 1977, before the Federal election, as reported in Hansard for 22 September, the Minister announced that seven naval units would be deployed from there in 1980. By June 1980 this had been put back to 1985, and then last year to 1986. The Minister is silent on the matter in this statement, but he refers to cuts in facilities programs; so we may well anticipate that home porting will be put back further. I have absolute confidence, however, that HMAS Stirling will be back there on the agenda for the next election, and despite cutbacks in the follow-on destroyer program, we shall be told of an intention to utilise the base to its maximum.

The Derby airfield is another case in point. With mighty fanfare, in early 1980 we were told of an intended expenditure of $47m on upgrading it, so that Western Australian voters in the 1980 poll could feel secure. We find to date that only $190,000 has been expended on the base and that the Government will put back completion of it from four years to six years from this date. The Prime Minister ought not to be surprised when people talk of cuts when so much is promised in such a false atmosphere. We on this side of the House have often pointed out that those promises are incapable of fulfilment. For the reasons mentioned by the honourable member for Macarthur, these are expenditures which take place over a lengthy period. But that is not the impression that his party conveyed to the electorate. When we say those sorts of things to the electorate, we are accused of backsliding.

The cuts in the other part of the program, of equipment purchases-to answer the honourable member for Macarthur again-are greater than the expenditure on the Invincible. The Government has no clear understanding of its strategic priorities. This is at the heart of its failure to perform. This is what permitted it to get off track with the Invincible and to suppress some real priorities. I refer honourable members to the Australian of 29 March and to an article by William Pinwill, in which he quotes from a document on strategic priorities endorsed by the Chief of the Defence Force Staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not true.

—I cannot verify the accuracy of the document that Mr Pinwill mentions. Suffice it to say that its accuracy has not been officially denied and it conforms to every assessment of priority that I have heard as a member of the Defence Sub-committee of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence when in public session defence spokesman have appeared before us. In that list of priorities, about which the honourable member for Macarthur is so keen, we find the sorts of priorities which would justify the purchase of the Invincible at the bottom. At the head of the list, in areas which are being very deeply cut in this defence statement, are:

SPEECH.PARA: Intelligence collection and surveillance of areas of approach to our northern regions.
A strike capacity as a deterring influence and for strategic operations.

A capacity to combat air and seaborne operations launched against widely dispersed targets in northern Australia. Air defence of Australian forces, military and civilian facilities, population, industrial and administrative centres, particularly in the north, against air threat.
Initial and simultaneous defence by ground forces of a wide range of geographically dispersed civil and military facilities and population centres against airborne or limited seaborne assault.

These defence cuts hit hardest in those areas which are assigned the highest priority, in the north and the west. Let us look at them. The Government has announced a cutback in the purchase of additional patrol boats. Not only shall we not get the 10 extra promised in 1980, but also we shall not proceed with the five of the 10 already scheduled, and the suggestions of a patrol boat base in Western Australia's north-west has disappeared like snow in spring, despite its presence in the 1976 defence White Paper, in promises at subsequent elections in 1977 and 1980, and in the form of a budget for site acquisition in the 1980-81 defence budget-an amount that was not spent. Expenditure on the follow-on destroyers will be reduced. Anyone can see that additional ships are required and are necessary if home porting commitments at HMAS Stirling are to be achieved. They cannot be achieved from within the current force structure.

I have already mentioned delays in construction at Derby. The Minister, however , mentions cuts in other areas of the capital infrastructure program. We are therefore left to assume that, as much activity has been promised in this area, at Stirling, Pearce, Learmonth and Derby over the next few years, if cuts in installations are to take place, cuts will be taking place in planned expenditure in these areas. If I am not right about that, I shall be very pleased to hear the Minister in response, and in response to questions that I have placed on the Notice Paper about the matter. But there has been no indication to date that I am wrong.

The Government has deferred a second underway supply ship. It has justified having a second supply ship in the past as giving the Navy a 'two ocean capacity ' for long distance deployments in two oceans-in other words, an equalising of the Navy's activities in the Indian Ocean and the Pacific Ocean. Clearly, this decision will diminish or put back the chances of a permanent long distance deployment capacity from the Western Australian coast. The defence of our northern and north-western approaches will also be diminished by a reduction in training activities, flying, steaming time, storage and repair facilities.
When he made his statement in March 1980, the Minister said:

Of fundamental importance to our military operations and defence preparedness is an improved availability of resources for such things as spare parts, maintenance and equipment repair, flying hours, steaming time, ammunition holdings and other stores, and higher states of training of skilled manpower. In these respects also we aim to broaden the expansion base and reduce the lead- time for movement to a higher state of operational readiness-

It is precisely these areas in which there has been announced a reduction of activities. In Western Australia, which is at the nether end of the training capabilities and deployment capabilities of the Navy and Air Force in particular and, therefore, at the most expensive end of exercises and deployments, we must expect-unless we are to be advised to the contrary-that deployment in our area will suffer the most.

I turn to the point I made earlier. It is not as though the Invincible were not useful. I would agree that if we wished to defend the Falkland Islands, the Invincible would be extremely useful. I would agree that if it were our intention in the near future to invade Fiji, the Invincible would be useful, and far more useful than the submarines, or whatever, to which the Australian Labor Party would prefer to assign priority. I would agree with all of that. But that is not the advice of the Government's defence advisers. That is not a sensible definition of priority in defence planning. All those items which have been cut back as a result of this purchase being brought forward lie at the very heart of defence self-reliance, at the very heart of solemn commitments and undertakings given to the Australian electorate by this Government which have been thoroughly supported by the Australian Labor Party right down the line.

As I have said, we have never opposed an aggregate increase in expenditure. We have retained the right to criticise the priorities. In the light of our experience, in this statement made last week and in the presentations of honourable members on the Government side, it is just as well, for the sake of the defence of this country, that the Australian Labor Party has not agreed to a bipartisan approach on that particular question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) open up in his characteristic manner, crouched over the podium on which he keeps his notes, with one hand pressed to his heart and with some rolling phrases coming from his tongue, such as strategic priority, setting the force structure right, et cetera, one could have been forgiven for thinking that he would actually address himself to some questions of strategic priorities and give his own grand design about Australia's defence. But unfortunately for the House and the people of this country, this was not to be. What we got was a shopping list of complaints about alleged cuts and deferments, plus of course a list of local complaints about the way in which the Government's decision on defence would affect the good people of Swan and the good people of Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Since it was his intention, as I thought, to try to put some perspective into his remarks, let me seek to do so by mentioning four subjects which, I think, are of interest to us all. First of all, the objectives of Australian defence; secondly, the limitations that government defence planners face; thirdly, the present state of priorities and preparedness; and, fourthly, the future.

It is perfectly plain that the first aim of our defence policy should be to deter attack by any save a major power because that after all is the whole purpose of having a defence force; not to use it to attack but that it should deter an attack upon us. Secondly, in the event that the primary purpose fails, our aim should be to repel, irrespective of the level of attack, from, once again, any save a major power, be it a low level attack or a major attempt to attack the continent itself. Thirdly, our aim should be to act in concert with our allies-that the Australian Labor Party sometimes forgets, or praises and at the same time condemns-such as the United States and the United Kingdom, although it is far less present here than it used to be, and New Zealand.

Let us look at the limitations and obstacles that face governments and government decision makers when deciding on priorities, and procurements. The first limitation is the fact that the objectives that we have to meet, that is the possible situations that we have to meet, put a variety of options before us . We may, for example, have to meet a low level of attack. On the other hand, we may have to meet an attack on the continent at some part of the coastline which is a long distance from major centres of communications.

The second limitation is that the spread of possibilities and the absence of a presently perceived threat to this country complicate matters. If a country is a land-locked European country it is a very much simpler thing to order one's defence priorities. One knows who is on one's borders and it is easier to make one's calculations. Here in this part of the world that we inhabit, without any perceived threat but with no assurance that the situation will continue, it is not as easy to order one's priorities because the options are greater. The third limitation is that we have the problems posed by our geography. We have a huge coastline with the concentration of population and material resources on the peripheries of this country. Lastly, there are the limitations inherent in any democracy, that is how it allocates funds between different domestic priorities such as how much it spends on social welfare, how much it spends on education, and how much it spends on defence. We have heard a lot of criticism from speakers on the Opposition side about the level of Government spending. We have not heard it suggested that the Opposition would increase spending or would match the present levels of Government spending. As well, one of the limitations we all face is the tendency, perhaps in this country and in other democracies in times of peace, to rely on others.

What are the consequences of these limitations? First of all, one can never be certain that one's force structure is right. The only way to prove it is when it has to be used and that of course is precisely what one always wants to avoid. Secondly, because of the difficulties that we face in having a variety of options, the different scenarios that this country might face in an unstable part of the world, we have to be even more cautious, more careful in our procurement decisions and in decisions affecting the force structure than other countries, other democracies, which are just as concerned as we are to defend themselves. If we are wrong and if we are tested we will not have time to go back to the drawing board.

What is our present and planned state of preparedness? First of all, there is an emphasis on maritime and air surveillance defence and attack systems. I have not heard any criticism of that. One might think for a country such as ours that it is the only rational policy we could adopt. As part of that policy we have had the recent decision to procure 75 F18 aircraft, HMS Invincible and to speed up the procurement of 10 P3C aircraft. The Opposition was hardly cordial in its reaction to the decision to purchase the F18s and of course that decision has not really been touched on in this debate since it makes rather farcical, does it not, the claims that the defence capacities of this country are being gutted, that they were in a state of wind-down and that there is a state of paralysis affecting the defence planning of this country. We are dealing with 75 of the top-line aircraft of this world, the highest state of the art available to us and that state of the art will constitute a very formidable weapons system, as everybody must acknowledge. The case in favour of the P3Cs has been conceded by the Opposition, reluctantly perhaps, so I will say nothing about that.

Let me say something about the Invincible. The honourable member for Swan was kind enough in his balanced analysis of the defence decisions made by this Government to concede that if we were to plan to retake the Falkland Islands it might be a useful craft. One might think the honourable member in saying that was joining all other Opposition spokesmen who have said nothing in favour of the Invincible at all. I would be the first to agree with many honourable members on this side of the House that such an important decision must always raise doubts. One can never be utterly sure that one is making the right decision. But surely to God one would think the Opposition would have more to say on a subject so important to this nation than to direct to this purchase a tirade of abuse followed by a few smart cracks about retaking the Falkland Islands and put that forward as a measured, balanced and responsible reaction to the Government's decision.

Let us look at one or two things the Invincible can do and which have not been mentioned by members of the Opposition. First of all, it has a very considerable troop-carrying capacity. Secondly, it has a capacity to carry vertical take-off fighters. I am very glad that the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen), when he made his statement, made it clear that the Government entertained this aspect as an option, that is, he was not closing the door on procuring those fighters. Let us consider some of the kinds of problems that we might face. Nobody from the Opposition has mentioned our far-flung interests. The fact that the British have to fight many thousands of kilometres from Britain seems to the Opposition to be a matter of some slight amusement.

Has anyone from the Opposition stopped to think that the Cocos (Keeling) Islands are 2,700 kilometres north-west of Perth and even further from Darwin? Has anyone from the Opposition stopped to think that Norfolk Island is over 1, 600 kilometres from Sydney? Does anybody think that we can be certain that in 10 or 15 years we will not need the kind of capacity that the Invincible has to take care of some problem in the Cocos (Keeling) Islands region or elsewhere in the Pacific on islands which are near or far from our coast? For all the criticism that the Opposition has levelled how would it relieve the Cocos ( Keeling) Islands if an enemy force were there? Would it do that with a submarine ? The Argentinians tried that at South Georgia, and what happened? The captain and crew of one submarine came to dinner. One submarine is to be found on the shores of South Georgia. How was that submarine brought down? It was brought down by helicopters from an aircraft carrier.

TALK.START.PARA: —And another one of those submarines is sinking an Argentine cruiser.

—Since the honourable member of Swan has chosen to interject, how does he think that one patrol boat was taken out by the British and another damaged? That was done by a helicopter launched from an aircraft carrier. What would the Opposition have us do? I think it would probably have us buy a whole lot of these small-firing platforms, which, on one view of the equation, is sensible, and on another view, is highly dangerous because they are exceedingly vulnerable to just that sort of attack. Let us therefore accept that if the Opposition had intellectual honesty it would concede that there is a great deal to be said in favour of the purchase of the Invincible. It is dishonest and a disservice to the Australian public to say that there is nothing in favour of it and that the whole story is to the contrary. That is nonsense and dishonest, and that is known.

SPEECH.PARA: Lastly, let me say something about the future. I think we would all agree that we live in unstable and dangerous times. I have not the slightest idea of what are the intentions in detail of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Mr Brezhnev does not talk to me nor to anybody else in this House that I am aware of. I include all members of the Opposition in that statement. But we can be certain of one thing; that is, that what the Soviet Union seeks is a radically different international balance of forces and one that all of us would find intolerable. So what should we do in our region? Clearly, we need to maintain our relationship with the United States of America. But that, in itself, is never enough. Next we need to continue with the building up of our forces. For my part, I would like this Government and the Opposition to agree that very much more money should be spent over the next 10 years on defence than the Opposition most certainly is prepared to spend. Thirdly, we have to develop our relationship with Japan. If one looks to a map of South East Asia and to the area between Japan and Australia, one is struck very clearly by one thing and that is that many of the countries between us have histories of governments which do not promote in our minds a feeling of stability and continuity. One thing that we can be certain about is that the Japanese defence capacity, which is now formidable, will increase over the years. It is in our long term interests that we work as closely as possible to secure a close defence relationship with that country. This may be many years away but it is something that we need to keep in the front of our thinking about defence and about the future of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden). I think I should remind the House of its terms. The first paragraph deals with the failure of the Government to enunciate a clear defence strategy for Australia. I think that those people who have listened to the speeches of Government supporters in this debate to date will find it apparent that no clear strategy exists for the defence of Australia and that honourable members opposite have no idea what the aims of our defence policies are. Obviously the aims and strategies which were set out in the White Paper of 1976 have gone by the board. What, then, are our defence spending programs seeking to achieve? It is for the Government to make decisions on what tasks it expects the defence forces to be able to perform and what are the equipment needs to meet those requirements, and to follow through those programs once they are enunciated.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the major criticisms which is levelled at this Government and which consistently can be levelled at this Government and its predecessors in office, which have a very similar record in the defence area, is that it has a long history of making snap decisions of major consequence which have subsequently not been carried through to completion or have been irrelevant to the long term planning about the capabilities and requirements of the Australian defence forces. The decision to purchase the Invincible fits clearly into this pattern. It is a decision which has more to do with the vision of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) of Australia's international role in the foreign policy area than it has to do with the defence of Australia or the capacities and priorities for the establishment of the defence forces of Australia. This is the criticism. It might be easy to say that the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen), the Department of Defence or the defence forces have not carried through their planning roles or met the requirements of Australia's defence. But the facts are that collective Government decisions, especially those of the Prime Minister, have consistently undermined the long term planning and development of the Australian defence forces along lines which the Government clearly enunciated in 1976 and which it has not yet replaced by another set of criteria for the Australian defence forces. It may be that the Minister for Defence is responsible. However, it may well be, and is more likely, that he is the victim of Government decisions made in respect of financial and other commitments which act against the planning of our defence forces and the achievement of a position in relation to defence which would enable us to defend this country should it become necessary and to carry out those functions which we see as desirable and necessary for the defence of Australia.

Since 1976 in excess of 40 announced programs for equipment in the defence forces have been deferred, cancelled or substantially delayed. Some of these programs were announced in this House with a lot of trumpeting and great fanfare . Others have come and gone almost unnoticed. Unfortunately there is also a history of quickie statements-statements not properly thought through-being announced in this House when it has been obvious that they could not be carried through. It is now said that the purchase cost of the Orion aircraft is one of the reasons for the problems with the defence budget at the moment. It is one of the problems which has forced deferments and cancellations of equipment and the deferment of payments on items of equipment already in the pipeline.

In February 1980, the Prime Minister announced to this House that a modernisation program would be undertaken in respect of the P3B Orion aircraft. In March 1980, the Minister for Defence made a similar announcement in this House. This was despite the fact that the Australian Department of Defence some six years earlier had undertaken studies into the feasibility of modernising those aircraft and had determined that it was not cost effective and that it would be a better proposition to purchase new aircraft rather than seek to extend the life or change the technical capacities of those aircraft. It is not a case of a sudden problem relating to the P3Cs. It is a case of the Government making an announcement without first investigating the advisability of that announcement and subsequently having to go back on it because ultimately it came to the same conclusions as had been arrived at six years earlier. It was then decided to buy P3C aircraft. The advancement in the program was not caused by a sudden concern about additional capacity for anti-submarine warfare; it was brought about by the fact that the production run for these aircraft is about to cease. Because of procrastination and because of an incorrect decision back in early 1980 on a program which was not in the best interests of Australian defence planning, we are now caught in the situation where we place orders now and keep the production line going or the aircraft will not be available. That is the truth about the P3Cs. It is not that the Government has suddenly decided to advance that program; it has been caught by its own earlier mistakes in defence planning.

In a large number of areas the Government's advanced defence planning just does not add up. We have just heard that suddenly we will have a new capacity because helicopters will operate off the Invincible. One wonders in what way a helicopter operating off a highly vulnerable platform such as the Invincible is any better than a helicopter operating off an FFG. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) indicated that we would be dropping that capacity and would now be using the helicopters off a different platform. Let us not kid ourselves about the Invincible. An aircraft carrier is desirable in any defence situation, especially when a country has large reaches of sea to protect. It is not the desirability that matters; it is the priorities that are established for the expenditure of the funds available in the defence area that are important. Those priorities have to be questioned in this House because they do not fit into any pattern of strategic planning; they do not have any consequence for the defence of Australia.

In fact, if deterrence is the aim-that is what honourable members opposite have mentioned-we have reduced the deterrence available by purchasing the Invincible. It is a vulnerable platform that any country with the military capacity to carry out a major attack on Australia could plan to and know it could remove. It is not defended by any systems and the Minister has not indicated that systems for defence against missile atack will be incorporated. In fact, his statement earlier indicated that they will not be. It is to have its radar capacity, vital to the defence of any weapons system, reduced by 50 per cent by the replacement of its existing radar capability with the totally obsolete system which will be removed from the Melbourne. It has no fixed wing air defence and none is planned . It is a very expensive toy which will add little to the defence capacity of Australia but which will reduce other capacities significantly.

What we want to know, and what we as a parliament are entitled to know, is what is the strategic aim of the purchase of this piece of equipment when we see displayed no urgency whatsoever to produce equipment which will add to and provide for the actual defence of this country. The Australian defence forces have no surface-to-air missiles available at all. In fact, the Chief of Defence Force Staff some time ago made a rather alarming statement to the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. He said: 'I understand we used to have one missile but we gave it away.'

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense, Gordon.

—That is what he said, and the Minister knows it. We have no modern defence against an aircraft attack. I instance how vulnerable we are. At one stage, being half smart-which is not unusual for the Prime Minister-and trying to score political points, the Prime Minister spread the fact that Backfire bombers operating from bases in Vietnam could now operate over Australian soil. The statement backfired because the Prime Minister-who did not pursue the matter once he saw he was in trouble; for that I give him credit-found out that Australia had no defence capacity whatsoever in any shape or form against a Backfire bomber. Our fighters could not intercept it and the missiles with which the Mirage aircraft are equipped could not catch it; in other words, if the Russians decided to put a Backfire bomber over Australia we would have to sit by and hope they missed their targets, which they would not. We have no surface-to- air missiles and no interceptor or fighter aircraft capable of dealing with that situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The planned update of the Mirage aircraft has gone by the board. So has the planned re-equipment of the F111 planes with electronics that would enable them to deal with precision weapons. So has the re-equipment of the Oberon submarines with Harpoon weapons-a program announced some time ago with a lot of flair but which has not been carried out. As the Minister well knows-certainly his advisers do-the F111 is one of the best aircraft in the world for obtaining and getting to a target. In its present capacity, with analogue computers, it lacks the ability to use precision guided weapons-the types of weapons that honourable members opposite will be telling us have been so successful in the Falkland Islands. The only capacity Australia's F111s have-even with the modified update taking place-is to drop iron bombs. It is a waste of a very sophisticated weapons system but there is to be no re-equipment in this program; it has gone. That would be one of those things which would help to provide a deterrent, to provide Australia with an adequate defence capacity. But there is no planning; there is no program. What there is is a series of announcements made by the Government whenever some crisis occurs-announcements which have no connection whatsoever with long term defence programs. There is no strategic aim; there is no development plan for the Australian defence forces; and there are no directions to the defence forces on what capacities they should plan to achieve.

Apparently we have only one aim and that is to provide Australia with the greatest capacity anywhere in the world to find submarines. I say 'to find' them but that is not a defence capability. It is to provide ourselves with knowledge. After we find them, we must have the capacity to destroy them. The honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), who spoke first in this debate today, made a lot of noise about the problems the Australian Army faced because conscription had been withdrawn. It might interest him to know that even now the Government cannot meet its recruitment programs. It cannot fulfill its stated recruitment aims. This is at a time of massive unemployment. If we are about defending liberty, we are entitled also to acknowledge that people in the community are entitled to that liberty, something the honourable member does not understand.

Most important to Australian defence-critical, in fact-is a capacity to get to the place where one is required to engage in action. A notable feature of major exercises in Australia is that logistic movements are excluded. They are simulated, not performed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harris Mr G.McD.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to take part in the debate on the statement on defence last Thursday by the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen). That statement demonstrated the continuing commitment of the Government to the sound defence of this country. It included an announcement rescheduling the acquisition of certain items of equipment. This became necessary because of the opportunity to acquire HMS Invincible and the P3C Orion aircraft-items of equipment which I remind the House, were at all times times part of our defence program but which, happily for Australia, became available sooner and more cheaply than expected.

SPEECH.PARA: It is doubtful whether a statement has ever been so completely misrepresented as was that of the Minister. I take this opportunity to answer some of those misrepresentations. It has been said that defence cuts have taken place. The fact is that there have not been cuts in defence spending at all. This year defence spending has increased by 19 per cent in money terms, or about 8 per cent in real terms, which is an enormous increase. Also, it is clear that next year there will be a further increase in real terms. Indeed, defence spending should then reach an amount equal to about 3 per cent of gross domestic product. Unfortunately, the rescheduling of our defence purchases has been characterised as making cuts. This is simply not correct. The honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) stated, last Thursday I believe:
Deferred payments are not payments forgone. They are not payments which reduce their impact into the defence equipment budget.
Deferring some payments is part of the rescheduling which was referred to earlier in the Minister's statement on Invincible. The Minister said:
. . . though some rescheduling is unavoidable, this act should be measured against a background of other recent decisions involving substantial expenditure .

Rescheduling within the defence program takes place all the time; it is not new. It is part of the very nature of managing a large program, one that must be alive to changing circumstances and opportunities. The chance to buy Invincible was a rare opportunity, one of which the Government sought to take advantage. The opportunity arose quickly and the Government believed that its purchase should be given priority. I have no doubt that decision was correct. Further, the recent P3C decision was also taken against shifting circumstances, circumstances such that if we had not acted we would have had to wait many more years and eventually pay a vastly greater sum to get the aircraft. The honourable member for Corio, who is the Opposition spokesman on defence matters, seems to misunderstand the situation completely. Last Thursday he said amongst other things:
The price to the Navy of the Invincible is to be . . . a substantive reduction in capacity, including a total loss of naval air power.
I emphasise that he said 'total'-
But there is no suggestion that that power will be retained or that naval air power will be restored. There is to be no fixed wing aircraft on a carrier . . .
He went on:
. . . only the British Navy, of all major navies, in fact relies solely on carrier-borne aircraft for naval air operations.
I will certainly return to the last sentence of that statement. He went on:

The Minister . . . released a statement which indicated that a committee would be established to study the future of naval air power. The terminal date of the Melbourne has been known for five years. It was mentioned, as was an inquiry into the future of naval air power, in the 1976 White Paper . . .
He also said:
The ultimate cost . . .
He was referring to the purchase of Invincible--

. . . will be a reduced anti-submarine warfare capability in the Australian Defence Force . . . We are losing a capacity in pensioning off the Tracker aircraft. We will have no fixed wing aircraft on the Invincible. That fact has been announced.
Finally, he said:
The Sea King helicopter depends on a dunking buoy sonar operation which is not of significant anti-submarine value in view of the numbers which can be operated from the Invincible.

It is instructive to consider these statements by the Opposition spokesman and then see just how much they are out of touch with reality. The fact is that the cost of purchasing Invincible, with initial support, is $475m. The cost of alternatives, such as the amphibious assault ship, LPH, of the United States Navy, would almost certainly be double this amount. Of course, the program has always included a ship of this type. The Government has simply taken advantage of an opportunity to get such a ship earlier and at a better price. Further, alternative platforms would not be available for some years following our acquisition of Invincible. Savings will be effected as a result of paying off Melbourne early and cancelling the proposed 1982 refit, lower running costs until Invincible arrives and in manpower over the life of the Invincible. The proposed expenditure on Invincible represents a very minor component of the total equipment expenditure in the defence program. In all, it amounts to about 6 per cent. It is not true to say that there will be a total loss of naval air power. Helicopters will remain in the Royal Australian Navy for both anti- submarine warfare and other tasks. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) referred also to other uses, including anti-surface action, to which helicopters can be put.

The importance of embarked ASW helicopters was a major influence in the Government's decision to acquire a purpose-built ASW carrier. The British Navy relies not only on ship-borne helicopters and Harrier short take-off and vertical landing aircraft, but also aircraft of the Royal Air Force. Apparently, the honourable member for Corio did not know that. Shore-based aircraft include the Nimrod maritime surveillance aircraft, Nimrod air defence early warning aircraft and Tornado multi-role combat aircraft. Indeed, the suggestion by the honourable member for Corio that the Royal Navy alone, of all the major navies, relies solely on carrier-based aircraft is an extraordinary one. To my knowledge France, the United States, Spain and Italy-when its carrier has been completed- Brazil and India use a similar combination of land-based and carrier-based aircraft. It may be that Argentina does not have land-based aircraft dedicated to maritime support, but, if so, it is the only navy with a carrier, that I know of, that does not.

I shall now deal with some of the honourable member's other observations. There is to be, not a committee to study the future of naval airpower, but a working party to examine the position of the Navy's existing fixed-wing aircraft. This is a most important difference. In the short term, naval air power will be vested in helicopters, while maritime air power will additionally include appropriate aircraft of the Royal Australian Air Force-the P3C Orions, the F111s and the FA18 Hornets when they arrive. In the longer term, the question of the use of short take-off and vertical landing aircraft by the Navy will arise. No decision in that regard has yet been made, but I hope that eventually we will acquire Harrier types of aircraft to make full use of the capabilities of Invincible.

The terminal date for Melbourne, to which the honourable gentleman referred, has been quite flexible. Recent planning has been based on retaining her in service further into the 1980s. The 1976 White Paper stated that Melbourne's life 'can be extended to 1985'. The Government, in a sensible piece of rescheduling, has decided to be finished with Melbourne and obtain Invincible earlier. The decision not to pursue options to acquire a conventional aircraft carrier was a sensible one; even if an appropriate design had emerged the cost would have been excessive. Invincible can embark and operate up to 22 aircraft, including Sea Kings with dunking sonar. This would be more than adequate for ASW operations and, in fact, is more than can be carried in Melbourne at present. In this regard, Invincible has considerable spare capacity, which will be available for future generation ASW helicopters, with sonics for sonobuoys such as the BARRA, which was developed in Australia.

In the short term we will be operating our existing Sea King ASW helicopters, with dunking sonar from the carrier, We have six in service and two are on order . Other helicopters, such as the Wessex, can be carried for embarked search and rescue purposes. The prospects for the purchase of additional ASW helicopters are under review. The Minister stated that 'planned expenditure for additional helicopters has been deferred', not that 'there would be no more ASW . . . helicopters', which is what I believe the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison) alleged.

It is unfortunate that, at a time when defence matters are more in public consciousness because of the Falklands situation, the announcement made last Thursday should be misrepresented as representing defence cuts. Let me remind the House that since the mid-1970s we have obtained for the Defence Force- specifically in this instance the Army-Leopard tanks, Rapier missiles, fire support vehicles, Land Rovers, other vehicles and Nomad aircraft. Equipment which is in the pipeline includes communications and electronic warfare equipment, medium 155 millimetre guns, light 105 millimetre guns and a large number of trucks and other vehicles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who ordered all those?

—Negotiations to acquire anti-tank missiles are well advanced. In the course of discussing the continued acquisitions for and support of our Defence Force, it would be irrelevant to discuss who ordered them. Honourable members opposite have been trying to persuade the Australian public over the last few days that nothing is being acquired. That is simply untrue. It is also worth reminding the House of major defence decisions taken at the time of or since the Budget last August. They include: The tactical fighter; the new basic trainer; 10 P3C aircraft-this has already been mentioned-Invincible; long lead items for the first follow-on destroyer; the modernisation of the guided missile frigates and a whole range of other items such as tactical teleprinters, laser airborne depth sounders and the like. Work is also proceeding on improvements to various of the defence facilities such as airfields and the Garden Island dockyard. When considering a major defence purchase, or indeed the construction of a major defence facility, it is worth remembering that such equipment or facilities will have to last for 25 years or more. This is well beyond the period where any sensible person could make precise predictions as to the future course of international events. It is desirable, therefore, to get weapons and weapons platforms which are the best, contain the greatest capacity for expansion, and are the most flexible that we can afford. The purchases in the current program meet that need.

TALK.START.PARA: —The words that the Opposition has proposed-I would like to read them out to order the debate for the for the remainder of the evening-are:

SPEECH.PARA: This House expresses its want of confidence in the Government because of-
(1) its failure to enunciate a clear defence strategy for Australia;
(2) its persistent failure to maintain its announced defence programs, and
(3) the confusion and distortions in defence planning which have seriously weakened Australia's security.

For any political party to move a want of confidence motion requires serious consideration and, I trust, the serious consideration of this House. Tonight we are debating the statement by the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen). It is a statement that the Opposition has condemned, a statement that the Opposition has censured. I was reminded in a previous intervention by the honourable member for Chisholm (Mr Harris) that over the last six years the Government has had a very easy run in defence. As I was reminded again by the observations of the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) and the honourable member for Chisholm, over the last six years this Government has been parading in borrowed clothes. There was mention of the Leopard tanks in the speech by the honourable member for Chisholm. I intervened: 'Who ordered all those?' They were ordered in the period 1972-75. The first two of the FFGs were ordered in that period. The Rapier surface-to-air missiles, HMAS Tobruk, the 15 patrol boats, the Orion--

TALK.START.PARA: —No. We ordered them in two lots of five.

—My good friend the Minister for Defence raises an objection. I remember quite clearly stating in this House in August 1975 the announcement of the decision to purchase the 15 patrol boats. I am sure that the Minister for Defence, who was then in the Opposition, clearly and adequately recalls that event. Throughout these years all the major decisions that the Government has had to take on board were decisions that were made in that period of the Labor Government. I will grant to the Minister that his Government added two FFGs. It also added some more Leopard tanks. That proposition came to me as Minister for Defence from the Department of Defence and I rejected it. It came to the current Minister who, as we all know, is the long-serving Minister for Defence, although I understand that that period of tenure may be coming to an end. I regret that, but I hope he enjoys greener and more lucrative fields in the future. He ordered them and, of course, what happened was that they all went into mothballs.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of observations have been made during this debate of the Australian Labor Party's administration of defence. We set out very clearly and concisely the defence doctrine, of what Australia's defence was about. I was delighted to see in the 1976 White Paper that all the propositions that we had put forward in the period 1972-75 had been accepted by the Government. The only real difference is that, having accepted them, it has proved a monumental incapacity to implement them. Time after time great promises have been made but time after time the Minister for Defence and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) have come into this House and had to regret sincerely their incapacity to carry out the plans.

The Opposition moved an amendment recently in relation to the aircraft carrier. One of the points of that amendment-I will read it because it is very relevant to what we are discussing tonight-was the proposition that the matter should be considered by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence in order to study the effects of the purchase of an aircraft carrier on future defence procurement programs. It is very important and it is very necessary in making any decision on defence to ensure, firstly, that it happens to conform with the strategic analysis of the situation; secondly, that it happens to complement the force structure-not just the Navy, the Air Force or the Army, but the defence structure-and, thirdly, that it should happen to play some part in a sensible and rational defence financial program.

This Government has not been able to meet those three important criteria. The five-year rolling program is something that it has never been able to understand . When an item comes in at year five it is not a decision to purchase. It enters that five-year rolling program as part and parcel of a defence planning exercise . The idea of having a five-year rolling program is to iron out the humps and drops in defence expenditure so that we have a sane and sensible defence program . But, unfortunately, this Government has not been able to do that. With the purchase of the Invincible and the accelerated purchase of the P3C aircraft- again items that we had originally ordered and that the Government has added to over a period-has had a tremendous impact on the budgetary arrangements, or the financial arrangements, and the Government's whole program is in tatters.

Let us look at some of the documentation that has not been referred to in this debate. I think it is important that we should refer to it. I refer to the explanatory notes of the Department of Defence about the estimates of expenditure in Appropriation Bill (No. 3). These were provided-I think that this is something that we as members of the House of Representatives should keep in mind-to our colleagues in the Senate but were not provided to us. The estimates provide for an expenditure this year of $81.6m on the aircraft carrier. If we look at the total program of expenditure for 1981-82 on naval construction, as provided for in division 234.1.01, we find that the program was estimated at $ 202.9m. If we add to what was agreed upon by this Parliament in the discussion of the Budget the figure of $81.6m, which is what the cost of the aircraft carrier involves this year, we come up with a figure of $284.5m. But when we turn to the revised estimates put forward by the Government we find that, instead of asking for $284.5m, it has asked for only $238m. Therefore, the Navy' s program-not the program of the Air Force or the program of the Army-has been effectively cut by $46.5m.

But that is not all. If we look also at the documentation from the Government in the form of the statement of savings expected in the annual appropriations we find some more interesting figures and facts. A felicitous word, 'savings', is used. If one looks at division 234.1.02, which relates to aircraft and associated equipment, one finds that expenditure on this item has been slashed- admittedly it is covered by this lovely word 'savings' but it has been slashed nonetheless-by $62.7m. If we turn to division 234.1.04 we find that expenditure on other equipment and stores has been slashed by $73m. Let us get rid of this nonsense of the Government that the expendture program has not been slashed. These documents prepared by the Government show in the vital area of defence equipment that the program has been slashed. So let us not monkey around with these phrases that the Government has put forward. It is an effective cut in the most sensitive area of our procurement programs-the area of equipment.

This means that there has been, to use the new lexicon that the Minister for Defence has developed, a deferral, a rescheduling and a termination of the major programs of the Air Force and the Navy. So we come to the basic consideration that expenditure on the aircraft carrier is not only distorting the Navy's force structure but also reducing the force structure of the other Services. There was a lot of talk this afternoon about the effects and priorities and so on. But what is happening is that this impetuous decision has distorted the financial program. That is what this debate is all about; this is what we are discussing tonight; this is why we are discussing this matter. Not only is it distorting the financial program but also it is effectively distorting the force structure of the Navy as well as the Air Force and the other service. That is what we are considering; that is why this statement is being debated in this House today.

The other reference in our motion is to the persistent failure of the Government to maintain its announced defence program. It is a long, sorry sad history of persistent failure. It goes back to 1971 when Prime Minister Gorton announced a decision to cut $75m of Government spending; and, of that $75m, $21. 5m came from defence. Who do honourable members think was the Minister for Defence in those days presiding over these cuts in defence expenditure? It was none other than the present Prime Minister.

What is interesting is the rationale. It was said: 'There will be, however, some slowing down of a large range of purchases and delays'. This was the rundown in the period 1968 through to 1972. Observations have been made about the Australian Labor Party's defence expenditure. But all of those cuts were made in the period prior to 1972. Before that year, there was a substantial cut in the expenditure on defence equipment. In 1968-69, actual expenditure on new equipment amounted to something of the order of 25 per cent of the Budget. By 1971-72, that figure had dropped to 11.5 per cent. For anyone who wants to seek to contradict me, this information is contained in the annual reports of the Department of Defence. We had to pick up the shambles in 1972 to 1975. We made a very conscious decision that what was needed in the Australian defence forces was a greater emphasis on equipment. We can analyse each expenditure on equipment from 1972 to 1975 and onwards. We do not pay for all of these things in one fell swoop. The whole program of capital equipment that we initiated in that period is still continuing. We are still paying for some of the decisions. But when it came to decisions on FA18 aircraft and decisions on the aircraft carrier-the seaborne air platform-this Government got itself into a monumental mess because it did not understand-and I fear it still does not understand-the requirements of defence planning and the real meaning and real intent of a five- year rolling program.

Let us look at the performance of the Labor Party. Despite all the rhetoric of the Liberal Party, all the pomp of the statements made in the 1976 White Paper and the statements made in the fervour of Afghanistan, the expenditure in terms of gross domestic product of the first six years of the Liberal Government was exactly the same-that is 2.6 per cent of GDP-as that which the Labor Government achieved in the 1975-76 Budget. So it is preposterous for the Government to criticise the performance of the Labor Party, because the whole basis of what this Government has done over the last five years has been what was laid out by the Labor Party. But tonight we are faced with a dismal statement, a statement that is a confession of mismanagement by the Government. It cannot manage its defence procurement programs and it has not brought forward a consistent line on defence doctrine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shortly before the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison) sat down, he used a somewhat pejorative phrase-'the fervour of Afghanistan'. I remind him that there are still some 100, 000 Russian soldiers in Afghanistan. I remind him of the occasion when, at the Congress of Vienna, there was a break up of the Napoleonic Empire and the news was brought to the great Austrian statesman Metternich that the chief Russian delegate had died. I should like to ask the honourable gentleman, who tosses off such smart phrases as 'the fervour of Afghanistan': What is the motive of the Russian presence in Afghanistan today?

SPEECH.PARA: When I first came to the Department of Defence, seemingly a long time ago, I had but two high hopes. The first was that it would be possible to introduce some rationality in defence debate throughout this country. The second was that it would be possible to find some measure of bipartisanship in defence considerations. After the period that I have spent as Minister, I must confess that I am sharply disappointed. I should have thought that it would be at least possible for men and women of clear conscience to agree upon facts and then to interpret facts according to their prejudice or according to their political philosphy-but at least to agree upon facts.

I find myself somewhat dismayed, looking at the packed Press Gallery, that during the last few days some of the lamentations about the statement I put down last Thursday have been directed towards the fact that I did not hold a Press conference after making the statement. This is no mere sentimental grievance. I strive in this world to observe good manners towards everyone. In the 27 years in which I have been in this Parliament, I have placed in high priority the observance of good manners towards this Parliament. It is an institution that I value very highly. I should like those in the Press Gallery, principally from the Australian and the Age, to understand but one thing: I was elected to this Parliament, not elected to come here and to answer to Press conferences.

I would regard it as an insult of the highest order if I delivered a speech and walked out of the House without listening to the member who followed me, and I would regard it as a gross offence to my friend the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes), who moved an amendment, if I had sailed out to go to a Press conference. The amendment was seconded by the honourable member for St George, and I felt under the clearest obligation to stay and listen to him. After having listened to both of my honourable friends-disagreeing vigorously, I assert-I was then under an obligation to introduce the Defence Force Discipline Bill, a Bill that had been hanging around this country and this Parliament for some 37 years. I am prepared to face the Press of this country at any time, but it will be a time of my choosing, and I do not propose to be instructed in parliamentary behaviour by any political columnist or by any editorial writer. My obligation is to this Parliament and to the people I represent, and I hope that is clearly understood by the Press.

Today I noticed that one of the papers was invoking a non-journalistic political commentator. Who is he? Anonymity or accusation! Has this House got to the stage where it feels inured to this? If the writer has qualifications, let them be paraded. Let us find out who he is, if he has any bias, if he has any competence. I appeal to honourable ladies and gentlemen on both sides of the House to understand the importance of that.

I congratulate the honourable member for St George on what I must describe as an almost virginal display of moderation because this evening he went to the very heart of the difficulty in defence planning, namely, the fact that it is not something which is static, something which is immutable. I am under heavy obligation to my honourable friend for having reminded the House of that salient , that singular, that solitary dominating fact-that defence planning is not inflexible. But I want to invite honourable members to agree on one fact and that is-use what figures they may like-at the end of the day they must come to the conclusion that this year in money terms, as against last year, there is a 19 per cent increase. I am prepared to listen to argument as to whether or not it is in real terms. I am duty bound to listen to argument and I have a heavy preference to listen to argument provided it is honestly, cleanly and directly delivered. But when I find in a newspaper like the Age language such as 'Massive defence cuts', I want to ask my distinguished friend Creighton Burns: What would he say if he had a 19 per cent increase in salary? Would he face the board of directors with equanimity and say 'Oh, it has been a cut'? Would he say to his board if his circulation had increased by 19 per cent 'Oh, but I would like to say to you, Mr Ranald Macdonald, and to your colleagues that the circulation has gone up by 19 per cent but you tell me it is a cut'? It is the language of Alice in Wonderland: When I use a word it means what I choose it to mean, nothing more , neither less.

The central feature of this defence debate-I am indebted again to my honourable friend from St George; it is a pity that the debate could not run on for several days-is the question of priorities. I do not gainsay it in any shape or form. My honourable friend may seek to impeach me, to rebuke me; but I use the language of deferrals. I am not conscious of having used the language of cuts. This is precisely one of the conspicuous features of the five-year defence rolling program in this country. It is not, as the honourable gentleman says, something static, something immutable. It is something that changes-changing according to technological advance, changing according to strategic circumstances, changing according to contractual opportunity. At the very Mediterranean of this argument we find two things, and I am prepared to discuss them. The program has been disturbed by two things. One is the purchase of the helicopter carrier, the HMS Invincible, and the other involves the P3C aircraft. I do not wish in any way to lacerate my friend the honourable member for Corio but I say this to him: He is the only person I have heard to offer any complaint about the program of the P3C Orion aircraft. I do appeal to my honourable friend to come to the Department of Defence and get his facts right, not according to me but according to the neutrality of professional officers. My friend has confused his mind with the installation in the 1970s of Barra equipment in the P3Cs and the possibility of installing Barra equipment in the P3Bs. It was decided against going the P3B way for a variety of reasons. Today that judgment has been reinforced because the fatigue life of the P3B would be shortened considerably. In 1995 very special measures would have to be taken to carry it through to the year 2000 but the life of the P3Cs would be much longer.

I come to the Invincible. This is where we differ. When I put down a statement in this House announcing the Government's decision in September 1980 about the acquisition of an anti-submarine warfare capability by the way of a helicopter carrier for this country, I was astonished; there was very little public debate about it. For a variety of reasons, not the least of them being that the United Kingdom found itself in financial difficulty, we got the bargain-priced offer of the Invincible. I will go on to argue about whether the Opposition thinks the acquisition is merited.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not.

—I hear my honourable friend say: 'It is not'. One editorial writer asked: 'Where is this submarine threat to this country?' I think it is time the country was told this. A bit of gleaning from Janes Fighting Ships alone, quite apart from any other source, will produce the information that in Littoral countries in our region there are some 300 submarines, and the preponderance of those are held in the Soviet Pacific fleet. That is the threat. People may dismiss it and say: 'This is of no account'. But I want to say to the House that when the opportunity was presented to this country for the acquisition of Invincible the Government was under the clearest obligation to consider it, and to consider it earnestly. I can find any number of my Service advisers who do not share the judgment which was made. But this judgment one can find altering from one piece of defence equipment acquisition to another.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not seek to make mean points. This is my twenty-seventh year here. I do not propose to stay another 27 years. I am interested in this Parliament and I am interested in this country. I am interested in my family and I am interested in my friends. The mean points no longer interest me. But I cannot recall a debate on one piece of heavy defence equipment that has met opposition approval. I can take my honourable friend the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) through some of the speeches which he made upon the acquisition of the F111 in which he described the aircraft in harsh and rather rugged terms. I could point him to debates held in this House and in another place on the acquisition of the FA18. To what point? What does it serve? The fact is that we are under an obligation to consider these matters as objectively as we can. I believe that this nation was clearly charged with the responsibility of finding for itself a significant ASW capability. As I say, there may be differences upon this great issue. We could not find that capability by using P3Cs. We could not find it by using the FFG helicopter which, I am sorry to say, is still far out there. The technology in that field sweeps at a pace which fills me with both awe and, indeed, a sense of horror. But this opportunity came our way. If we were to acquire this ASW capability seaborne there was the opportunity. We would never find it through the other two carriers made available, the Iwo Jima or the Garabaldi class carriers. There was the opportunity and the judgment had to be made.

I do not seek to take any mean point, because my great complaint about contemporary Australia is that there are occasions when we seem to concentrate upon those matters which divide us rather than attending to those things which should indeed unite us. If we could have the opportunity of a more extensive debate upon these issues in this House-I would seek the first such opportunity-I believe that we would find a greater measure of commonality.

The last thing I want to say to the House, and through this House I trust to the country, and please God into the hearts and minds of Australians, is that I referred in my statement to what I regard as being the dire threat that faces the whole of civilised mankind-no, the whole of mankind, even though he be uncivilised-and that is the nuclear holocaust and the great gathering of nuclear strength now possessed by the two super-powers. This is the outstanding commitment which must be addressed by every man and every woman interested in the preservation of the species. I can understand the fretful anxiety of some of my honourable friends opposite who seek to take some advantage out of this. I have not yet abandoned my conviction that given the time, given the opportunity, we will find a greater measure of agreement than they have now paraded before us .
