This Bill and the Radiocommunications (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1982, which I will introduce shortly, vary the basis on which radiocommunications licence fees are charged. The intent of these Bills is to allow for radiocommunications licence fees to be determined on a basis other than solely the recovery of the costs of administering the radio spectrum. In future, regulations made under the Radiocommunications Licence Fees Bill 1982 will set out the fees applicable. At present, licence fees are determined by regulations made under the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905. This Bill also includes a provision to ensure that all Commonwealth and Territory authorities are required to pay fees. In addition, it provides for transitional arrangements to exempt licencees who have already paid licence fees under the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905 from payment of fees under the new Bill, in respect of the grant or renewal of licences during the period 1 July 1981 to the date of commencement of these measures.

Other matters connected with the implementation of these measures are included in the Radiocommunications (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1982. Honourable members will be aware that section 55 of the Constitution requires that no matter other than the imposition of taxation can be validly dealt with in a tax Act. The costs of providing radio frequency management services relate, among other factors, to the amount of spectrum space needed to accommodate the service , to whether the service is in a valuable part of the spectrum, to the service's potential to interfere with other services and to the power allocated. Each assignment complicates the task of succeeding assignments as there is less spectrum available for allocation.

All these factors were taken into account when setting radiocommunication licence fees for 1981-82. As this financial year was the first year in which full cost recovery was implemented, there was an overall increase in most categories of fees of the order of 12 per cent. However, some categories of licences increased by much greater percentages as these categories of licences were previously charged at levels well below the costs associated with them. The licencees, in some cases, faced increases in fees of the order of many thousands of dollars. The television industry was particularly affected due to its extensive use of wide-band fixed links. Let me explain that many television stations introduced their television services and the translator adjuncts to them largely because of the concessions that are available in this area. While at that stage full recompense was not sought for the connection of these links, it is felt that there should now be a redistribution of charges. It was with that in mind that the charges were changed at the time of the last Budget.

These fixed links are essential to the operation of many stations, especially to those stations serving a viewing population spread over a wide area. The links are used to distribute programs to remote transmitters and for studio to transmitter links. These facilities were established at great capital cost at a time when the licence fees for these radiocommunications links ranged from $40 to around $300. Accordingly, the cost of a radiocommunication licence for these links was very low in comparison with the costs involved in establishing and maintaining them. I might point out that, because they were low, many of these stations were able to provide an extension of services that otherwise the higher cost-the cost that is now to be imposed-might well have precluded.

In 1981-82, with the implementation of full cost recovery in the radio frequency management area, the cost of licensing these links increased dramatically with the fee liability of two stations now exceeding $30,000. Most other existing licence fee categories were not affected to the same extent as the fees paid by them in previous years were relatively close to the cost recovery related fees introduced in 1981-82. The Government's attention has been drawn to the problems that these increases have caused some licencees and, following reconsideration of the matter, the Government has decided that some adjustment in fees is necessary. The Government remains firmly committed to full cost recovery in the area of radio frequency management but acknowledges that a period of phasing in of these fees is appropriate and that the measures should be retrospective to 1 July 1981.

The Government has been advised that it would be appropriate for its objectives to be achieved by the introduction of legislation providing for the imposition of licence fees as taxes, with the actual levels of fees being established in regulations made under the new legislation. Accordingly, licence fees would cease to be prescribed in the Wireless Telegraphy Regulations made under the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905.

In introducing these Bills, I wish to make three things clear. First, the Bills do not indicate an intention on the part of the Government to increase immediately and substantially radiocommunications licence fees. The appropriate levels of these fees will be determined by the Government in the light of all relevant factors. Of course, this significantly includes the cost of providing the administration of the spectrum itself. Second, the fees to be imposed by these measures do not apply to normal television and broadcasting receivers. There is no suggestion that they should do so. Third, commercial television and radio stations are licensed under separate legislation in respect of their broadcasting activities-that is, transmissions intended for reception by the general public. Fees imposed under this legislation will not apply to those activities. Radiocommunications licence fees apply to the transmission and reception of private and business radio communications conducted via two-way radios and microwave links. In fact, the charges under this Bill will provide for an extension of three years within which full cost recovery will be implemented. I commend this Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill (No. 1) 1982 is one of a series of general statute law revision Bills. It amends 39 different Acts of Parliament and contains 237 clauses. We are pleased that the Government has accepted the suggestion of the Opposition, made in November last year, that these Bills should be titled and numbered as this Bill is. Honourable members can imagine the difficulties for practitioners in trying to find out what amendments have been made to legislation when it is put in a package which amends so many Bills. The only point I make is that modesty forbids me from saying which member of the Opposition made that suggestion.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill involves the responsibilities of 10 different shadow Ministers. If each of them were to speak on the Bill the Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) would have a haemorrhage because we would be here for many hours. Basically it is a non-controversial Bill. I suggest to the Government that while we do not disagree with the introduction of Bills of this kind, it would be a useful idea if, in future, they were referred to legislation committees where the detail of the Bills could be discussed.

I have already made comments about legislation committees. I believe that if amendments are made in a legislation committee it is neither a win to the Opposition nor a victory to the Government: It is Parliament and, in particular, this House exercising its right to scrutinise legislation. I believe it is unfortunate that when legislation such as the Customs Amendment Bill 1979, which dealt with narcotics, is substantially amended by virtue of amendments proposed by the Opposition the Press chooses to see it as a defeat for the Government. I can understand why the Government has felt reticent about sending legislation to committees since that date. However, the Customs Amendment Bill established important principles in terms of civil liberties because of the amendments then passed. Bills such as this, I believe, are ideal for sending to legislation committees and I hope the Government will consider that suggestion.

I do not believe there is much point in rehashing the points made in the second reading speech of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) who represents the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). The most important of the amendments are concerned with the companies and securities law and my colleague the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) will be dealing with these. Those amendments were fully debated in the Senate. They relate to the Companies Act in a number of ways which he will fully elaborate on, namely, investigation, the question of interim orders and the question of declaration pursuant to section 60.

The amendments to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act go some way towards mitigating provisions preventing the disclosure of the giving of reasons for decisions which we in the Opposition have objected to in the past. Whilst they do not go as far as we would like, we welcome the reforms. The amendments being made to the Acts Interpretation Act relating to regulations have been the subject of recommendation of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, and the Opposition supports them. We also think it appropriate that the title of the Australian Capital Territory's highest judge be Chief Justice rather than Chief Judge, which puts him on par with the Chief Justices of all State courts.

Many other amendments are being made by this Bill. A quite important one is the amendment to enable royal commissions to function in foreign countries. Again, we support that provision. Many of the other amendments are purely of a drafting or correctional nature. Some of them are to previous statute law revision Acts, however they have been called, but we would be the first to concede that parliamentary draftsmen, particularly when they are dealing with laws as detailed as these types of Bills, may make mistakes. We do not object to that and we do not object to correction of those mistakes in Bills such as this. I said on the last occasion when a Bill such as this was before the House in November 1981 that it would be far better if matters of substance were not dealt with in these statute law Bills. I think that is important. I regard matters relating to the companies, securities and takeover laws as being matters of substance. I think it would have been better had they been dealt with by separate legislation.

Last time we were debating a Bill such as this we dealt with 29 Acts of Parliament. This time we are dealing with 39 Acts, and I hope we will not see any increase in that number unless we are dealing with amendments of a purely drafting or technical nature. I hope that the Government will take up this suggestion that in future these Bills be dealt with by a legislation committee so that the details of the Bills can be discussed. The very fact that we are in this Bill amending two previous statute law Bills ought to be testament enough to the fact that we ought to spend more time discussing these Bills in that way. Accordingly, the opposition supports the legislation. My colleague will be elaborating on those provisions relating to the companies and securities Acts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to concentrate in my remarks on the amendments which are provided in this Bill to three of the codes of the national Co-operative Companies and Securities Scheme. At the outset I wish to register my objection to the burying in an omnibus Bill of these important amendments. Many of these are of substance and are, if not in themselves controversial, at least related to issues and problems which have been considered controversial by sections of the business and legal communities. This so-called omnibus Bill contains amendments to 39 different Acts. Therefore, it is very difficult to draw appropriate public attention to the changes involved in any one area and subsequently to use the printed statute in an easy and efficient manner. Moreover, this is just a further means of reducing the effective scrutiny of company law in this Parliament-scrutiny already taken from us to a great extent by the dictates of the co-operative scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: However, notwithstanding this objection, the Opposition supports the Bill. Indeed, it welcomes its provisions which in general clarify and enhance the powers of the National Companies and Securities Commission in ways which we as an Opposition have previously sought. The amendments represent a reasonably speedy response by the Ministerial Council to the weaknesses which a number of Supreme Court decisions earlier this year revealed in the original statutes, particularly weaknesses which were revealed in the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act which deals with the takeovers code.

Before I make more specific comments about the amendments which are proposed, I would like to make some brief comments on the rather quaint legal decisions which have made this amending legislation necessary. Quite frankly, the Opposition was astonished and dismayed at some of the Supreme Court decisions. For instance, the decision by Mr Justice Sheahan in the Queensland Supreme Court in many circumstances effectively prohibited the NCSC from conducting hearings into company takeovers. Surely that is what the whole of that legislation was all about. In my view, narrow and mistaken legal interpretations in that case severely weakened the clear intention of the legislation expressed in section 36 of the National Companies and Securities Commission Act, which gives the NCSC a general power to hold hearings. In my view, this extraordinary decision pointed to one of the fundamental flaws of the co-operative as distinct from national approach to company law. Clearly, it is open for each of the States supreme courts to adopt a different interpretation of the law and, in so doing, make a mockery of the concept of national uniformity.

We can only wonder at how often we will find ourselves debating in this national Parliament, amending laws made necessary by disparate and disjointed legal interpretations adopted in any of the States' courts. How often can we be assured that quick Ministerial Council responses will be forthcoming under the cumbersome decision-making processes of the scheme? How many important cases in which action is required will be swept under the carpet while such amendments are awaited? Already we have seen the unsatisfactory deal between Ron Brierley's Industrial Equity Ltd and the Sydney Stock Exchange. This became necessary following a decision in the New South Wales Supreme Court. The deal did not involve a compulsion on IEL to complete a takeover, thereby giving fair and appropriate opportunities to minority shareholders. But rather it merely led to a partial divestment of the IEL shareholdings in Hutton Ltd. The deal lost sight of the original intention of the takeover code-the protection of the rights of minority shareholders.

It is to be hoped that the amendments provided in this Bill will rectify these immediate problems. The amendments to the Companies Act include the insertion of a new section 16A which provides specifically for investigations by the NCSC where the Commission has reason to suspect that a person has committed an offence under the Act. This strengthening of the investigatory powers of the Commission is welcomed by the Opposition. We note that this power extends also to the acquisition of shares codes. I suggest that that would appear to be where it is most needed. Most of the other amendments to the Companies Act are not controversial or of great significance, and all are supported by the Opposition. They will, I hope, assist the Commission in the administration of the Act when it commences.

As we understand it, it is currently planned to bring the company law into effect on 1 July this year. I understand, however, that the necessary legislation has not yet been passed by one of the State parliaments owing to the Tasmanian election. It seems quite possible that Australia will therefore still not have a uniform company law after July. It is already over seven years since the conservative political parties in this country rejected Labor's National Companies Bill and almost seven years that we have awaited the completion of the cumbersome hybrid that is the co-operative scheme. I wonder whether the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner), who represents the Attorney-General ( Senator Durack), would be able, at the conclusion of this debate, to inform the House as to what the Government now expects will happen in relation to the commencement of this legislation.

The second Act which forms part of the companies scheme and which is amended by this Bill is the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act, which sets out the law in relation to takeovers. I have already indicated the Opposition's reaction to some of the cases which have been dealt with under this code. The amendments proposed are of considerable importance. The courts are given the power to make interim orders; that is, orders which may secure the rights of certain parties before a full hearing has been completed and a decision given. The NCSC is also to be given the power to make orders in a new provision, proposed new section 60A. Where the NCSC has declared an acquisition of shares or other conduct to be unacceptable pursuant to section 60 the Commission may now make orders regarding acquisistions, disposal and transfer of shares. This provision should greatly enhance the Commission's powers under this code, and brings them more into line with the greater powers which had already been conferred under the Securities Industries Act.

The provisions in relation to section 60 are also amended in other ways. The Commission is now to have 90 days, instead of only 14, in which to make a declaration. In another change, it is intended that target companies and their members may apply to a court for orders to protect the rights of any person affected by unacceptable conduct. Each of these amendments is clearly sensible.

Very briefly, I mention also the Opposition's support for the changes to the Securities Industry Act. These include provision for interim orders by the supreme courts in relation to sections 14, 83 and 147 of the principal Act. Once again, these streamline the powers available under the legislation and shorten the reaction time of the authorities. In an industry in which speed and flexibility are of paramount concern these amendments must be welcomed, and we in the Opposition do just that.

It remains for me to make only one further point in relation to the companies and securities package with which this Bill deals. As I have indicated in relation to other areas of the administration of law which are the responsibility of the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, it is going only half way to ensuring that the statute is well drafted and effective; equally important is the quality of the administration of the law. The National Companies and Securities Commission has already done an excellent job, given the extreme constraints which have been placed on it. We in the Opposition applaud the efforts the NCSC has made to this time. But unfortunately it has to work, largely on the basis of goodwill, with a mixed bag of corporate affairs commissions which are maintained by the States. At the same time, it continues to suffer from a staff ceiling which is ridiculously low, indeed significantly below the levels which had been anticipated as necessary by the Ministerial Council.

The work load at present, of course, is largely associated with only the securities industry and the acquisition of shares codes. In July, or soon after, the companies code will be added to the responsibilities of the Commission. One shudders at the thought of the work pressures that could arise if a heavy period of company failures or other problems arise later this year as the recession in this country deepens. I appeal to the Government to reconsider its entire attitude to the provision of resources to bodies such as the NCSC. There is absolutely no serious controversy about the need for effective companies and securities regulation. This is not an area which can be sensibly considered as being subject to de-regulation or small government rhetoric.

The health and strength of the private sector depends on the confidence that the investing public has in it. That is what companies and securities regulation is all about-maximising disclosure, security and confidence in relation to the investment of funds in limited liability enterprises. It is the Opposition's strong hope that when the Fraser Government finally appoints its sixth Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs he will demonstrate a responsible attitude by reinforcing the staff and resources of the National Companies and Securities Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Albury-Wodonga Development (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill seeks to vary the conditions under which certain financial assistance is provided pursuant to the Albury-Wodonga Development (Financial Assistance) Act 1973 and to repeal section 10 of that Act. The sad thing about this Bill is that, although it has far reaching implications, the second reading speech of the Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) and the explanatory memorandum fail to explain the tragedy of the lack of action and support by this Government in relation to the Albury-Wodonga concept. Section 10 of the principal Act provided Commonwealth moneys for the States of New South Wales and Victoria to acquire land and to carry out public works programs in a planned decentralisation proposal for Albury-Wodonga. It was an historic experiment and an historic decision. It involved three governments, two conservative State governments-that of Victoria and of New South Wales-with, of course, the Commonwealth Labor Government of 1972-75. Moneys were made available to those States at the long term bond rate to be repaid over 30 years. No interest was to be paid in the first 10 years. It was to be deferred, capitalised, and repaid over the remaining 20 years of the loan. The conditions were set to allow the Development Corporation to get the Albury-Wodonga project under way, to give it time to allow it to generate income and to pay off its long term loan which, of course, within a year or two, would have been coming forward.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3 of the amending Bill will repeal section 10 of the original 1973 Act. Clause 4 ensures that, except in the case of loans for municipal works, the States are now relieved of any obligation to pay interest that may have accrued on loans prior to July 1981. But, in lieu of repayments to the Commonwealth, it was agreed that the Commonwealth would have access to the funds generated from the development activities. The proposed amendment to the 1973 Act will enable the new agreement to be implemented.

Before I examine why the Commonwealth has taken this action, let me outline briefly some of the aspects of the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation proposal. Albury-Wodonga was first proposed as a selective growth centre in 1969 by the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Whitlam. He proposed it, spoke about it prior to the 1969 election and developed his arguments during that election. He again brought it forward in 1969 when I became spokesman for the party on urban and regional affairs and developed the arguments in support of that concept. Mr Whitlam again brought it forward, on behalf of the Labor Party, in his policy speech of 1972. One of the early actions of the Whitlam Government when elected in December 1972 was to seek a conference with the New South Wales and Victorian State Liberal governments. A meeting was held in Albury on 25 January 1973. Arising out of that historic meeting, the Prime Minister of the day, Mr Whitlam, issued a Press statement. It is a very historic document and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
ALBURY-WODONGA
Introductory Statement by the Prime Minister, Mr E. G. Whitlam, Albury Civic Centre, 25 January 1973

This is an historic meeting. It is the first time on which the Governments of the two oldest and most important States have come together with the Commonwealth to plan the development of a new city. I trust it will signal the beginning, not only of similar regional development projects, but of a new spirit of common enterprise within our federation. The Murray River, once the symbol of colonial separation and interstate rivalries, may yet come to stand for a new era of interstate co-operation.

All three Governments represented here are committed to decentralisation. New South Wales and Victoria have worked towards this goal over many years. But my Government believes that only with the active participation of the Commonwealth, in a scheme involving all three Governments as well as the local authorities, can real decentralisation be achieved.

This enterprise is therefore a challenge to our energy, our ability to work together, and our determination to ensure the success of a pilot project which may one day convert our former dreams and theories into living and concrete reality. On the outcome of this task, the whole future of decentralisation in this country may stand or fall.

My Government is committed to the concept of building new cities. In my policy speech last November, I announced that at first we would concentrate our initiatives and endeavours in the Albury-Wodonga area. In making this choice, we were conscious that as a national government our involvement would benefit two States, and ease the pressure on our two largest cities-Sydney and Melbourne.

As I have mentioned, we regard this project as only the first of several new cities with the development of which we will be involved. We are determined, therefore, to use our full resources to ensure its success. We believe that the chances of success are high. Its location on the transport corridor between Melbourne and Sydney will be attractive to industry. It has an adequate supply of water. It is convenient to major recreational areas, and its natural environment provides a beautiful setting.

Let me outline briefly what the Commonwealth hopes to see happen at Albury- Wodonga. We look first of all, for a significant acceleration of population growth. Much of this increased population would, we hope, be made up of people who would otherwise have gone to Sydney or Melbourne. We want to see Albury- Wodonga achieve the status of a major city. We set no limit to its growth, but believe that if the new city is to achieve its major purpose it should have at least 300,000 people. And this growth will be planned to ensure a quality of life at the highest level. Pollution will be controlled: The environment protected.

The economic benefits of this development must pass to the people of Australia. Large sums of public money must be spent. We believe that this can give a good return but we must ensure that the return is to the community at large and is not tapped off to provide an unearned gain to land speculators. We want land to be cheap and its use to be controlled in such a way that the new city is both beautiful and efficient. We also want home ownership in the new city to be less of a burden to families than it has become in the major Australian cities. To this end the Commonwealth believes that the leasehold system must prevail.

From the beginning of this major project, we want local people to be involved in its planning and operation. We hope that the machinery which is devised to develop and operate this new city will, in at least some respects, become a model for future local and regional Government.

The Australian Government has available-in the National Capital Development Commission and the National Urban and Regional Development authority-the fund of technical expertise which has conceived, planned and built in Canberra, the only substantial new Australian city of our time. For historical and constitutional reasons we have had a particular connection with the Murray River. The Commonwealth will be associated with supplying the quantity of water required by the new city through the Snowy Mountains Authority and the River Murray Commission.
Let me outline now the steps my Government has already taken to ensure the success of this centre.

The Postmaster-General's Department has been instructed to prepare a report on the cost of recognising Albury-Wodonga as an extension of the Metropolitan area of both Sydney and Melbourne, for the purpose of keeping telephone and telex charges at a suitable level for industry.

The Australian Universities Commission and the Australian Council of Advanced Education have, as I have already indicated in my letters to Sir Robert Askin and Mr Hamer on the 15th of December, been instructed to confer and report on the provision of tertiary education facilities in this area.

In accordance with the recommendations of Sir Henry Bland on the Victorian Land Transport System, The Bureau of Transport Economics has been instructed to investigate the impact of inter-system rating practices on rail traffic from the Riverina.
All Departments in the Federal Government have been asked to investigate the possibility of locating divisions of the Public Service in Albury-Wodonga.
The new Department of Tourism and Recreation has been instructed to investigate tourist development in Albury-Wodonga and to recommend a program for increasing it.

Finally, as you are aware, my Government is committed to amending the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act to give local authorities access to the Commission. We propose to encourage all relevant local authorities in the Albury -Wodonga area to consult and co-operate in preparing such a submission on a regional basis. The new Department of Urban Affairs and Regional Development will make its expert advisers available to any co-operative effort among the local authorities.

I do not wish to anticipate the detailed decisions that will flow from this meeting, but I trust we will reach common agreement on our objectives, and set in motion a feasibility study of the project. I hope we will reach agreement upon the general structure and essential powers of the tripartite development authority, on the structure of consultation and supervision at Ministerial level , and the procedure for involvement of local authorities.

I am grateful to the Governments of New South Wales and Victoria for their generous co-operation in this scheme and for the valuable work they have already done to ensure its success. Let us bend all our efforts to work in harmony together and achieve our aims. None of us here is indifferent to the present sprawling growth of our major cities, with all the waste, the pollution, the inefficiency they bring, and the baneful effect of their unchecked growth on the living standards of our people. Here is a chance, in the most literal sense, to build for tomorrow and improve the lives not only of the people of this region, but of other cities, today and in times to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. I might say that on that day I learned a great deal because for the first time as a Minister I attended a conference at which State governments representatives, Federal government representatives and representatives of local government authorities met. I saw the tension that existed at that time. I was concerned that it might seem that we had come from a foreign land to take over and lay down demands. Certainly, I believed that the only real way that we would develop Commonwealth-State relations on that project was to do it in a gentle way. On that day maybe I realised the sensitivities that I still hold as a politician, even though I have been around for a long time. I felt that I did not want to try to force on to the States our new Commonwealth-State programs. I wanted to do it in a spirit of co-operation. Certainly, that was the way that Ministry functioned during those years when I was Minister. With great pride I must say that the bureaucrats who worked with me then were able to carry out my instructions. I told them things in nice quiet terms. Maybe it was in those male chauvinist days, but I said that I did not want to see any hairy chested Federal bureaucrats from my department going to the States laying down the law. I wanted to make sure that when they went there they discussed the arrangements with the States in a gentle, persuasive way. The only way we can solve the problems of decentralisation and the problems of the cities is with a spirit of co-operation between State, Federal and local governments together with the private sector. There has to be a spirit of co- operation. That is how we did it in the Department of Urban and Regional Development between 1972 and 1975. We will do it in the same way in the years from 1983 through to 1986. There is no doubt in the world that there will be a change of government in this country. We will be developing and carrying out our programs during those years.

SPEECH.PARA: As part of the Albury-Wodonga proposal it was agreed that a study would be carried out in an area bounded by a circle with a 55-kilometre radius. This was measured from the centre of Union Bridge, a bridge linking Albury and Wodonga. It was determined that within this area a new complex would be developed and a study would be made. It was also an area to which land price stabilisation legislation would be applied in respect of the land acquired for the purposes of the growth complex. Subsequently, the area of land was reduced to that finally agreed to by the three governments. The matter was finalised by 30 June 1974. The land purchases were based on the land stabilisation prices of October 1972. The concept was to create a city where people can live in harmony with their surroundings, where dearly loved townscapes are preserved, where landscapes make full use of our natural trees and shrubs and where the planning process is flexible and spontaneous.

The Albury-Wodonga area was a very gentle area. It was cleared to the snow fields. It was a very pleasant place where people were able to bring up their families. We wanted to create a city with an environment which would allow people to acquire a block of land at a reasonable price. It was agreed by the three governments that when the outline of the development area was completed all the land that was not zoned non-urban would be publicly acquired by the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation. Residential land would be sold freehold but development rights would be retained by the Development Corporation. All other land-commercial, industrial and recreational-would be leasehold land. The principle behind that was that if enormous capital were put into the infrastructure for the development of that area the people themselves should benefit from the capital appreciation of the land as those improvements added to the wealth of the land. We drew on the Canberra experience and agreed that we would create Albury-Wodonga along similar lines.

Credit is not often given for one of the few things that Menzies did in his era , the development of the National Capital Development Commission from 1957 onwards. The great development of Canberra, as we see it today, really reflects the imprint of Menzies and the Commissioner appointed at that time. A planned city has been built here in Canberra. One can still buy land here at about one- third or one-fourth of the price payable in many cities of Australia, particularly Sydney. We wanted to create the same concept in Albury-Wodonga. In fact, if we did it in more places I am quite sure that young people would be able to purchase land at a much more reasonable price. The Albury-Wodonga development area was located in pleasant surroundings on the Murray River and we purchased land. It was on the main road and rail transport corridor between the major cities of Sydney and Melbourne.

In the years between 1949 and 1972 Australia's population grew at an average rate of 1.9 per cent per year. In 1972 Australia had a population of 13 million. Most of the increase in the population from the end of the Second World War until 1972, through both natural growth and immigration, had settled in our capital cities. The overwhelming majority of people resided in Sydney and Melbourne. It was proposed that by the turn of the century both of those capital cities would have a population of five million.

In introducing the National Urban and Regional Development Authority Bill in October 1972 Sir William McMahon, the Prime Minister of the then conservative Government, argued that Australia would have a population of 23 million by the turn of the century. That would mean that from about 1972 through to the turn of the century there would be an increase of 10 million in the population through both natural growth and immigration. At that time, in debating that Bill in this House, I argued on behalf of the Australian Labor Party that such a population growth would be madness. Let me tell honourable members why I think it would be madness. Even if we could slow down the growth of our cities by locating one million people in selected growth centres, the remaining nine million people would be located in our capital cities. That would create chaos. Most of those people would move into Sydney or Melbourne. I argued that we must slow down our population growth, both natural and through immigration, to 1.1 per cent. That meant by the turn of the century the population would have been about 17.5 million, an increase of 4.5 million during that period.

If we slowed the growth in our capital cities by one million, which was equal to what was happening in the new town commissions in Britain-I might say that was done between 1945 and 1970 and that was the best record in decentralisation of any nation in the Western world-if we could still equal that by getting about one million people to go into our decentralised areas, we could then rationally accommodate the remaining 3.5 million in our capital cities and lift the standard of living of the people in those cities. That was the plan of the Labor Government from 1972 to 1975.

We planned for a population of some 300,000 for the growth centre of Albury- Wodonga by the turn of the century. Then Professor Borrie, in a report to the Parliament in 1974, estimated that Australia's projected population by the turn of the century would fall from the 23 million that Prime Minister McMahon predicted to 17.5 million because there had been a fall in natural births and the intake of migrants into this country. As I have said, Labor's program for Albury-Wodonga was based on a projected population of 17.5 million by the turn of the century. We are now confronted with the latest estimate by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) who, in his statement in 1981, projected that there would be a population of approximately 19.5 million by the year 2000. That projection is made because in the last few years, particularly the last four or five years, there has been an increase in the immigration intake and an upturn in the natural growth.

That is the situation. Our program for Albury-Wodonga was based on a projected population of 17.5 million. Now, with this projected population of 19.5 million, we ask: What are the prospects for the future? There seems to be no planning. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is a man of compassion. He has shown some thought and concern about planning. I must say that he is the only Minister who seems to give some thought to this matter. It is not much good just one person being involved; we have to start to look at the real policies that are involved. We have to look at what is happening in the western and south- western suburbs of Sydney. The honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) comes from an area which has the fastest rate of growth of population in the whole of metropolitan Sydney. We can look at the western and the south-western corridors of Sydney. We can look at some of the growth centres in New South Wales where there will be a growth in population, in areas such as Wallerawang and Lithgow, of something like 8,000 in the next few years because of an upturn of concern about the energy problem and, hence, the need for exports of coal. We can look at the Hunter Valley. We can look at the LaTrobe Valley. My colleague the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham), who will follow me in the debate , will speak of the problems that are occurring there.

We can look at the centres around the Brisbane area which have grown because of demographic changes. Within the next few years the real problems of housing and the pressures on housing in the Brisbane metropolitan area and in the south- eastern part of Queensland will be enormous. Yet nothing is done by this Government about planning. There has been no work in co-operation with the Government of Queensland and the councils in those areas. We can look at the situation still further north where we see the chaos and the growth in Gladstone and the awful lack of social and physical planning which has occurred. This is an utter disgrace to all governments. It is certainly a disgrace to the Australian Government and the Queensland Government. The burden has been thrown on to local government representatives, so much so that the people have revolted against any further growth in the area until the social infrastructure is improved by the governments. We must look at what has to be done.

Let us examine what the Federal Government has done. For the first time in Australia's history we have a Federal Government that has no regional development policies at all. Federal funds for urban and regional development programs have been cut by 90 per cent under this Government. A small allocation in the 1981-82 Budget was made for the winding up of former programs. The growth centre program is now defunct. In April 1981 the Federal Government terminated the decentralisation assistance program and abolished the Decentralisation Advisory Board. The Government has dismantled former regional development programs. It has pursued policies which have had a dislocating effect on the lives of many people and a disruptive effect on the viability of regional economies. This Government has failed to bring any co-ordination into the process of industrial restructuring that has been occurring over the past six years. When the Albury-Wodonga Development Bill 1973 was introduced it received the support of all colleagues in this Parliament. The leader of the then Opposition-which is now the Liberal-National Country Party Government-who is now Speaker of the House, Sir Billy Snedden, said when leading for the then Opposition that the Opposition supported the Albury-Wodonga Development Bill. He talked about the imbalance in the cities and the real problems in the growth of the cities. I quote from the Hansard record of the debate of 29 November 1973, page 4104, on the Albury-Wodonga Development Bill and associated measures. Speaking on the Bills the then Leader of the Opposition said:
They will be supported by the Opposition.
He went on to say:

. . . Consideration needs to be given to the circumference and also to developing regional development centres so that the pressures on the circumference or the inner city are relieved by the development of the regional development centres.

He went on to support this scheme and to talk about the necessity for the development of such areas. But, somehow or other, they seem to be empty words. I could mention what was said by other members apart from the present Speaker. The present Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt), who at the time was the spokesman for the National Country Party on these matters, greatly praised the Bill. But somehow or other when they came to government in 1976 there seemed to be very little support for the legislation. As I said, I could quote what was said by many other members, some of whom are now Ministers in the present Government. But they have since given this scheme little support.

The record of this Government in respect of decentralisation has been appalling . Its record since 1976 is even worse than the record between 1950 and 1972. It has been opposed to any real planning at all. There has been no real contribution to planning. The Government, of course, believes in market forces, or what it calls 'free market forces'. In other words, it believes in the law of the jungle, in the survival of the fittest. It is not much good the Government claiming anything because it does not really believe what it says. The Government really wiped all of Labor's long term programs. Labor provided the initial stimulus. We thought that we could build that stimulus in the early stages of the development of Albury-Wodonga by transferring Commonwealth public servants to that area. We thought that industrial development would occur in later stages of the development of this area. Although Commonwealth public servants were not transferred to the area, the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation, to its great credit, was in fact able to attract industry which to a great extent has been extremely successful. To give the House some idea of the sincerity of the Labor Government in its proposal to transfer Commonwealth public servants to the area, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a Press statement I made on 22 October 1975 entitled 'More Public Servants for Albury/ Wodonga'.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR URBAN AND REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT

PROCTEXT.PARA: PRESS RELEASE
For Release Wednesday 22 October
MORE PUBLIC SERVANTS FOR ALBURY/WODONGA
The Australian Government has decided to transfer more of its public servants to the Albury/Wodonga growth centre.

The Minister for Urban and Regional Development, Tom Uren, said today that the Central Office of the Australian Housing Corporation with about 300 staff would be transferred from Canberra to Albury/Wodonga as soon as practicable.
'The Government has also approved in principle the transfer of the Central Office of the Bureau of Meteorology from Melbourne to Albury/Wodonga', he said.
'The timing of this transfer which will involve approximately 900 exployees is subject to further study.
'The Australian Government has also initiated negotiations for the leasing of office space in Albury/Wodonga for a regional taxation office with about 90 staff.
'This office will supply local services for the people of Albury/Wodonga and north-east Victoria. It will also administer the tax instalment scheme for Victorian country districts.
'It is significant that a number of tax staff have already volunteered to transfer to Albury/Wodonga.
'Transfer of each of these units will create employment opportunities for support staff in Albury/Wodonga.
'Where possible, vacancies resulting from the decision of public servants to opt out of the transfer program will be filled by local recruitment'.
'Detailed timing of the transfer will depend on further consultation with the units involved, with staff associations, and with the Albury/Wodonga Development Corporation.
'We would hope that those personnel seeking voluntary transfer will be moved to the growth centre as quickly as possible.
Mr Uren said that the Government had also decided to set up joint consultative machinery for the transfer of Australian Government employees to growth centres.

A Joint Consultative Committee would be set up with representation from the Public Service Board, the Councils of Australian Government employee Organisation, the Council of Professional Associations and the Australian Council of Trade Unions.
The Committee would recommend general conditions of employment to apply to staff transferring to growth centres.
A re-location co-ordination committee would also be set up for the Albury/ Wodonga growth centre.
It would include representatives of the Public Service Board, staff groups, the units to be transferred and the Development Corporation.
'The Government is conscious of the human factors involved in re-locating its public servants to growth centres'. Mr Uren said.
'We want any disruption to be kept to a minimum.
'In particular, we want to ensure that those involved in transfers are given the maximum opportunity to take part in making decisions on the transfer program .

'These two committees will provide a forum to consider how the transfers should be implemented, in particular the timing of specific transfers, the special facilities that might be required, and any special conditions to apply to staff transferred to Albury/Wodonga'.
Mr Uren said that the latest transfer decisions demonstrated the strength of the Australian Government's commitment to Albury/Wodonga.
'We are backing the growth centre with our money and with important units of our administration'. he said.

'We believe that the association with State Government transfers, these moves will give a stimulus to the growth centre and encourage the private sector to switch staff and functions to Albury/Wodonga.'

TALK.START.PARA: —In opening my remarks I want to make it clear that we of the Opposition support the Albury-Wodonga Development (Financial Assistance) Amendment Bill. This Bill will relieve the debt on the Albury- Wodonga Development Corporation. As has been clearly espoused by two previous speakers, the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) and the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Bourchier), this has been a successful enterprise. The Albury- Wodonga Development Act was proclaimed on 21 December 1973. In accordance with the agreement between the Australian Government and the State governments of New South Wales and Victoria the Corporation was established as an Australian Government statutory authority charged with planning and developing a regional area of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth looking at the first report of the Corporation, which was handed down on 30 June 1974, and reading to the Parliament and to the public what the Corporation sought to do. The report states that the Corporation sought to build a new and vigorous city in which there would be a high level of physical and social planning; that social planning would be tailored to meet the particular needs of different social categories, by age, income and lifestyle; that where possible the lifestyles of the existing population would be capable of continuing with minimal intrusion; that planning would proceed from a full understanding of the historical, social, ecological and geographical uniqueness of the development region; that all citizens would have the opportunity to be informed about and share in the shaping and planning of the new community; that planning would avoid excessive strain on existing resources and facilities as the population grew; that planning would ensure that the advantages of the growth were shared by existing residents and newcomers; that there would be adequate compensation for land acquired for development by the Corporation; that every possible care would be taken to protect the local ecology; that places of historical interest and importance would be preserved; that planning would ensure that future trends and possibilities were adequately prepared for; that planning would allow for maximum flexibility, both physical and social, to adjust easily to changes of need and desire; and that planning would respond to all these requirements with as new and as fresh an approach as possible.

The report went on to state that the Corporation recognised that the achievement of dynamic growth would depend upon the provision of incentives to existing and potential residents. It stated that these incentives would include real opportunities in housing, employment, education, health and recreation and should extend as far as possible to the total quality of life within the community.

There is no doubt that is a goal well worth achieving. The previous speaker from the Government side, the honourable member for Bendigo, criticised the running of the program to develop Albury-Wodonga because the Labor Government supposedly spent a lot of money. It amazes me that Government members, who espouse a free enterprise philosophy, appear to lack the expertise necessary in government to carry out that philosophy. In the last 10 years I have not met anybody who has regretted investing money in land. Yet we hear Government speakers saying that a Labor government wasted money by investing in land around Albury-Wodonga. Any money invested in land in the last 10 years has not been wasted. It is capable of being recovered and can be used again. Investment in land is a normal process of good business management, but the Liberal Government lacks the expertise of good management. There is nothing wrong with the approach ; it is the management by the Government that seems to be at fault.

For the first time in Australia, with the exception of Canberra, a new city was planned in conjunction with the settlement of its people. Even given the Fraser Government's cut-off in resources and its failure to decentralise Government employment to Albury-Wodonga, it has been a successful project.

The objectives set by the Ministerial Council on the Development of Albury- Wodonga in 1974 and revised by it in 1977 has meant that the growth centre project has progressed in a most satisfactory manner. The generation of employment, particularly in the private sector, has been the key to the success of the project. The Federal Fraser Government, by cutting off resources and failing to decentralise government employment, has limited growth considerably. However, the private sector development has guaranteed stability and a sound base for growth in all sectors of the economy of the area. The Corporation has devoted a major part of its resources and efforts to the encouragement and expansion of already established industry as well as to the attraction of new industry. Its aim has been to build on employment through the growth of basic industries-those industries which market their goods and services outside the Albury-Wodonga area. Basic industrial growth is essential to the economic development of the area. This has been followed by real development of the service sector. This, in turn, has strengthened the ability to promote the area still further.

I now refer to the planning of the area. Short-medium term plans to fit in with the principles of urban design and development established for the growth centre continue to be revised. These five to 10-year plans are developed to provide a clear idea of phasing to both the private and public sector. During 1980-81 a significant study of the needs and priorities of the community for the provision of social services was carried out. This indicated major concerns with youth, particularly youth unemployment, housing, public transport and isolation in new areas. Appropriate programs are now being developed in association with the local and State agencies responsible for these services. Further work is being carried out on examining and seeking ways to ameliorate the effects of border anomalies.

It is estimated that between 30 and 50 per cent of newcomers arriving in the growth centre are welcomed through the Development Corporation's arrivals program. People receive information and advice on settling into the area and are introduced to existing residents who could help or who have similar interests. The program is gradually being extended, with the use of volunteers, to welcoming newcomers. A children's services program aims to increase understanding of existing family support services in the Albury-Wodonga area and to make people more aware of them so that people who need them make better use of them. Groups and services approached as part of the program include play groups, school support groups, pre-schools, church groups and single parent groups. The principal aim is to encourage development of community-based services in areas of high need.

On economic planning, the financial implications of the longer term development continue to be monitored, with particular attention being given to the implications of the State and Federal governments in respect of land costs and returns. Further investigations and discussions on rates and charges for municipal head works have taken place. The location computer model has been used to assist companies and firms assessing the financial implications of relocating part or all of their operations in Albury-Wodonga. Some adjustments have been made to the model to improve its overall suitability.

On structuring planning, the new structural local and environmental plan for the New South Wales section of the growth centre has been gazetted and is now in operation. A number of local development plans have been prepared for those areas that remain in private ownership but are obviously located where development no longer could take place. Discussions continue with Albury City Council and Hume Shire Council to ensure that as far as possible procedures and zones are compatible. Two new interim development orders have been introduced in Victoria and each covers the Baranduda township and the West Wodonga areas. The remaining rural areas within Wodonga have now been incorporated as the rural cities interim development order. The rural areas in the Yackandandah and Tallangatta shires will likewise be transferred once the shires in question have new orders. Let me now turn to the area which I represent and also the area the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) represents. This is the Central Gippsland region of Victoria. This region includes the resource rich Latrobe Valley. I would like to compare the totally different approach that a Liberal Government has taken in Victoria to planning as against the Federal Labor Government's approach to Albury-Wodonga. In 1973-74 a statistical district was established by the Australian Bureau of Statistics around Albury-Wodonga in order to more correctly identify the growth rate. These figures show the Albury- Wodonga district as having a population of approximately 78,000 persons. The Central Gippsland area has recorded a population in the vicinity of 130,000 persons. During the last five years the population has increased by over 10 per cent. These figures are now available from the 1981 census and can be obtained from the Gippsland Region Information Unit, which is located at the Gippsland Institute at Churchill. The main increase in this population growth has occurred in areas most affected by energy developments. What initiatives of a similar nature to the Labor Party's approach to Albury-Wodonga were taken by the Liberal Government which was in government in Victoria? Further, is there a need to take a planning approach to the area?

The major source of change in the Latrobe Valley has been the development of the area's brown coal resources, first for the traditional purpose of electricity generation, and secondly for possible conversion to other energy forms. The potential scale and character of future use of coal for electricity generation has been illustrated by the discussion paper on future power station siting, released by the State Electricity Commission in May 1980, which indicated the possible need to build a number of new power stations at least equivalent in size to the current Loy Yang project. A further major impact could result from programs to use brown coal resources to supply alternatives to petroleum based products or to provide a substitute for natural gas. Plans are already well advanced for the establishment of pilot plants to convert brown coal to oil.

Closely related to the question of protection and development of the brown coal areas is the issue of providing for futher urban growth in the area. This is where planning comes in. Development of the brown coal resources has been the principal factor leading to urban expansion in the region. On the other hand, the large areas of land needed for brown coal extraction, electricity generation and other uses, together with factors such as transmission lines, oil and gas pipelines and transport corridors, will impose significant constraints on the possible scale and or location of urban development. It may even prove necessary to consider moving all or part of some existing urban areas to make way for coal -winning operations. Because these constraints will not apply uniformly throughout the region, there have been significant conflicts over the most appropriate land use policies for specific locations. Urban development policy in the region needs to consider both the possible overall scale of development- which will be determined mainly by future population growth-and the closely related issue of the distribution of urban growth, including rural residential development.

Housing development in the Valley needs to be directed towards both overcoming current unsatisfied housing needs and providing for the people coming to live and work in the region. A housing policy for the region should be concerned with those four main issues: The number of houses to be built, including those required to overcome the current backlog; the type of housing needed to meet the needs of preferences of residents; techniques for providing and financing an increased supply of housing; and locating housing within reasonable access of jobs and community facilities.

New power generation projects have increased direct employment in electricity production and related operations by more than 1,000 jobs over current levels of about 8,000. Important changes in the distribution of work places will also occur, as old power stations are phased out. Similarly Australian Paper Manufacturers Ltd expansion of its Maryvale Mill has increased direct employment in paper and pulp production from 1,100 jobs to around 1,400. The building of new power stations, the APM extension and coal conversion projects will involve quite dramatic increases in construction employment, which currently exceeds 3, 000 persons.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Customs Tariff (Anti- Dumping) Amendment (Countervailing Duties) Bill is to amend the Customs Tariff ( Anti-Dumping) Act by introducing to its subsidies and countervailing measures provisions the concept of reciprocity. Before examining the provisions of the Bill it is appropriate to provide some background to it. The anti-dumping law in Australia embraces two of the codes of conduct which were negotiated in the 1970s under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. These codes are the Anti-Dumping Code and the Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Code. The underlying rationale and purpose of these codes is to ensure that international trade occurs on a fair basis, and in particular countries do not use their powers over trade either to subsidise exports or to provide back door methods of restricting imports.

SPEECH.PARA: It is universally accepted that where imports of goods at dumped subsidised prices cause injury to home industries they are undesirable and should be prevented by countervailing action by home governments. However, it is also vitally important that such interventions by home governments should not go beyond the strict meaning of the anti-dumping and subsidies codes. To do so is likely to lead to mutually defeating retaliations, the obstruction of trade and the resurgence of protectionism. It is also likely to lead to inconsistent industrial policies.

Australia acceded to the Anti-Dumping Code in 1980 and the anti-dumping law was amended accordingly in 1981. The amendments also provided in effect for the application of the Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Code even though Australia had not at the time become a signatory to that code. The Government's hesitation in signing the Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Code was caused largely by the problem of the Export Expansion Grants Scheme. This scheme, whereby increases in the value of Australian exports are rewarded by grants by the Government, would appear to be in direct breach of the GATT code. Clearly, signing the Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Code would put this scheme at risk. However, as it turned out the Government decided to accede to the code, apparently in order to prevent the United States from imposing a duty on lamb imports from Australia.

On 23 July 1981 the United States Department of Commerce made a preliminary determination that Australia was subsidising its lamb exports to America. The Americans proposed to impose a countervailing duty of 6.81 per cent on those exports. The American action was almost inexplicable, because Australia's lamb exports were valued at less than $6m a year. They would hardly have been noticed on the American market, and certainly could not have caused any injury to American lamb products. However, following complaints and submissions from Australia, the American lobby groups which had sought the action withdrew their allegations. Accordingly, the case was dropped. Frankly, I believe that this demonstrates just how flimsy were the allegations in the first place. The remarkable thing is that, having won the battle, the Government then agreed to become a party to the GATT Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Code. In effect , the Government had been intimidated by a flimsy threat to impose duty on a minuscule export trade. The threat failed to stand up to examination and was withdrawn, yet Australia signed the code.

Whatever the merits or otherwise of the Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Code, this episode is a clear example of the bias and incompetence of this Government. Its policies are conducted on an entirely ad hoc basis. In April the Government announced the extension of the Export Expansion Grants Scheme for another year. Then, in September, the Government became a party to a GATT code which prohibits such a scheme. Of course, the explanation for this obscure behaviour is the fact that Cabinet is run by its National Country Party members and its country-based Liberals. How could our trading relations be anything but dictated by country interests when the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade (Mr Anthony), the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street), all of whom form the core of our foreign and trade relations, are also the rural confederacy which dominates Cabinet.

It would be fair to say that Australia is run by a coterie of agrarian bolsheviks. They are not even accountable to the Parliament. I might instance the behaviour of Ministers and former Ministers, members of the National Country Party, who saw fit not even to explain to the Parliament their mismanagement of departments when Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd and the ruination of the meat export industry were discussed in the Parliament. That demonstrates the point I have made, that Australia is run by a coterie of agrarian bolsheviks- arrogant enough not even to explain their actions to the Parliament.

To return to the main thrust of the Bill, I say that the Government, having obtained satisfactory arrangements for the continued export of primary products to America, and in the process creating great uncertainty in other sectors of industry, has now determined that it still has not made life totally secure for our exporters. The Government, having signed the GATT code in order to avoid unfair and unwarranted American actions, announced on 18 November 1981 that the United States itself was not following the code. Apparently the United States often failed to apply the injury test at all. Also, it used a broad definition of export subsidy in determining the amount of countervailing duty. Therefore, the Australian Government announced that it would breach the GATT code if Australian exports were dealt with by foreign countries in a way which breached that code. Surprisingly, this approach was taken just seven weeks after Australia signed the code.

That brings us to the Bill that we are debating, whose purpose is to introduce this principle of reciprocity into our anti-dumping and countervailing measures law. Reciprocity means, essentially, that we treat other countries in the way in which they treat us. The concept is currently a subject of heated debate in the United States. As many as half a dozen Bills providing for various versions of reciprocity have been introduced in the United States Congress. One of these Bills, for example-it is sponsored by John Dingell of Michigan-requires the President to retaliate against any country which fails to give United States businesses substantially equivalent opportunities to those offered to that country by the United States. The American arguments are based upon their perception that they pursue free trade, whereas other countries do not. This is thought to discriminate against the United States. It is thus argued that reciprocity practised by America will force or encourage a freer trade attitude among other countries. In America, there is doubt among economists and trade negotiators whether reciprocity is likely to cause a positive, free trade response or a negative, retaliatory and protectionist response. It is the latter problem, of course, which led to the development of the GATT codes in the first place.

From Australia's point of view, the problem is compounded. First of all, there is little doubt that the Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Code is stacked in favour of the industrialised countries. The code operates to make it very difficult for small or less developed countries to encourage exports of manufactured goods. More importantly, certain primary products are exempt for the normal injury and subsidies provisions of the code. This enables the heavily subsidised agricultural producers of the United States, Japan and Europe, particularly the European Economic Community, to cause unfair competition against more efficient primary producing countries. On the other hand, it is very much in Australia's interests to encourage expanding world trade, as our own prosperity is very dependent, due to our small size, on a large and growing traded goods sector. For this reason there may be net benefits in our supporting a code which is not entirely to our liking.

We must also acknowledge that ours is not a perfect record when it comes to free trade. Motor vehicle and clothing imports to Australia are strictly controlled by volume quotas. If the principle of reciprocity were to be extended indefinitely our position could be extremely weak. Already we are seeing difficulties in the United Kingdom where it appears that objection will be taken by the British to the export of Japanese designed, Australian built cars. Where do we stand, given the restrictions we impose on British vehicle exports to Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on my right will subdue the level of their conversation.

—If they listened they might learn something about their failings- particularly the free traders. All of these considerations point to the need for a very clear and well thought out trading policy for Australia. Clearly the National Country Party, which runs this part of our national economic policies, has not been able to devise a rational trading policy. I was interested when I picked up the Sydney Morning Herald this morning to see an article by John Short entitled: 'Grass roots attack on Anthony'. Even the National Farmers Federation, which I would have thought would have been happy with the present Minister for Trade and Resources, finds his lack of policies almost unacceptable. The simple fact is that we have signed codes that we do not support. We are now introducing amendments which effectively allow us to breach the code in question.

SPEECH.PARA: We have complete uncertainty regarding the future of export incentive programs, which in any case have been arbitrarily halved without any assessment of the economic effects of such action. We have tied at least one of our industries-the motor vehicle industry-into an export facilitation scheme which is inevitably subject to severe pressures due to our own heavy restrictions. The trade policies of the present Government are in an absolute shambles. The administration of trade by the Minister adds to the list of disastrous and incompetent performances by National Country Party leaders in this Government. I note that the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt), who is one of the National Country Party Ministers, is sitting at the table. He is not to be excused from the same accusation. It is no wonder that confidence in this Government of business, and increasingly of the rural community, is sharply declining.

It is in this context that the Opposition believes that the legislation now before us is inadequate. We support the Bill itself because, in the narrow confines of the particular code of trading conduct to which it relates, it deals in an appropriate way with the unreasonable attitude which certain countries have occasionally adopted. In particular, it appears to us to be less severe a form of reciprocity than that being advocated by many United States congressmen. The reciprocation we are advocating is confined to the Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Code. It does not do any more than provide for common trading rules between Australia and any other nation in this narrow field. In contrast, some proposed American laws would involve reciprocity which goes beyond the area of immediate complaint. For example, the Bill proposed by Missouri Senator John Danforth would authorise trade retaliation by the President in any area he might choose. A breach of the Subsidies Code by one country, for example, may lead to retaliatory United States breaches of the Dumping Code, import licensing or any other area.

If the United States ever adopts such extreme measures the Bill we are now debating will be virtually useless and it should be seen in that light. Accordingly, it is essential that while we safeguard our basic rights through legislation of this kind we must continue to support as far as possible the principles of multilateral trade negotiation, and the ideals of the Kennedy and Tokyo rounds of the GATT. In order to effectively do this, the Australian Government must devise a coherent and responsible trade policy. It must stop the deceitful double talk which has characterised its pronouncements on trading issues. The Prime Minister for one must stop this regular practice of talking free trade in international forums and unbridled protectionism to local industry audiences. Our international credibility and hence effectiveness in pursuing and promoting more open and mutually beneficial trading relationships depends on a significantly more consistent approach to trade by this Government. With this vital qualification, I wish this Bill a speedy passage.
