SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that the Crimes Amendment Bill 1981 was before the Senate in October last year and my colleague Senator Evans on that occasion moved amendments which the Government accepted. Of course they are now in the Bill which we have before the House. I also notice that the Government appears to have changed its mind, and now says that amendments will be moved in this House which will remove the amendments which were inserted in the Senate. We cannot see the logic of that position; we wait to hear the Government's explanation. I quickly remind the House of what was said in the Senate when the matter was debated there. The point that was emphasised-we all applaud it-is that the Bill is important because it brings about innovative changes to the law governing the sentencing of Commonwealth offenders. The Bill must be seen in the context that it flows from a report of the Australian Law Reform Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) indicated, apparently in his second reading speech, the question of sentencing Federal offenders was a subject of a reference to that Commission in August 1978. Mr Justice Kirby was assisted by Professor Duncan Chappell, an internationally known criminologist. They completed a rather large report. It was called an interim report although I notice it contained 636 pages. It was available in January 1980. The report was tabled in the Parliament. It contained two draft Bills as well as 129 specific recommendations. Let me deal with the proposals which were deemed to be urgent. There was the question of the establishment of an adequate Commonwealth victims' compensation scheme, which I understand is still not before us, provisions to give guidance to the use of imprisonment in the case of convicted Federal offenders and also the facilitation of the use of non-custodial sentencing options where appropriate. It is that latter part that we now have before us.

Those of us who have been involved in the legal profession know full well the problems in society that are brought about by people who break the law. It is clear that courts, when sentencing, are really trying to give some justice to the community for wrong-doings that might have been perpetrated upon it and are also anxious that there should be some deterrent to guarantee that the offender is not likely to commit further offences. The point made by Senator Evans is that it is very important to see some uniformity in sentencing, because it does not always happen. If we leave what is called a wide discretion in an area of reform we will get a multiplicity of results, and the community itself will be none the better for that. Senator Evans, in his speech in the Senate, said about this Bill:
The most important thrust of it is in the direction of alternatives to imprisonment.

The largest prison in Australia is in my electorate, and I am well aware of the problems associated with crime and of the problems that are not satisfied by imprisonment. Society always assumes that a person who is committed to prison will come out of prison a much better person. Prisons basically were a creation of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, and many of those built in the nineteenth century are still in the same condition. We can imagine that if we treat people like animals in a zoo we will get the results of that sort of treatment. The point is that most people who are sent to prison are not rehabilitated; in fact they deteriorate. That fact ought to be clearly mentioned when we are talking about reform.

It is important, in fact it is intelligent, in future to look at the ages of offenders before the courts. We would notice that many first come to the notice of courts under the age of 14 years. That is the time for society to look quickly at the obvious crime potential in a person before the courts. If we look at an analysis of the problems of people who are in prison we find that they are there because of a broken home life-no mother or father, or because of an alcohol problem or a violence problem in the home-and that certainly they have had no love and affection and no education. That does not cover the whole spectrum, but it covers 99 per cent of the people who come to the notice of courts at an early age.

Apart from learned law reform commissions such as this which point out the difficulties of imprisonment and the alternatives to it, some of which are suggested in this Bill, I would like to add that it is about time society recognised that when a young person comes to the notice of the courts the mere placing of that person in an institution results in a failure to remedy the defects in that person's life of a lack of affection, care, concern and education. Surely those defects must be remedied by society immediately. In other words, it might be more appropriate to start by giving some financial contribution to a person who might be able to care for that child to guarantee that the child gets all the care it needs and gets as good an education as other children would get. If we did that, in my view, we would cut the crime rate by a massive amount.

At present it must be costing at least $400 or $500 a week to keep a person in gaol. We can see how counter productive that is. Everything that happens prior to that-police officers trying to find out who the offenders are, the processes of the courts, the cost of paying judges and magistrates and such things-can lead to an enormous expense on the community. Then we get the dreadful problem, which all of us who have been through prisons know about, that prisoners are deemed by themselves and by society to have reached the bottom of the barrel. Very few people want to employ a person who has been in prison. There is some worry about their honesty or integrity of such a person. Again, a person who has been in prison recognises that society has now reduced him or her to the lowest rung of the social ladder. So what more has such a person to fear? Such people are no longer worried about shame. They have been shamed to the utmost of degradation. Therefore, they readily lapse into committing further crime on release from prison. Honourable members should bear in mind that society always knows that the person sentenced to prison will return to it within a period.

Mr Deputy Speaker, it must interest you to find that most sentences are less than six months in duration. So these people come back into society within a very short time. Analyses show that they come back to society in a much more anti-society frame of mind than when they went into prison, much more prone to commit further crime than when they were first committed to a penitentiary. They learn more about crime in penitentiaries than when they are outside in society. They meet people in penitentiaries who are prepared to assist them in further crime because that seems to be the only hope that they have of obtaining a living if society treats them in that way. I know, by the process of age, that if one lives long enough one might reform from being a hardened criminal to one who takes the straight and narrow. But that is not likely. We find that most people in prison are under the age of 25 years. We exempt from that the people who are guilty of the offence of murder which certainly is a different offence and, in most cases, basically a crime of passion. All of these things would form the thrust of what has been said by the Law Reform Commission. It said that we should try to find a more intelligent way to deal with offenders.

My colleague Senator Evans moved a number of amendments in the other place. In particular, he moved an amendment to proposed new section 18B to make provision for an application by an offender for further time to pay. Let us look at a person who has been sentenced and see whether we cannot get some justice as to whether he or she should be given further time to pay. I note that that amendment is about to be removed from the Bill by the Government. I do not see what advantage that will achieve. Apparently it might have caused inconvenience in State courts on the basis that there was to be a plurality of applications for continual time to pay. But if the alternative was to send a person to gaol one would probably find that the Commonwealth and the State would then have to dig into their pockets to look after the wife and children of the person in gaol . It causes society no end of trouble. Surely this could be looked at, certainly from the point of view of seeing whether the person has any assets that could be acquired rather than saying: 'I have given you time. You have not complied with the time; so off you go to the penitentiary'. The Opposition-I think the Government also obviously accepted this-thought that that was a rational proposition.

I will not delay the House for too long. This is a matter of what could be called definite debate. However, Senator Evans moved a further amendment to insert a new section 18C. To use my colleague's words:

. . . a new section . . . to provide that where there is a default in payment of a fine, the court is enabled to impose, even at that late stage, a non-custodial penalty, as well as further time to pay or as well as a custodial penalty in respect of that default, and, more importantly, proposed new section 18C imposes an obligation upon the court not to allow the imposition of a custodial sentence for default in payment of a fine except where there is wilful and unreasonable default on the part of the offender.
Certainly if a person is not going to make any effort at all the court has no alternative but to impose a custodial sentence.

But it is important that we, in our society, particularly at a national level, set a few examples. In my view, one of the things that we want to see is a report giving the reasons why so many people are committed to prison, and stating whether there is any alternative. I am anxious to emphasise, as one who has taken an interest in this matter for a number of years, that the most important thing is to keep people out of incarceration. We should certainly penalise them, but get them back to their place of employment as quickly as possible and perhaps direct them to make weekly payments of compensation to their victims out of their earnings, thereby clearly indicating to them that they have an obligation to society. To commit them to a penitentiary with hardened people, many of whom have no interest in reform, is an animal-like behaviour. Many young people, particularly at the age of 18 or 19 years, are destroyed if incarcerated in a cell with two or three others. The behaviour is beyond belief; more crime and more sexual assaults are perpetrated. There were no reasonable amenities in the penitentiary I mentioned. I hope it has improved now. It catered for 1,500 to 1,600 people and there was, I think, one education officer. This is the sort of problem we face.

The people who have the responsibility of caring for the inmates will quickly tell us that there is continual violence in the close confinement of a large mass of people who feel that society has offered them nothing except incarceration and who are prepared to take it out in any violent act towards anyone who has the difficult task of trying to care for them. The continual assaults and further crime inside the penitentiary make a laughing stock of the suggestion that society will be better off by the incarceration of these people. Certainly, we have to protect society from those convicted of murder-violent people who are against society to the extent that they will take violent action against others.

But we have to look closely at where the problem first arose. In most cases it arose under the age of 14 years. Certainly, teachers at school would quickly know whether a child was neglected or unable to get care and attention. Teachers should be able to alert the responsible authorities, both State and Federal, as to whether that child should be getting some immediate attention. If the parents are delinquent the odds are that the children will be too. But we should not accept that because the parents are delinquent the child has to bear the burden and society cannot do anything about it. I hope that when people talk about law reform they clearly understand the position that has developed in society and realise the failure of gaols-I know they have to be there-in the sense of reforming people or returning a better person to society. That failure is obvious now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to clarify a speech I made in this House last week. I refer in particular to page 1882 of Hansard. In that speech I dealt with the cost of tax cuts. I stated that to lift the tax free threshold to, say, $5, 000 so that everyone earning that sum or less would pay no tax, would cost around $1,680m. That would represent a reduction of $15 a week in taxable income for most taxpayers. However, the actual reduction in tax paid would depend on the tax rate which applied to the taxpayer. Therefore, it would not represent a tax cut of $15 a week but rather a proportion of that. For example, someone paying tax at the rate of 32c in the dollar would receive a tax cut of around $ 256 or $4.92 a week. I trust this clarified the comments I made last week.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to raise a matter which is of great concern to me and to South Australians. South Australia saw some fairly major changes under the Dunstan Labor Government. Unfortunately, this cultural revolution was at the expense of our industrial base. No doubt Dunstan would, in medical terms, suggest that the operation was a great success. However, the problem was that the patient died. Dunstan's socialist policies resulted in business and industry leaving the State and we soon had a large unemployment problem. Fortunately for South Australia the Government changed hands and industry is now starting to return to the State . An example given recently was that of a Sydney firm which moved to Adelaide and now employs between 200 and 300 people building parts for the off-shore oil and gas industry. However, the Australian Labor Party has learnt nothing from its past failures. The minutes of the ALP special convention held on 27-29 November last year indicate that if the Labor Party were to gain power in South Australia the emerging and fragile confidence which has been built up in our manufacturing industries could evaporate overnight.

I give just a few examples of the sorts of policies adopted by the ALP which, I believe, threaten the future prosperity of the State and the people in it. Not satisfied with a lean, efficient Public Service, the ALP policy talks of an increase in public sector spending. It will, of course, fund that extra spending by 'raising tax rates rather than cutting public expenditure programs'. After its disastrous exploits into the manufacture of clothes and a food factory, it has learnt nothing. It is going to press on and 'marshal capital to finance an expanded public role in the development of selected industries'. It will set up a statutory corporation as a merchant bank. It will not only supervise the development of the Cooper Basin but also nationalise it. I must say that that would really provide a great incentive for industry to come to South Australia! Further in the resources area, long term agreements will be subject to renegotiation where, in the view of the socialists, they are not in the best interests of the people. Any industrialist who runs the race of nationalisation and the renegotiation of contracts and actually survives and makes a profit has a few hurdles yet to come. The ALP states that:
The making of super normal profits should not be allowed.
However, it does not define what is its idea of a normal and super-normal profit .

The ALP, not content to increase the public sector, increase tax rates, nationalise certain industries, set up more Government-run industries, including a Government-run merchant bank, and renegotiate some long term contracts, then went on to set down a totally unrealistic wages and conditions policy. There is no doubt that, apart from the Public Service, there would be few left in jobs to enjoy the spoils. These Labor Party policies are a blueprint for business failures, unemployment and individual bankruptcies. In short, they are a disaster for South Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -With consideration of the 1982-83 Budget under way by the Government, I want to make a special plea for the Australian wine industry against the possible imposition of a sales tax on our domestic wines. Any decision by this Government to impose taxes on the sales of domestic wines would have a proportionately more adverse effect on the industry than the financial benefit which might accrue to the Government. This is confirmed by market studies over a recent 20-year period which indicate that the demand for wine has a high price elasticity. This is especially so for table wines, which account for over 50 per cent of total wine sales in Australia. In fact, the elasticity measure indicates that the reduced demand for wine is likely to be in excess of 30 per cent greater than the percentage increase in its price.

SPEECH.PARA: The expansion of the wine industry over the past 20 years in the Pokolbin area of my electorate and the adjoining electorate of Paterson has played an important and necessary part in broadening the economic base of the region and in providing greater economic stability. This expansion was extremely important following the dramatic decline in the relative importance of coal mining in the area during the 1950s and early 1960s. The wine industry has also been the basis of the growth in the tourist industry in the lower Hunter and throughout the Hunter region generally. Already tourism helps to employ over 5,000 Hunter Valley people full time and it earns between $125m and $150m annually for the region. If present growth is sustained, within 10 years tourism will be employing almost 9,000 people and earning at least $215m each year for the region. The vineyards are of vital importance in this regard. In 1972, 270,000 people visited the Hunter vineyards. In 1981 there were half a million visitors.

The wine industry has gone through a period of difficulties and the people involved in the industry have responded with energy and initiative in adjusting to changing circumstances. The industry must be given time to consolidate. Hunter Valley vignerons have had to absorb the financial setbacks of successive drought vintages in 1980 and 1981. After a record vintage of 23,000 tonnes in 1979, the droughts of 1980 and 1981 cut production to 14,000 and 11,000 tonnes respectively. The industry has shown considerable restraint in its pricing policies. In recent years there has not been an occasion when the percentage increase in wine prices has exceeded the all groups index of the consumer price index. From 1977 to 1981 the cumulative CPI increase was about 49.2 per cent while the increase in the price of wine was only 26.2 per cent. Although that has been partly due to conscious restraint by the industry, it has also been affected by a general oversupply of grapes and grape products. To a large extent this has resulted from changes in consumption and taste patterns over recent years.

The Government has been very strong on rhetoric about allowing the market to operate freely. If it follows up this rhetoric in relation to the wine industry, the industry will be able to complete the adjustment process, reach a new level of stability and enter a new stage of growth. If the Government chooses to compound the problems of the industry with further cost imposts, the capacity of the industry to adjust and restructure will be seriously imperilled. The claim may be made that in addition to its revenue potential, which I have already shown may be self-defeating, a sales tax on wine may discourage the consumption of alcohol. The fact is that alcohol consumption in Australia has stabilised at about 9.6 litres per capita for the past eight years and the trend in the market for wine in Australia indicates a clear movement towards lower alcohol wines. Any forced increase in the price of wines must cause a shift in demand to higher alcohol content beverages. One very serious implication of the economic problems of the wine industry has been the effect on the quantities of stock held for matur- ation. The result is that our wine producers are not always able to sell their wines at peak quality. This has a detrimental effect on the competitive position of the industry as a whole and a sales tax would only compound the problem.

In relation to this matter I seek the support especially of those honourable members with significant wine production in their electorates. I refer to the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Giles), the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Chapman), the honourable member for Indi (Mr Ewen Cameron), the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher), the honourable member for Moore (Mr Hyde), the honourable member for Paterson (Mr O' Keefe) and the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Hicks). Five of them are members of the Liberal Party and three are members of the National Country Party . They all sit on the Government benches. I may be the only Opposition member with a significant wine producing activity in my electorate, so I expect the other eight members to prevail on their respective parties to respond rationally to this question.

SPEECH.PARA: What does the communique say? The first two paragraphs basically accuse Australia, by its participation in the Sinai Multinational Force and Observers, of 'stabilising imperialism and exploitation in the region' and preparing the ground for 'implementing the greeds of imperialism'. What a quaint interpretation of democratic life and what an admission of their own perception of governmental power that is. All of this self-righteous rubbish on behalf of their 'oppressed' Muslim people comes from an embassy representing a regime which rejoiced in the detention of American hostages in Iran for over a year, a regime which has wiped out the members of the Baha'i faith in Iran and a regime which, according to a recent report from Amnesty International-an independent human rights organisation-has executed more than 4,000 opponents of Ayatollah Khomeini, including suspects hanged after they died under brutal torture. TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise two matters. The first matter, which is of concern, was raised at Question Time this afternoon and passed off, I think rather lightly, by the Treasurer (Mr Howard). As a result of inflation and the failure of the Government to move upwards the level at which incomes become taxable, the current base level at which income is taxed is equivalent to an age pension plus the rent allowance which is paid to an age pensioner. Under the means test which exists at the moment an age pensioner is paid the rent allowance only if he has no other form of income. In other words, it is the strictest social welfare means test which is applied. The rent allowance is paid to assist such a person to pay rent. At the present rate of taxation the $8 rent allowance which is added to the pension takes that pensioner's income into the tax brackets. However, because of the cumulative effect of a 12-month operation that income will not in fact be subject to tax this year. But the fact is that the tax exempt amount is very close to the current level of pensions and far below what one could reasonably suggest is an equitable level of tax exempt income.

SPEECH.PARA: Over a period and especially with the abolition of the indexation of the tax scales, we are seeing a massive transfer of income and other tax liabilities from those people in our society who are best able to afford to pay taxes. I draw attention to the comments of the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) and others about super profits. We are transferring the liability from the highest areas of income to the very lowest areas of income. The burden of taxation, as a percentage of income, is increasing in respect of those people on the lowest tax brackets while it is reducing for those people with the highest levels of earnings. That situation is not equitable and it is not something which can be supported.

I wish to raise another matter which is of concern I think to every member of the community. It also relates to the means test. The present operation of the means test in respect of the unemployment benefit and invalid pensions, especially as they affect those people who are disadvantaged, is a disincentive and is creating significant hardship for people in these categories. The levels of income which are allowed for unemployment beneficiaries and for disabled persons who are working in sheltered workshop situations are far below those which would apply if the standards which had been set some years ago-surely by this time they should have been improved anyhow-had been kept in real terms. In the case of the unemployment benefit, $6 is the allowable weekly income. This is hardly a form of encouragement for people to seek some form of employment so that when they apply for a further position they can say that they have had some experience. Such people are in fact told that they should be totally idle: If they undertake any form of training to fit themselves for work, they are liable to have their unemployment benefit terminated because they are deemed to be not available for full time employment.

I wish to raise also the matter of the income of people working in sheltered workshops. Extreme difficulties are being created for sheltered workshops in that they are unable to pay the disabled people who work in them a respectable wage without interfering with the pension entitlements of those disabled people who should be given special consideration and should be encouraged, if for no other reason than their morale, to take such work as is available to them within reason. They should not be discouraged by having placed on them financial penalties which are unreasonable at this time and which do not take account of the changes in costs that have taken place over a considerable period since those allowances were altered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jarman Mr A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Wednesday, 28 April last, the Australian Bureau of Statistics released the preliminary labour force estimates for March 1982. The figures show employment growth in Australia of 71,000, or 1.1 per cent, over the 12 months to March 1982 and 217,900, or 3.5 per cent, over the two years to March 1982. Whilst the figures indicate substantial gains in employment, I am concerned, as is the Government, about the moderation in the rate of growth of employment which has been apparent since late 1981. The developing weakness in the labour market is a cause for deep concern for me and I hope for all honourable members. The easing in the pace of employment growth has not permitted the progress made by this government's policies in 1980 and 1981 in cutting back unemployment to be maintained.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst it is disturbing that the economic achievements of recent years are now at risk, the important question is why, and what can be done about it? There are two basic reasons for this recent trend in our employment situation, namely, the continuing depressed state of the international economy and the recent escalation in claims for higher wages and reduced hours of work, supported by a higher level of disputation. Developments in the international economy are important to Australia, because, as a trading nation, we rely on overseas markets to enhance our domestic real wealth. Fluctuations in the international economy affect our exports and consequently limit our opportunities for economic growth. America and our major trading partners in Europe have recently experienced a period of slow growth, and this has had consequences for Australia 's exports.

Thus recent employment trends must be seen in the light of international experience and the difficulties we face in trying to isolate ourselves from international events. While we should recognise that the level of unemployment and inflation in Australia is below that of many Western countries, this cannot justify complacency. We must, as the present Government is doing, continue our efforts to achieve further reductions. It is, however, a sombre thought that unemployment in the area of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development is likely to rise to an expected total of 28.5 million by the end of 1982. During a period when the international economy is slack, such as at present, we should be encouraging increased investment to establish the foundations for future growth in domestic output, exports and employment. This is necessary so that we can reap the benefits in export markets, as and when sound growth in the international economy is restored.

I turn to what I believe are disturbing developments in the industrial relations arena. These developments are also contributing to the rise in unemployment, and they cannot be ignored. In recent months there has been a resurgence of claims which are far in excess of the capacity of the economy to pay. These claims not only concern higher wages but also seek reductions in working hours, which substantially increase labour costs of employers and costs to the Australian consumer-in other words, the wage earner and the taxpayer. Of course, none of us can ignore the compounding effect of strikes taken in support of such claims. In the three months to January 1982 almost all measures of industrial disputation showed a serious and significant deterioration. The number of workers involved in disputes was 169,600-more than twice as many as in the three months to January 1981. The number of workings days lost increased to a level of almost three and a half times higher than that for the three months to January 1981. This is hardly a record of which we can be proud, particularly when one considers the damage to our international reputation.

This level of disputation reduces the ability of companies to expand and to increase their work force. As a result, all Australians suffer. How can we expect business to be confident about the future with this worsening situation of wages and industrial relations? If labour costs rise too quickly and production declines, not only are jobs for unemployed people in jeopardy but also many existing jobs are lost.

(i) Executive Officer, Land Conservation (Scientific Officer, Class IV)- Bachelor of Agricultural Science, Chairman N.T. Soil Conservation Advisory Committee, Member Australian Standing Committee on Soil Conservation, and Delegated Commissioner for Soil Conservation.

(iii) Soil Conservation Officer, Jabiru (Scientific Officer, Class II)-Bachelor of Agricultural Science. Three years post graduate soil conservation experience in Alligator Rivers Region. (vii) Soil Monitoring (Scientific Officer, Class I)-Bachelor of Natural Resources (Hons.). Three years post graduate experience in resource surveys, and soil sampling in the Alligator Rivers Region. Experience and in-service training in computer programming.

(4) Yes. Dr Letts is also a member of a sub-committee of the Uranium Advisory Council especially concerned with environmental aspects of all uranium mining projects in Australia, including those in the Alligator Rivers Region.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has North Korea (DPRK) asked South Korea (ROK) for moves to reunify Korea as a confederation.
(2) Will Australia use its good offices with the ROK to foster such negotiations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The DPRK has not asked the Government of the ROK for moves to reunify Korea as a confederation.

At the Sixth Congress of the Workers' Party of Korea, held in Pyongyang in October 1980 DPRK President Kim Il Sung proposed the founding of a 'Democratic Confederal Republic of Koryo'. The DPRK's proposal was much recently repeated by Vice President Kim Il, in a speech broadcast over DPRK radio on 26 January 1982.

In making this proposal, however, the DPRK has consistently refused to acknowledge the existence of the Republic of Korea, the legitimacy of which it does not recognise. Indeed the DPRK went over the heads of the ROK Government to name those it wished to participate from the southern side in a conference to advance its proposal.

(2) There now exists-and have existed for some time-on the Korean peninsula, two separate states and two separate governments, both of which are widely recognised internationally, including by Australia.

It is for these two governments to enter into negotiations. The ROK is prepared to do this and has made a number of proposals for discussions between representatives of the two governments. The ROK has indicated that it would be happy to see the proposal for a Confederal Republic of Koryo discussed in such meetings. In contrast, by ignoring the existence of the ROK and refusing to discuss the question of reunificatoin with the ROK government, the DPRK has indicated a desire to set its own terms for the future of South Korea.

The question of reunification is one for Koreans to determine. As it is not a party principal, Australia's role in the settlement of the long-standing differences on the Korean peninsula is necessarily limited. However, judged on its merits, the ROK's approach seems the fairer and more realistic, and more likely to achieve a satisfactory and peaceful solution to current difficulties.

In all these circumstances, I do not see the point of our urging the ROK to consider a DPRK proposal which the ROK has already said it is prepared to consider in fair and equal discussion with the DPRK. We have, on the other hand, made clear to the DPRK that we are not prepared to consider the re-establishment of Australia-DPRK relations until the DPRK enters into real discussions with the ROK.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Of the 90 staff at the Kingston headquarters of the Antarctic Division on 26 March 1982, the following numbers were recruited in the Hobart area:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he give a written undertaking in July 1980 to examine an air trainer development program proposed by Slipstream Aviation based on Essendon, Victoria.
(2) Did he recently advise that company that a full examination of the project had been undertaken and the proposal rejected.

(3) As those stated to have undertaken the study did not examine the aircraft, visit the company, nor discuss the matter with those in charge of the development, how was the assessment program carried out.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In responding to representations by Dr Cass, the Member for Maribyrnong, Victoria, on behalf of the firm I advised, in July 1980, that material provided by Slipstream Aviation was being examined along with information on other existing aircraft and proposals in a study of options for the replacement of the Royal Australian Air Force basic trainer aircraft. This was the extent of my undertaking.

(2) Later, in October 1981, in responding to further representations by Dr Cass , I advised that none of the options considered, including the Slipstream Aviation concept, fully met the Air Force basic trainer aircraft requirement. I also advised that a further and separate examination was being conducted of the Slipstream proposal. This further examination was intended to supplement the earlier and wider study.

(3) Slipstream Aviation's proposal has now been subject to three separate but complementary considerations by my Department. Taken together these examinations represent an extensive study of the proposal. Briefly these three examinations were:

(a) Between March and June 1980, a comparative analysis of Slipstream's design concept was undertaken as one of a list of several aircraft. Each was processed through a standard performance assessment program. The study purposely avoided the use of brochure information or other claims by the aircraft designers.

(b) In June 1980, a separate examination of the Slipstream proposal for financial assistance was conducted by the Government Aircraft Factories and the RAAF. It was concluded that the proposal was unlikely to satisfy the Air Force's requirements and recommended that financial support not be given to Slipstream.

(c) Between August and October 1981, a further examination was conducted by Air Force and other Defence authorities, based on Slipstream's responses to a detailed questionnaire. The questionnaire sought further information regarding engineering competence, areas of specialist engineering support, production capability and other aspects.

The examination showed that Slipstream would be unable to comply with Air Force requirements for the award of a design authority and that it did not have the engineering and support capabilities needed to develop and prove its concept in accordance with standards and practices recognised by the Air Force. It re- affirmed that the proposed aircraft configuration was not consistent with the RAAF requirement and would involve high technical and cost risks.

In consequence of these examinations and findings, the Department advised Slipstream Aviation, on 27 October 1981, that its proposals were considered not to offer an acceptable solution of the Defence requirement.

Officers of my Department have a knowledge of Slipstream Aviation's capabilitites, its workshop facilities and of the activities in hand to construct an aircraft. My Department judged that a visit to examine the partly constructed aircraft would not affect the conclusions of its evaluation.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The 'export and grow' campaign consists of a group of films designed to alert manufacturers to the benefits that can be gained from export and the range of services from Government and other sources which can assist them in developing overseas markets.
(b) The 'export and grow' films were first shown on television in December 1981 . The campaign started on the initiative of the Trade Development Council and my Department.
(c) The total cost of the 'export and grow' films was $186,740.

(d) There is no advertising agency handling the campaign. The films have been approved by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal as 'Community Service Announcements' and are broadcast free of charge at the discretion of the management of each station. Twenty-four television stations have agreed to telecast them. The physical distribution of the films was effected by my Department.
(e) There is no set duration for the campaign. The films will continue to be shown depending on the scheduling by television stations of no-charge time slots .

(f), (g) The 'export and grow' films campaign is one of the measures adopted by the Government to stimulate individual manufacturing firms to develop their export trade. The films were not aimed at specific Australian industries or specific overseas markets. Accordingly their impact on individual firms in respect of specific export markets would be difficult and costly to evaluate.

(2) The expansion of Australian exports can be of considerable benefit to the Australian taxpayer. It provides direct assistance to the balance of trade situation, and generates employment opportunities, particularly in the manufacturing sector. Moreover, in many industries, a move into the export market is accompanied by increased production and hence a reduction in unit costs, usually to the direct benefit of the Australian economy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 21 April 1982 :

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the article in the Australian Financial Review, page 5, 29 March 1982 headed 'Departments miss Post deadline'.
(2) What are the reasons for the failure by the Minister's Department to make a submission to the inquiry into Australia Post before the extended deadline.

(3) If the reasons include a shortage of staff due to Public Service Board staff ceilings, will the Minister now ask the Public Service Board to recommend an increase in the Department's staff ceilings; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) and (3) The honourable member would be aware that all institutions of Government are extremely busy with many urgent tasks and deadlines to meet. My Department made its assessment of the priority that could be given to the preparation and lodgement of its submission to the postal services inquiry in the light of the strong orientation in the terms of reference towards input from the private sector. The question of adequacy of staff in my Department is not a relevant consideration in this matter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 24 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister order the preparation of an environmental impact statement for the proposal to develop coal deposits at Redbank Plains near Ipswich, Queensland; if not, why not.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to a document entitled 'Summary of Environmental Effects' prepared by Rylance Collieries and Brickworks Pty Ltd; if so, does it meet the requirements of an environmental impact statement under the provisions of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. As I pointed out in a news release of 4 March 1982, I considered that protection measures already imposed by the Queensland Government on the proposal to develop coal deposits at Redbank Plains were sufficient to protect environmental interests, and that an environmental impact statement was not required. In making this decision I took particular account of the protection measures embodied in lease conditions imposed by the Queensland Government, as set out in response to Senate Question No. 2016 which appeared in Hansard on 20 April 1982 (p. 1329-1330).

(2) On 6 March Rylance Collieries and Brickworks Pty Ltd released a report entitled 'Summary of Environmental Effects'. The report outlines the project in general terms and details the measures which will be taken to safeguard the environment. I understand that the report is available from the Company offices in Brisbane. The report was prepared with the purpose of informing government authorities, non-government bodies and interested individuals about the company' s commitments to environment protection relating to the coal mining project. It was not intended to be an environmental impact statement.
